commit_message:
Implementing client for new x509 support in nova.

* This depends on the approval of vishy's changes here: https://review.openstack.org/#change,3199
* Adds novaclient library code, and cli.
    CLI Use:
      nova x509-create-cert [private_key_filename] [cert_filename]
      nova x509-get-root-cert [cert_filename]

Change-Id: If5b833b90bfb5bc16ea4636abb667717a67065d3

subject: dashboard: Fix pop up menu location (bug 918452)
messages:
[{'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-01-18 23:55:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I can reproduce the bug in Firefox, but your patch causes a different problem. 

Chrome displays the correct behavior, which is that the dropdown appears overlayed on top of other form elements when hovered. With your patch, the menu appears inside the div, causing the row to expand in height during the hover event."}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-25 01:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-18 23:02:18.000000000', 'message': "dashboard: Fix pop up menu location (bug 918452)

On my F16 machine with Firefox 9.0.1, dashboard's popup menus don't work
(the example I'm trying is under 'instances + volumes'->'edit instance'
menu).

Hovering over causes the menu to appear quickly in the top left corner,
disappearing soon after since the mouse isn't anywhere near the menu to
keep it active.

Change the menu to position from 'absolute' to 'relative'. Fixes
bug 918452 for me.

(This sounds conceptually correct but I assume this must be working for
someone, so if this isn't the correct fix I'll be glad to help debug the
situation further.)

Change-Id: Ie8d34ce12b5231a822417b7a29e588c2c0cc914d
"}]
commit_message:
dashboard: Fix pop up menu location (bug 918452)

On my F16 machine with Firefox 9.0.1, dashboard's popup menus don't work
(the example I'm trying is under 'instances + volumes'->'edit instance'
menu).

Hovering over causes the menu to appear quickly in the top left corner,
disappearing soon after since the mouse isn't anywhere near the menu to
keep it active.

Change the menu to position from 'absolute' to 'relative'. Fixes
bug 918452 for me.

(This sounds conceptually correct but I assume this must be working for
someone, so if this isn't the correct fix I'll be glad to help debug the
situation further.)

Change-Id: Ie8d34ce12b5231a822417b7a29e588c2c0cc914d

commit_message:
Catch novaclient up with renaming and other nova changes.

Added novaclient support for dns domain manipulation.

This includes additions to the 'nova' commandline tool.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: I97b36d69f5f4abfbfa0ce416a347efa202fe3a0b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-20 01:38:05.000000000', 'message': 'Create nova cert extension for x509 support

 * Adds new worker for cert management
 * Makes decrypt use an rpc to the worker
 * Moves CA filesystem creation out of cloud.setup
 * Moves test for X509 into crypto
 * Cleans up extra code in cloudpipe
 * Fixes bug 918563
 * Prepares for a future patch that will fix bug 903345

Change-Id: I4693c50c8f432706f97395af39e736f49d60e719
'}, {'created': '2012-01-20 21:55:35.000000000', 'message': 'Create nova cert extension for x509 support

 * Adds new worker for cert management
 * Makes decrypt use an rpc to the worker
 * Moves CA filesystem creation out of cloud.setup
 * Moves test for X509 into crypto
 * Cleans up extra code in cloudpipe

commit_message:
Create nova cert worker for x509 support

 * Adds new worker for cert management
 * Makes decrypt use an rpc to the worker
 * Moves CA filesystem creation out of cloud.setup
 * Moves test for X509 into crypto
 * Adds test for encrypting and decrypting using cert
 * Cleans up extra code in cloudpipe
 * Fixes bug 918563
 * Prepares for a future patch that will fix bug 903345

Change-Id: I4693c50c8f432706f97395af39e736f49d60e719

commit_message:
Add flavor create/delete support

Makes use of the new nova module for flavor creation/deletion (still
under review at https://review.openstack.org/#change,3197

tests and cli commands added.

v2:
    Fix tests
    Fix pep8 violations

v3:
    Drop unused import

v4:
    Usage defaults to end date 'tomorrow'

v5:
    Undo unintentional change

v6:
    Drop useless comment
    Fix meta var name for flavor-delete command

Change-Id: I14baa02d5cbe5eaf17875c285c993508b1671a13

bug 917397

Add configuration sanity to QuantumManager. Logs error message
if a parameter not used by QuantumManager's create_networks()
method is passed into it.

subject: Add a 'usage' module and 'usage-list' cli command
messages:
[{'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-23 17:32:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Hey Cole - looks like you need to run pep8 on the files you modified to identify some whitespace issues'}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-23 18:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-23 18:48:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-23 19:30:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Cole - since usage_list is only available to admins, perhaps add usage_show that would default to the current tenant?  Then this is useful for regular users as well.'}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-23 20:33:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Anthony,

usage-shot is a good idea, but at the moment novaclient doesn't provide a good way to map the authenticated projectid to the tenantid required for the usage API.

I'll be happy to add that (should be a simple addition) along with the usage-show bit, but I think it's best left for a separate patch."}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-23 20:50:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Cole - that's cool, show isn't critical right now.  One more inline comment."}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-23 21:18:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-23 21:18:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-23 21:23:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Add a 'usage' module and 'usage-list' cli command

This module talks to the nova extenstion os-simple-tenant-usage,
replacing the openstackx module currently used by horizon.

v2:
    Fix some pep8 and style violations

v4:
    Have usage-list default to including todays usage

v5:
    Fix a HACKING violation
    Fix rebase conflicts

Change-Id: Ica0b128c7b807b839abf23b4026e48bbee08b1be

[{'created': '2012-01-23 01:05:48.000000000', 'message': 'usage: Fix time filtering

Querying for resource usage within a given time range seems to have a
logic flaw: it will only report instances that have run the entire
length of the specified range.

AIUI What we really want is any instance that spent any time consuming
resources at any point in the specified range. Fix the logic to
implement this.

commit_message:
usage: Fix time filtering

Querying for resource usage within a given time range seems to have a
logic flaw: it will only report instances that have run the entire
length of the specified range.

AIUI What we really want is any instance that spent any time consuming
resources at any point in the specified range. Fix the logic to
implement this.

v2:
    Update function comments as well

Change-Id: I4fa567982457e5f447ec33cf3d96457f50d71d86

I also pulled in some of the changes from the linked patch.  In reality, most of this reconnect stuff in impl_qpid isn't necessary, because qpid has reconnection support built in, and it is enabled by default.  The connection flag that lets you turn it off is exposed, though (but I would expect it to be rare to never that it would be turned off).

Rebased on to master.

@Eric: Can you be a bit more specific about your concerns?  That code, along with some other code, is in nova.rpc.common because it is shared between impl_kombu and impl_qpid.  There's no reason all rpc implementations have to use it if they don't want to.  For example, impl_carrot doesn't."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-24 19:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-24 19:06:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I have to second Eric Windisch's concerns.  The abstraction for rpc was made my Zed Shaw in order to allow for different (non-amqp) backends.  Eric is working on the ZeroMQ driver and we should make sure we aren't preventing his code from working. I appreciate the code reuse, but moving everything into common is a bit of a step backwards.

Perhaps we could have a common amqp.py file (or even a section of the file that defines amqp_cast, etc.) for the shared code between the two and leave cast/call in the individual drivers.  It could just be a simple:
import amqp
def cast(...):
  return amqp.cast(...)

Eric, is there any other code that is a problem? Or is it just cast/call/multicall?



Is there anything other than cast/call/multicall"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-01-24 20:05:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I find having a common amqp.py an acceptable compromise for *all* of the changes made here in rpc.context, although I'm still not certain that this particular implementation is correctly abstracted for that purpose.

I need to think a bit more about ConnectionContext and Connection, with Connection existing inside of impl_* drivers."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-01-24 20:06:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-01-24 20:08:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

This patch includes a new amqp.py that includes everything that was originally moved out of impl_kombu to be shared with impl_qpid.  I'm sure there is room for improvement, but hopefully this is a reasonable compromise for now since it is out of the way of common."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-24 20:26:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-11 21:49:27.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for Qpid to nova.rpc.

Implements blueprint apache-qpid-rpc.

This patch adds a new implementation of the nova.rpc API that uses Qpid
as the messaging backend.  We first considered trying to add Qpid
support to kombu, but the kombu API did not map very well to Qpid, which
is based on a newer version of AMQP.  It was easier to just map the nova
rpc API to Qpid.

The structure of impl_qpid is largely based on impl_kombu, but adapted
to use the Qpid APIs as necessary.  The unit tests were written from
scratch instead of taking advantage of the common rpc unit tests.  The
common unit tests only work if qpidd is running, but they do pass if
enabled.  The unit tests for impl_qpid instead use mox to mock out the
Qpid objects and ensure the right operations happen on them when the rpc
API is exercised.

This patch was a joint effort between myself and William Henry, which is
why he was added to the Authors file in this patch.

commit_message:
Add support for Qpid to nova.rpc.

Implements blueprint apache-qpid-rpc.

This patch adds a new implementation of the nova.rpc API that uses Qpid
as the messaging backend.  We first considered trying to add Qpid
support to kombu, but the kombu API did not map very well to Qpid, which
is based on a newer version of AMQP.  It was easier to just map the nova
rpc API to Qpid.

For more information about how to use Qpid with Nova, see this wiki
page:

    http://wiki.openstack.org/QpidSupport

The structure of impl_qpid is largely based on impl_kombu, but adapted
to use the Qpid APIs as necessary.  This patch also factors out some of
the code shared with impl_kombu into nova.rpc.common to try to cut down
on duplicated code.

The unit tests were written from scratch instead of taking advantage
of the common rpc unit tests.  The common unit tests only work if qpidd
is running, but they do pass if enabled.  The unit tests for impl_qpid
instead use mox to mock out the Qpid objects and ensure the right
operations happen on them when the rpc API is exercised.

This patch was a joint effort between myself and William Henry, which is
why he was added to the Authors file in this patch.

Change-Id: Ibacaa956e016ef96f014443074e2a4622e31f090

commit_message:
Drop eval-based json parser fallback

Drop potentially-unsafe eval-based json parser that was
used as a fallback in case simplejson and json were not
available. Let's assume people run Python 2.6 or can
install simplejson if they are not. Fixes bug 909568.

Change-Id: I1b1860a77de5075fcea291a4f1b320a3e9e6261f

commit_message:
Bug #916312: nova-manage network modify --network flag is inconsistent.

Change nova-manage network modify --network to --fixed_range, to match
nova-manage network delete.

Also document both.

Change-Id: I3c03a33e9e3576393252d771eb4ce3353a7f2eaa

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-21 01:08:19.000000000', 'message': 'Change the logic for deleting a record dns_domains.

Since keys are just the domain name, we need to be able
to reuse them.  That means we have to do a real record
deletion to free up namespace rather than just mark the
records as deleted.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: If47e961cf2cb977d297b506bd397f1a438499f18
'}]
commit_message:
Change the logic for deleting a record dns_domains.

Since keys are just the domain name, we need to be able
to reuse them.  That means we have to do a real record
deletion to free up namespace rather than just mark the
records as deleted.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: If47e961cf2cb977d297b506bd397f1a438499f18

commit_message:
Handle error in associate floating IP (bug 845507)

* Raise NoFloatingIpInterface when associate floating IP has an
  interface that doesn't exist.
* Return 500 Internal server Error, indicate only that associate
  action failed

Change-Id: I6b032f7554795de64bce8e669d20269210c62e33

[{'created': '2012-01-24 18:57:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add nova.exception.InvalidRPCConnectionReuse.

commit_message:
Add nova.exception.InvalidRPCConnectionReuse.

nova.rpc.common.ConnectionContext makes use of an exception that was not
defined.  This patch adds it.

Change-Id: Ibfbd2fc56dbcc36c8f271d5bc8c6e1db04ce8c93

commit_message:
horizon: Use novaclient for flavor create/delete

API is the same as openstackx, so it's an easy drop in. Also drop
all openstackx admin_api handling since it isn't needed anymore!

Change-Id: Ifa8c7f3bd3e0ba0e1664d6c3a87bf07853f3e693

commit_message:
Explicitly encode string to utf8 before passing to ldap.

Python-ldap sometimes behaves poorly when receiving unicode strings.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: If61c3b5bb9198e3870fb48974fa4a8fc072bb1bb

[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-20 00:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The "collection" argument to ControllerExtension identifies the resource being extended.  So, for instance, if you're extending the "servers" resource (nova.api.openstack.compute.servers.Controller), you use "servers", and if you're extending the "flavors" resource (nova.api.openstack.compute.flavors.Controller), you want "flavors".  See nova/api/openstack/compute/__init__.py for the values (they're the keys in the APIRouter.resources dictionary).

Hope this helps; feel free to ping me if my explanation was still too opaque :)'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-20 00:16:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-19 23:54:05.000000000', 'message': "Add an API extension for creating+deleting flavors

This extension is a step towards deprecating openstackx for horizon.
Most of the extension code is based on the equivalent in openstackx.

A few things I was unsure about:

- Delete operation takes an optional ?purge=[0|1] value. Is there any
    convention for boolean options or is 0/1 fine here? openstackx
    seemed to encode str(bool(...))

- Uses the URI namespace os-flavor-lifecycle. Is that fine? Is there any
    way to piggyback on the existing flavors namespace and extend that,
    or is that a no no

- ControllerExtensions is using 'servers' collection. not sure what it's
    for or what a proper value is.

Change-Id: I3fdfccdd8e7337e1759f5875c3b15fa9954371ef
"}, {'created': '2012-01-23 16:46:36.000000000', 'message': 'Add an API extension for creating+deleting flavors

This extension is a step towards deprecating openstackx for horizon.
Most of the extension code is based on the equivalent in openstackx.

v2:
    s/lifecycle/manage/ for all bits
    Address Pádraig style issues
    Drop purge API option
    Adjust now inaccurate comment in DB api
    Make extension admin_only
    Extend existing /flavors namespace rather than os-flavor-lifecycle
    Only allow API access from admin user

Change-Id: I3fdfccdd8e7337e1759f5875c3b15fa9954371ef
'}, {'created': '2012-01-23 20:19:12.000000000', 'message': 'Add an API extension for creating+deleting flavors

Change-Id: I3fdfccdd8e7337e1759f5875c3b15fa9954371ef
'}, {'created': '2012-01-24 18:31:08.000000000', 'message': "Add an API extension for creating+deleting flavors

This extension is a step towards deprecating openstackx for horizon.
Most of the extension code is based on the equivalent in openstackx.

v2:
    s/lifecycle/manage/ for all bits
    Address Pádraig style issues
    Drop purge API option
    Adjust now inaccurate comment in DB api
    Make extension admin_only
    Extend existing /flavors namespace rather than os-flavor-lifecycle

v3:

v4:

Change-Id: I3fdfccdd8e7337e1759f5875c3b15fa9954371ef
"}]
commit_message:
Add an API extension for creating+deleting flavors

This extension is a step towards deprecating openstackx for horizon.
Most of the extension code is based on the equivalent in openstackx.

v2:
    s/lifecycle/manage/ for all bits
    Address Pádraig style issues
    Drop purge API option
    Adjust now inaccurate comment in DB api
    Make extension admin_only
    Extend existing /flavors namespace rather than os-flavor-lifecycle
    Only allow API access from admin user

v3:
    Some pep8 fixes

v4:
    Adjust to root_gb, ephemeral_gb changes
    Drop admin_only (it's on the way out AIUI)

Change-Id: I3fdfccdd8e7337e1759f5875c3b15fa9954371ef

commit_message:
Add support for dealing with 501 errors (notimplemented)

This allows us to return NotImplemented() from an extension if the plugin
doesn't support a given function.

Change-Id: I73c6dec959aea7b2bde1378222b62e6fc82a5d43

commit_message:
Client.add_image() accepts image data as iterable.

Fixes bug 773562

Allow the image data to be passed to glance.Client.add_add_image()
via an iterator, in addition to the previously accepted images types
(file-like or string).

Change-Id: I1f90b9875f5610d478a5ed123fbf431501f1c2b6

commit_message:
More flexible specification of auth credentials.

Fixes bug 853933

Add new --username|--password|--tenant|--auth_url|--auth_strategy
switches to bin/glance to allow the username, password, tenant name,
and authentication URL & strategy be specified on the command line.

Avoid needlessly falling back to keystone v2 auth after a successful:

  GET /v1.0/tokens

returns with the X-Image-Management-Url or X-Glance header set,
as opposed to X-Server-Management-Url.

Extend the keystone functional test support to ensure that the URL
returned by keystone via the X-*-Url header contains the appropriate
dynamically allocated port for the glance API service.

Ensure the underlying $OS_* environment variables do not leak into the
TestPrivateImagesCli functional tests, also explicitly exercise both
noauth and keystone strategies.

Change-Id: Iee8bf3745d65a9c57a9da803d5cf9ae5f343a159

commit_message:
Update Extended Credentials (EC2, S3)

- format should be extension:credential.
- older format (extension-credentials, or ec2Credentials
  still supported for compatibility

Change-Id: I3e2651a37baeae411e626e97c4eb4e992cf4cf2f

The tests themselves make assumptions that are wrong with both approaches.  I can go either way with it.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2011-11-30 23:40:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Remove admin_only ext attr in favor of authz

Working on blueprint separate-nova-adminapi. This removes the
admin_only extension attribute and the allow_admin_api flag. The
approach we're going for now is to load all extensions, but
to set an admin-only rule in our policy file for those extensions
that should be limited to just admin users. Now that all of our
admin api code has been moved to extensions, in order to
prevent admin api code from being loaded, simply remove it from
the extension list.

Change-Id: Ic574e06af44922ba764013b769077fc5099fd1a2

[{'created': '2012-01-23 16:46:34.000000000', 'message': "extensions: Allow registering actions for create + delete

This allows an extension to add new actions for create and delete
operations to an existing collection.

Currently when extending an existing collection (API namespace), an
extension can register brand new 'actions', and extend any preexisting API
functionality, but unfortunately create and delete are special cases that
don't fall under the 'actions' classification, meaning the infrastructure
can't handle them unless extending an existing impl.

Stubbing out the create/delete methods in the original resource with
the equiv of a NotImplementedError doesn't work, since 'extend'ing
requires the original implementation to exit correctly.

Whitelist 'create' and 'delete' and handle them appropriately.

Change-Id: I550ae93c5e200f18644042ac81656bc76dbe8955

Change-Id: I550ae93c5e200f18644042ac81656bc76dbe8955

commit_message:
extensions: Allow registering actions for create + delete

This allows an extension to add new actions for create and delete
operations to an existing collection.

Currently when extending an existing collection (API namespace), an
extension can register brand new 'actions', and extend any preexisting API
functionality, but unfortunately create and delete are special cases that
don't fall under the 'actions' classification, meaning the infrastructure
can't handle them unless extending an existing impl.

Stubbing out the create/delete methods in the original resource with
the equiv of a NotImplementedError doesn't work, since 'extend'ing
requires the original implementation to exit correctly.

Whitelist 'create' and 'delete' and handle them appropriately.

v2:
    Add myself to Authors
    Update wsgi.action docs
    Add a test case

v3:
    Actually update Authors

Change-Id: I550ae93c5e200f18644042ac81656bc76dbe8955

[{'created': '2012-01-24 04:37:32.000000000', 'message': "Fixes LP#920812 - KeyError: 'overLimit' on 413 return

Turns out that over quota limit and over ratelimits
return different keys in the faults. This patch adds
a new exception for RateLimitExceeded that handles
413 returns when there is an overLimitFault key (and
not the overLimit key that is in the over Quota fault)

Change-Id: I64d10cb592512e7de71c5d8518131deee516d9b2
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes LP#920812 - KeyError: 'overLimit' on 413 return

Turns out that over quota limit and over ratelimits
return different keys in the faults. This patch adds
a new exception for RateLimitExceeded that handles
413 returns when there is an overLimitFault key (and
not the overLimit key that is in the over Quota fault)

Change-Id: I64d10cb592512e7de71c5d8518131deee516d9b2

commit_message:
Fixes bug 918388.

This fix forces RestfulTestCase.restful_request to send an
"Accept: application/json" header when calling for json static files.

This may not be the *best* way to fix this problem, but it does allow
the tests to pass.

Change-Id: Ib97f85f14a7e4577891d0687c7f97be909c239e0

commit_message:
Make a bunch of dcs into single-entry lists.

I was seeing dcs where ['e','v','e','r','y'] character was
a list item, so clearly ldap is going to interpret this field
as a list whether it is one or not.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: I9f383b322e85d99783f9ce93bdfc4e0d3d94e2ed

commit_message:
glance-control need not locate a server's config file (lp#919520)

Before converting to cfg, glance-control would use find_config_file() to
locate the servers config file if the user did not explicitly specify
it.

With the change over to cfg, we screwed that code up. However, we should
instead just allow the server to locate its own config file rather than
trying to guess what it will use.

Change-Id: I422839ae4c684ff2de3a0a96dd54c6b74ce6df97

commit_message:
glance-api fails fast if default store unsupported

Fixes bug 852850

Ensure the glance API server will not start if the class supporting
the configured default store cannot be imported.

Change-Id: I80a97dbc0af4737dbbc1bf0491e7cef222ec3454

Reviews are certainly welcome, but I'm going to -1 this while I wait for smokestack results."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-10 00:54:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Johannes,

We got some 'ImageTooLarge: Image is larger than instance type allows' exceptions in the XenServer runs.

The image we are using is a Debian Squeeze image which is about 260 Megs. Torpedo defaults to Flavor ID 2."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-10 01:19:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-10 01:26:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

I think all of these inline comments apply to patch set 2 as well.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-10 15:53:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

Thanks for the feedback Vish.

Also, I didn't make any changes to how data was exposed via the API. Right now, after this change, we still only return root_gb as part of the flavor API. I'm guessing ephemeral_gb should be returned as part of the API, but I'm unsure how we plan on making this change to the API at this stage?"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-10 16:16:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Johannes,

Can you bump your migration to 068. You have a conflict with 067_add_pool_and_interface_to_floating_ip.py.

Once you get that I'll have a look at the ImageTooLarge exceptions."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-10 16:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

Hi Johannes,

I left an inline comment on the change_flavor_local_gb migration.

I'm not the biggest fan of using the connection_type flag inside of the migrations. I feel like most people may or may not have nova.conf setup on their database machines where they run migrations and this could cause some real head scratching later on because the behaviour is different for XenServer and Libvirt.

I'd prefer to use another mechanism to implement this part of the change... If we must use the flag I really feel like we should make connection_type have a default that is not set. That way we could check for that in the migrations and fail fast (prompting the user to set the correct value there)."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-10 16:41:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The problem is the behavior *is already* different for libvirt and XenAPI. The entire point of this change is to fix that, making the behavior similar between the two.

Current users of libvirt have come to expect the behavior that it currently implements and users of XenAPI have come to expect the behavior that it currently implements.

If we have one default migration, we will break the expectations of one set of users. So I'm trying the next best thing, varying it based on what the user is running.

That is possibly fragile as well for the reasons you ran into. An alternative is to break it for everyone to force everyone to understand what is happening."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-10 17:58:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

inline'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-10 18:36:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

One the presence of connection_type in the migration:  It seems reasonable to default connection_type to null to prevent unexpected behavior, as Dan mentioned.  In general I think it is desirable to migrate in such a way that leaves the existing flavors behaving in a manner identical to how they behaved prior to migration.  So this may not be a clean solution, but for existing deployments, it seems like it will cause the least headache.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-01-10 18:39:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This might be a silly question, but does nova support a multi-hypervisor-type environment (Such as having 2 compute nodes, with one being libvirt and the other being Xen)? If so is this effectively saying this is no longer possible or will not be possible in the future?

I say it's silly because I can see the use of it, I just have never heard of someone attempting it."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-10 18:58:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I can't think of a reason why a heterogeneous environment of hypervisors wouldn't work in nova, but they would behave differently for the reasons this change is trying to fix.

So I'm doubtful anyone is using an environment like that right now."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-10 23:56:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-11 00:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
KVM and XEN Disk Management Parity

Implements blueprint disk-configuration-parity

This change splits local_gb into root_gb and ephemeral_gb. libvirt
interpreted local_gb as what ephemeral_gb is now, whereas XenAPI
interpreted local_gb as what root_gb is now.

Change-Id: I496600991bac1e990326d4ded1607fee08209d68

subject: adds REST api for allocating all interfaces of an instance
messages:
[{'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-01-19 16:29:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Looks good except for the vif_id_on_device, that implies there are different "vif_id"s to worry about. There should only be one.'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:38:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I agree with aaron.

What are the differences among Interface.id Interface.virtual_interface_id and Interface.vif_id_on_device? Why not just use Interface.id for everything? If Melange is authoritative for virtual interfaces, its Interface.id can be used for everything and it doesn't need to track additional associated id fields."}, {'account_id': 845, 'date': '2012-01-20 04:48:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The new instances api doesn't expect nova to give it the virtual_interface_id
This vif_id_on_device is only retained for backward compatibility with the current nova code.We will remove this once nova starts using this new instance api.
Since there is a small chance the nova changes may not make it in for the current milestone, we thought we should retain the old apis with the old vif_id behaviour

We can remove the vif_id_on_device code from melange in this merge prop itself, if you feel the risk of milestone mismatch between nova and melange is not that great"}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-23 16:23:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-01-23 17:12:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

OK, but if this is still around in 6 months I get to taunt everyone with "I told you so" :)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-23 17:13:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Fails

Build Failed

subject: Adds keystone auth-n/auth-z for Swift S3 API.
messages:
[{'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-01-17 15:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

BP needs approval and, if approved, this needs to make essex-3'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2012-01-20 06:55:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Akira - this looks good.

My main concern is that /ec2tokens actually broke the core contract and is something we need to clean up. This follows the same model. What I'd prefer to see is code that handles /v2.0/tokens calls when the body contains the S3 token (should be the same for EC2 as well).

Is that a change you could get done by Tuesday - that's when we start to finalize E3?
- copying this to the blueprint too"}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2012-01-20 10:17:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

See https://review.openstack.org/#change,3220. That should give you a good basis to implement according to the intent of the core contract (which is to use extension objects on /tokens instead of additional resources)."}, {'account_id': 659, 'date': '2012-01-21 02:03:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 659, 'date': '2012-01-21 02:16:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-01-22 04:48:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Adds keystone auth-n/auth-z for Swift S3 API.

This capability has three parts:

a) a keystone patch to handle OS-KSS3-s3Credentials
   when received in a POST to /tokens.
b) a new keystone middleware s3_token.py for swift.
c) a swift patch to use token and endpoints from keystone via b).

This patch contains a) and b).

Note: modified by zns to get it in by E3.

See:
blueprint s3token
bug #874280

Change-Id: I9021de064177db358ea6d727c570f4e3bcd6e56c

commit_message:
Implement cfg.py

- Updates configuration handling to use module
  other projects use.
- Fixed the command-line to accept options that
  override config file settings.

bp keystone-configuration

Change-Id: I63958b1cc2918f5984c65164f6b3e5116efd0ea6

self.vmap.set(vlan_id, network_id)

Shouldn't need to be changed for set_vlan too or I'm missing something ?"}, {'account_id': 2315, 'date': '2012-01-24 09:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

ummm understood.

Yea my bad, the set method was in the plugin itself that you already fixed.'}, {'account_id': 2315, 'date': '2012-01-24 09:40:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Why not keep the same method name (just set) ? Need to see if nothing else calls that method set if you plan to change that method in the Class.

For example, in the tests, it uses set and not set_vlan... 

And in the test, the assert need to be inside the for loop no ? It's only asserting the last vlan.

Just rename the method back to set and it'll be good (i guess)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-24 09:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

[{'account_id': 1427, 'date': '2011-09-14 08:50:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1427, 'date': '2011-09-14 08:56:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

the "glance index" provides a "more style" of pagination
1. the number of image indexes is "adapted" to the size of the console,
while users still can customize the number of output per page through
the parameter --limit. If the --limit is greater than console's rows the latter while be used.
2. users "need not" to press the "enter key" to confirm YES or NO, if getch() style is adopted.
3. seamless output, you will never see the prompt message by scrolling the console'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-09-14 15:06:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Is Bueno.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-09-14 16:27:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(9 inline comments)

I have a number of comments relating to portability, because I believe we intend for the glance client to be usable on non-UNIX systems.  I also have a couple of style comments that aren't blockers, but it would be easy to address them..."}, {'account_id': 1427, 'date': '2011-09-22 09:20:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1427, 'date': '2011-09-22 09:22:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-09-22 15:55:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (4 inline comments)

Much better overall.  I still have some stylistic comments, but most are fairly minor.

Have you run the test suite on this, yet?  I know there are some tests on the output of bin/glance that could potentially be affected by this, and I would also like to make sure you've run the code through the pep8 tool (which the test suite does if all the other tests pass)."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-10-24 21:13:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
adaptive pagination

1. solved portability issues
   a. add getch() for WIN32
   b. add code for getTerminalSize() for WIN32
   c. since WIN32 don't support '\1b[A'; for erasing
      raw_input's prompt, I use getch() to workaround
      the problem.
2. fix coding styles and logic
3. add name in Author

Change-Id: Ieadc1eb916997cd2046f14625f01d08abf69076e

Hm.. i don't really like the 'tries' thing in declare_consumer().  I feel like this would be a more simple and better fix:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/3758/

The above patch makes it so that creating the consumer instance doesn't automatically declare the queue.  Later when we go to consume (in Connection.iterconsume), while we are in a try/except block to catch connection errors, the queue will get declared if it's not been declared yet.

What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-12 17:25:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(Oops...  remove the 'channel' argument from ConsumerBase.declare() in the above patch)"}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2011-12-13 14:28:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi Chris
your solution is more elegant I started to do some tests and it seems to work properly. Now I need to re-design the fix and unit test then I'll submit the change. I really hope than I can implement it by the end of this week otherwise I need to wait the new year"}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2011-12-15 14:17:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi there is a problem with this implementation. I run unit test but the unit tests hang, when we do a rpc.call the message is published but the queue is not binding yet to an exchange and the message is never received. I think the problem is due to the fact we split the queue declaration and the queue binding. In order to pass the tests I added a time.sleep(0.1) in the Publisher.send method just before the self.producer.publish(msg) call.
I think that the separation between the declaration and the actual binding can generate this problem also in a real env, maybe it's unlikely but we need to consider to this option.
Do You think we can leave this change and insert the time.sleep in the code if the memory_transport is TRUE?

please have a look at the link below reporting debug information while running unit test in 3 different scenario:
1 new version (with the separation between queue declaration and binding) and time.sleep enabled
2 new version (with the separation between queue declaration and binding) and time.sleep disabled: note in this version the queue bindings happens at the same time of the publishing process (lines 50 - 51) 
3 old version

paste.openstack.org/show/3828/

Please let me know what you think.
Cheers"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-20 02:29:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Interesting.  I'll try this out when I can find a little time.."}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2012-01-10 10:02:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi any news about this stuff?
Cheers 
Andrea'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-10 18:59:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Yeah, I found the reason, although now I can't remember what it was. :)  I had to make some further fixes to this to better deal with network issues and so forth as well that I was seeing in my environment.  So, I've ended up with a patch that is closer to what you did, but expands on it further.

Do you mine if I propose mine and you can take a look at if it's acceptable to you?"}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2012-01-11 14:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

ok no problem. I am happy to have a look at your solution.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-11 20:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Try this one out:  https://review.openstack.org/#change,2973'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Exception handler for kombu connnection

The declare_consumer method of the impl_kombu.Connection class now
has an exception handler for catching  exceptions that can occur
during the creation of the consumer in the Transport layer.
Fixes bug #888621

Change-Id: I39c9566aec079dc1285d31901aa323f99af4bf1f

subject: Improve the vlan/bridge startup
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 706, 'name': 'Brian Lamar', 'email': 'brian.lamar@rackspace.com', 'username': 'blamar'}, {'_account_id': 979, 'name': 'Dave Walker', 'email': 'email@daviey.com', 'username': 'davewalker'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1528, 'name': 'Stanislaw Pitucha', 'email': 'viraptor@gmail.com', 'username': 'stanislaw-pitucha'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 979, 'date': '2011-10-07 12:39:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Code looks clean, not tested it.

Looks good to me, but I am interested how the bug was encountered.  Did restarting the service remove and not re-create the rules?  How did the rules get lost?

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2011-10-07 13:00:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, simply restarting the compute service in a host with vlan networking model will try to try to reload the iptables rules, but will not apply them afterwards. This causes the -o brXXXX -i brXXXX -j ACCEPT rules to go away completely. The vlan presence check matters when the compute was restarted just as some instance was supposed to get its network. It also allows to recreate the vlan if it's been taken down manually (this happened when debugging the first problem) - it shouldn't happen during normal usage, but better safe than sorry.

The iptables bug will most likely hit everyone trying to upgrade a running cluster to a new version if they're using vlans."}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-10-07 21:20:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Thanks for the tests! Comments inline, and feel free to message me on IRC as I'm not as well-versed in the networking code as I am some other areas."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2011-10-07 23:07:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So it's not necessarily a bad thing to call the network manager straight from compute. There is code that exists in the network manager which actually runs on the compute host, such as create_network(). This is kindof stupid. In this case it's just rolling through the network manager to get to the linux_net driver. This functionality really needs to be refactored somehow.

I also dislike the fact that this adds networking related tests now in the compute manager unittests. Definitely not unittests at all. Compute should operate similarly regardless of the network topology. Having a specific network topology compute test is kindof gross.."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-10-12 16:38:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

See comments inline."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-10-13 00:50:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Affirming blamar's comment and providing more info inline."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2011-11-11 18:17:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-01-11 22:22:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

so old, with no updates. -2 to get rid of it'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-10-03 19:30:09.000000000', 'message': 'Improve the vlan/bridge startup

In case the nova-compute daemon restarts without a complete reboot
make sure it brings up the right iptables rules and bridges.
Previously forward rules on bridges could be missing.
Fixes bug 865629.

Change-Id: Iddfca3f0f8e5c027b63f4f5e3c36dea0078b3218
'}]
commit_message:
Improve the vlan/bridge startup

In case the nova-compute daemon restarts without a complete reboot
make sure it brings up the right iptables rules and bridges.
Previously forward rules on bridges could be missing.
Fixes bug 865629.

Change-Id: Iddfca3f0f8e5c027b63f4f5e3c36dea0078b3218

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 357, 'name': 'Devin Carlen', 'email': 'devin@openstack.org', 'username': 'devcamcar'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. messages:
[{'account_id': 191, 'date': '2011-12-16 16:51:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I haven't found this to be particularly confusing, but as the flag is only used in the process of creating the network and there is an easy way to pass arguments to this process to accomplish the same thing, I agree with removing the flag.

There will some required changes to the configurations that people use so the docs will need to be updated. For example, the flag is gone so multihost users will be required to pass the "multi_host" flag to each network being created instead.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-16 18:29:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-19 02:37:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm mixed on this.  I agree that it's a bit confusing, but I think a different way to address it would be to fix the documentation of that argument in nova-manage to indicate what the default value means.

I mainly mention this because this will cause confusion when it's rolled out by people who already have automated their installations.

I suppose in a nutshell, this seems like an unnecessary breaking change when we could really just address it with better documentation within nova-manage."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-19 11:06:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Even if you enhance the documentation, I still think it's not the right place to set a flag to be the default value of a command line switch option."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-04 20:51:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'll let you guys fight it out, but it seems ok to me."}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-01-09 14:29:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I disagree with the removal. It would be surprising if this option disappeared in the next version exactly because we set it in the config (additional unknown option will not cause error/warning) not on the command line.
Maybe it was a bad decision originally, but I think that reverting it is worse than just adding proper description in the docs."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-01-11 20:22:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We've been pulling flags out in favor or using arguments nova-manage commands, I don't see why we should stop now. The longer the flag sticks around the more difficult it will be to remove it later.

Worst case, in my mind, is we deprecate using the flag for a milestone and then yank it out."}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-01-11 20:31:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I would be happy with a deprecation strategy.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 20:50:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'll agree that a deprecation strategy makes sense—i.e., leave the flag in, but disconnect it and document that it's deprecated in the flag help.  (Is there any way to get a DeprecationWarning or something issued when the flag is used?)"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-15 17:05:48.000000000', 'message': "Remove FLAGS.multi_host

I propose to remove FLAGS.multi_host because this is really confusing.

People set this to True in the configuration file thinking that it will
enables multi-host in nova, but nobody thinks that it's actually the default
value for nova-manage when adding a network. I felt into this trap when
starting, and I'm not the only one. So I think it's better to only mention
this in one place, i.e. in nova-manage, so anybody can find at what time it
should be set: at creation time (and not at run-time).

Change-Id: Icd014230e7e41055925688ec3101966516968f89
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Remove FLAGS.multi_host

I propose to remove FLAGS.multi_host because this is really confusing.

People set this to True in the configuration file thinking that it will
enables multi-host in nova, but nobody thinks that it's actually the default
value for nova-manage when adding a network. I felt into this trap when
starting, and I'm not the only one. So I think it's better to only mention
this in one place, i.e. in nova-manage, so anybody can find at what time it
should be set: at creation time (and not at run-time).

Change-Id: Icd014230e7e41055925688ec3101966516968f89
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>

subject: Move console.log to a ringbuffer
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 34, 'name': 'Todd Willey', 'email': 'todd@ansolabs.com', 'username': 'xtoddx'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 236, 'name': 'Monsyne Dragon', 'email': 'mdragon@rackspace.com', 'username': 'mdragon'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 979, 'name': 'Dave Walker', 'email': 'email@daviey.com', 'username': 'davewalker'}, {'_account_id': 1082, 'name': 'Scott Moser', 'email': 'smoser@ubuntu.com', 'username': 'smoser'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1620, 'name': 'Robie Basak', 'email': 'robie.basak@canonical.com', 'username': 'racb'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-09-28 14:56:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Couple quick observations/questions:

1) This will absolutely work.

2) There are simpler (yet seemingly more inefficient?) ways of creating a circular buffer/file in Python, do we need to be this complex for efficiency? I'm fine if the answer is yes. One of the one's I've used in the past is given as an example here (the one using collections.deque).

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6293868/a-text-file-circular-buffer-in-python
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4151320/efficient-circular-buffer

3) There is a lot of code here without tests. I'd love to take your word on the accuracy of the code, but tests help me push the approve button."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-09-28 19:49:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Random question - what happens if nova-compute goes down? Does the pipe fill up eventually and the guest block?'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2011-09-29 13:35:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

when you raise ValueError, you should let the string go through gettext.
ie:
- raise ValueError('RingBuffer size out of range')
+ raise ValueError(_('RingBuffer size out of range'))"}, {'account_id': 1620, 'date': '2011-09-29 18:33:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1620, 'date': '2011-09-29 19:19:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Brian

1) Thanks! I appreciate your time in looking at this for me.

2) I don't think it's appropriate to use a deque for two reasons:

a) I'm trying to keep behaviour the same as before, so after a restart, get_console_output() still needs to return old console data. If I were to use an in-memory buffer only, this would not work. Thus I concluded that a disk-backed store was required.

b) A deque can only store discrete objects, rather than a buffer. One of the examples you linked to, for example, uses lines. As I'm solving this from a security perspective, if I did store lines the guest would still be able to DoS the host by using a really long line. To get around this I'd have to use a deque in a more clever way. Using it to store a byte per entry would force get_console_output to iterate over each of 64k entries, which is horrible. Or I'd have to do something really clever with chunking entries into the dequeue by reads, but this would be complex to manage and result in a confusingly variable buffer size. Either way, I'd have to wrap the implementation into a RingBuffer-style class.

I tried to find a sensible implementation of a ringbuffer, found none, so I wrote one which solved both of these issues. It's nicely encapsulated in a simple API anyway, so the underlying implementation can be changed without issues. I've now added some unit tests for the ringbuffer too.

3) I've added unit tests for the RingBuffer and ConsoleLogger which is the main code that I'm adding. As I'm not adding any new functionality, existing functional tests should suffice. The only sensible way that I can think of implementing a regression test would be to test an image that generates lots (eg. 128k) of console output, and check that get_console_output returns only the last 64k. I haven't found anything suitable in the existing test framework. Is there an existing mock that I could use? I'd appreciate some guidance whether this is required and how I might approach it.

@Mark

I'm now restarting the logger threads when nova-compute is restarted. I've tested (by hand) to see what the behaviour is when data is written to the console from inside the guest while nova-compute is down. Previously, everything worked fine. Now, a small amount of data is fine (presumably buffered within the FIFO). A large amount of data appears to hang the guest, and it doesn't resume when nova is restarted. This happens at around the 64k mark. I wonder if this the FIFO buffer size?

So it seems that a quick restart of nova-compute is fine, but if it's down for an extended period then there will be a problem. I'm not sure how this situation can be improved. It's certainly better than the existing DoS possibility.

If we want to do better, then I can see three options:

1) nova-compute spawns FIFO-reading/ringbuffer-writing processes that will outlive nova-compute (instead of threads). Perhaps it could leave a pid file in the instance directories to manage termination.

2) qemu is patched to support writing to a disk-based ringbuffer directly in some kind of agreed format. nova will need to be able to read this format, libvirt's XML schema will need to be extended so that nova can specify the request to qemu and libvirt will need to be patched to support this.

3) qemu is patched to do some kind of internal buffering. But it can't buffer an indefinite amount, so what should it do if the buffer is full?

Fundamentally the issue seems to be that writing to a ringbuffer from a FIFO requires a thread somewhere, unless it's embedded into qemu, and that nova currently have any other thread that lasts the lifetime of a guest.

Any other suggestions?

@Scott

I've now done this, thanks!"}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2011-09-29 19:19:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Always using ringbuffered logging makes sense in public cloud, but in private cloud you may not want to do that, and indeed may have regulations preventing you from destroying logged data.

This should be enabled via a flag.

It also seems that having the compute driver keep all those file handles may not be as good as having it spawn a process per-instance to handle logging."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2011-09-30 16:32:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In response to Todd, this is a serious issue in private or public cloud.  It is expected that the instance is somehow "constrained" so that it cannot negatively affect other instances.

In a private cloud, the owner of the cloud may be less likely to suffer malicious attack.  However, the possibility of accidental exploit and a loss of service is still present.  Additionally, even a "private cloud" may have external facing services that could be compromised, and then that instance attacked.'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2011-09-30 16:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

i should have stated, but I think that the flag to set this variable to a given size is sufficient.  Ie, the user owner of the cloud coudl set it to 100M, which would likely mean it would never hurt anything.

Clearly the potential loss of data should be minimized, though.'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2011-10-03 22:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hmm..... Could we simply use a separate logrotator process (like Cronolog with the FIFO patch, or somesuch) to manage this? This could live separately from the nova-compute, and avoid hanging the guest if compute is stopped.'}, {'account_id': 1620, 'date': '2011-10-05 17:17:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2011-10-07 00:28:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This must be optional, for regulatory compliance reasons.  Risking a resource exhaustion is okay, but losing logs isn't.

I see a couple of ways forward.  First is to just enable/disable this via a flag.  Second is to specify an external program to handle the pipe, in which case my program can just keep everything (or write it remotely, which solves both of our problems)."}, {'account_id': 1620, 'date': '2011-10-07 09:13:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Todd,

I'd be happy to implement this if there is general consensus. Unfortunately enabling/disabling the entire patch with a flag would be complex: I've had to modify the libvirt xml template file, so we'd need to have two templates or dynamically change it or something.

But I'm confused. Exactly which part of which regulation requires this behaviour?

AFAIK, no other system retains the console output (Amazon: last 64k [?]; non-virtualised machine: just what appears on the screen that nobody reads as it scrolls by). Doesn't this mean that they are all out of compliance?

Exactly how much space does this regulation require must be retained for logging? Can we not just set the (sparse) ringbuffer to this required size? Or does the regulation require a disk of infinite space?

And what exactly makes the console output a "log" under these regulations? What other system logs the console output of a virtual machine in this way? Can the guest not write to a remote syslog? How is compliance achieved when a system isn't running virtualised and thus console logging is not available?

Note that the existing implementation of get_console_output requires the entire console output to fit in memory, so right now we don't have an unlimited get_console_output size anyway. If you need this extra functionality, shouldn't that be going into a separate change request?'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-10-07 22:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

Hey Robie, sorry for the lapse in my review here.

I don't think that this console output is subject to the laws that Todd is suggesting. However, I also wouldn't be surprised. :)

This is a big case of something that I struggle with on a day to day basis: Should we implement the feature with code or should deployers be responsible for their setups? I would say that this is an uncommon enough situation that falls into the category of "do it in code" as there isn't a standard way (that I know of) for deployers to reproduce the functionality of your ring buffer. You mentioned before that there is a kernel module out there (emlog) but it's not standard/updated enough to make people depend on it IMO.

I included some inline suggestions, as making this patch optional is a good goal and shouldn't be too difficult to accomplish. You should just be able to add a flag, then add a couple of lines to the libvirt/connection.py. In my opinion the flag should be ON by default to be the most gentle to potential operations teams.

Thanks for adding tests for the buffer class!'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2011-10-10 21:51:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm concerned about FISMA compliance.

FISMA requires each project to analyze their own points of data collection to determine what is relevant and what isn't.  If something is relevant, then it has to be archived, duplicated, and protected.  At very high levels this can mean printing the most important types of logging messages to a line printer in a room with restricted access.

Specifically, since tools like cloud-init talk to the infrastructure layer it is good to have correlation between the client logs and server logs (nova-compute) to verify and track access and failures.  It may be possible to have FISMA compliant infrastructure without retaining console logs from instances, but if you want to have a compliant services layer that is built on top of nova (ie, provided inside of virtual machines), you'll probably want to keep those logs.  There probably are ways to use syslog-ng or kin to do it, but I favor an approach to keep everything by default, since disk is cheap and text is tiny.

I know this patch is important to prevent resource exhaustion, but it is possible to use a flag and template variable to accomplish this without removing the current behavior.  Alternatively, using a helper application to do this lets us both be happy by using different helpers, and has the nice side-effect of not breaking or dropping messages from console logging if nova-compute crashes or needs a restart (for example in the case of upgrades)."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-10-13 07:00:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> So it seems that a quick restart of nova-compute is fine, 
> but if it's down for an extended period then there will be 
> a problem. I'm not sure how this situation can be improved. 

I think this is a blocker, especially now that I understand our current recommendation for folks upgrading a zone ...

Basically, you take down all the nova-compute services during an upgrade. The theory is that, while you have a period where API operations is unavailable, the VMs themselves keep running ... and that's what really matters.

So, we are *designing* for nova compute being down for an extended period of time.

> It's certainly better than the existing DoS possibility.

Hmm, am I missing something here?

logrotate can rotate files just fine - even when program's can't be notified to re-open the file - just by truncating it in place. See its copytruncate option. Can we not do the same? Or even just recommend folks use logrotate?"}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2011-10-20 12:05:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Unless I have mistaken logrotate it operates by request, such as cron or triggering a rotate.  This means that logrotate would have to run at the minimum every 60s, as 
$ cat /dev/urandom > /dev/ttyS0, can run really rather quickly. :)

The other option is something like rotatelogs, where the log would be piped through an app... feels kinda dirty to me.

Personally, i'm a fan of this being self contained within nova - rather than using external tools.  I'd quite like to see this merged as is, as it /does work/..  The benefit of getting it in early, means people can find bugs. :)

If we keep discussing this until deep into the cycle, we risk merging late or worse, releasing Essex with this pretty serious DoS hole.

Note, Ubuntu is already carrying this patch - we haven't yet had negative feedback."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-10-25 12:53:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This branch fails to merge cleanly w/ Master.'}, {'account_id': 1620, 'date': '2011-10-25 12:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Apart from the clean merge with master, is there any other reason why this patch will not be accepted right now? If there are other reasons this cannot be merged now, I see little point in continuously rebasing it until other issues are resolved.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-11-03 04:24:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm with Mark on this one.  I don't think we can merge this as is if it hangs the guest when nova-compute is down for a significant period of time.  A separate process seems like a reasonable solution.  The fisma concerns aren't a huge blocker for me.  I think there are other ways around it, and we can add a flag later if it is really needed."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
Move console.log to a ringbuffer

Prevent a DoS by storing console output in a ringbuffer on the host,
instead of allowing it to grow indefinitely. Fixes bug 832507.

Change-Id: I6b4794419509e0f9b71c8be9f235d8d999baa884

commit_message:
Dont hard code the number of nbd's to create.

A user can load the nbd module with more that 16 devices. So if the
nbd module is loaded, then check to see how many nbd devices to
iniitalize.

Change-Id: Ieb13899f41776d673c706dc987c72e8ea682bb31
LP: #861504

subject: file-schedule host
messages:
[{'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-11-11 14:46:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(6 inline comments)

Hey, thanks for the submission:

1) I can't seem to find the blueprint, the link might be mangled or I might just be missing something, can you link me to the blueprint?

2) If you run pylint -rn <file> on this file you'll see a number of errors and warnings, can you check them out?

3) I think that this is a fine idea, but I'd also like to keep the ChanceScheduler as *simple* as possible. Could you potentially make your scheduler a subclass of ChanceScheduler? I think it would be much cleaner that way.

4) Can you please add unit tests for these new features so we know that they're all working and that they'll continue to work in the future? Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2011-11-11 17:40:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

+1 to what Brian said,

and it appears the correct blueprint is at 

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/chance-scheduler-specify-host-for-diagnostics

chance is misspelled "change" in the commit message

Also, why are we opening and reading the file every time? Do we expect it to change frequently? I'd prefer we read it once and cache it for later use.'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-14 10:20:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your comments, I will change my code so the file-schedule is a subclass of chance, I will add unit testing, and cache the content of the file: I will add a flag to configure the "cache timeout" (time to wait until we read the file again to override the cached values).'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-11-14 14:30:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(5 inline comments)

needs unit tests

What happens when the host for the user fills up?"}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-14 18:13:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (11 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-14 18:51:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-14 18:56:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

new version submitted.

The most important changes are:
1- I moved the code to a new file (nova/scheduler/hostfile.py) 
2- I created unit test for it.

The most important change in the code is that I added a caching mechanism with a "timeout" defined in a new flag.'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-14 19:10:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Shandy,
to answer your question (What happens when the host for the user fills up?):

The idea is to define a host for a particular user just for diagnostics. For example, if we are studying a bug with a particular compute node (or a bug that can only be reproduced in big environments with 100s of computes), we might need to specify a particular host for a particular user for debugging, although it is not the normal behaviour of the scheduler.

For that particular use case, we don't need to worry about filling the compute node.

Anyway, I agree it is a good point to consider for the future if this type of scheduler needs to be used in production environments for actual customers."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-11-14 19:40:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(17 inline comments)

The test shouldn't need to write to the disk, instead the implementation should make better use of stubs that the tests can override.

Look at nova/tests/scheduler/test_scheduler_options.py for an example (and nova/scheduler/scheduler_options.py)"}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-15 15:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (17 inline comments)

thanks for your comments!
Doing the changes.. I will push a new version soon'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-15 15:51:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-11-18 10:53:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

It seems more appropriate to put this information in the database. Why do you keep it in a file?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
file-schedule host

implements blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/chance-scheduler-specify-host-for-diagnostics
the hostfile scheduler reads a file and tries to
select the host defined in its first line
for the user whose id is the file name.
If the file does not exist, the random
algorithm is applied.

Change-Id: Ie119e6f0cbb4130b0ae7fd2098f7e9e886b01dea

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-11-29 22:56:08.000000000', 'message': "Enhanced identification of HOST_IP and eth device

Enhance the algorithm to automatically identify the HOST_IP
and NIC to be used for networking, simplifying things so that,
for most uses, defaults will `just work'.

First use the first NIC that has a valid IP address.  If there
is no such device then use the IP from the `my_ip' field of the
`nova.conf' file.  If that fails then inform the user that the
script can't find a NIC and bail.

Change-Id: I8798395fb73b379508ba74ede83908de766572b0
Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Enhanced identification of HOST_IP and eth device

Enhance the algorithm to automatically identify the HOST_IP
and NIC to be used for networking, simplifying things so that,
for most uses, defaults will `just work'.

First use the first NIC that has a valid IP address.  If there
is no such device then use the IP from the `my_ip' field of the
`nova.conf' file.  If that fails then inform the user that the
script can't find a NIC and bail.

Change-Id: I8798395fb73b379508ba74ede83908de766572b0
Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>

[{'created': '2011-09-23 19:10:17.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes LP Bug #824794

"Tables are generated outside of migration process"

This commit adds a functional test case that actually
uses the glance-manage db_sync, db_version, upgrade,
and downgrade commands. Without the fixes in the
glance.registry.db.migration module included in this
patch, this test case will fail with the infamous
"IMAGES table already exists" OperationalError which
appears if a user tries to run db_sync on a new
Glance installation, or an upgrade script tries to
run db_sync on a Glance installation that has not been
put under version control.

The changes in migration module catch this common
exception (existing images table) and uses some
sqlalchemy migrate magic to manually determine the
latest migrate version in the repo and manually set
the migrate_version in the database.

Also, moved a test case that was in test_misc into
test_bin_glance...

commit_message:
Fixes LP Bug #824794

"Tables are generated outside of migration process"

This commit adds a functional test case that actually
uses the glance-manage db_sync, db_version, upgrade,
and downgrade commands. Without the fixes in the
glance.registry.db.migration module included in this
patch, this test case will fail with the infamous
"IMAGES table already exists" OperationalError which
appears if a user tries to run db_sync on a new
Glance installation, or an upgrade script tries to
run db_sync on a Glance installation that has not been
put under version control.

The changes in migration module catch this common
exception (existing images table) and uses some
sqlalchemy migrate magic to manually determine the
latest migrate version in the repo and manually set
the migrate_version in the database.

Also, moved a test case that was in test_misc into
test_bin_glance...

Change-Id: I60cbd17c2adb5147c7180b586478d0642783f768

commit_message:
Adds support for PCI-passthrough.
Implements blueprint pci-passthrough.

- PCI passthrough parameters for instance provided in extra_specs of instance types
- Passthrough device inventory feeded by configuration flags or discovery mechanisms
- Instance metadata holds information about PCI passthrough devices on particular host
- Fixed issue with deleting/purging instance types (corresponding extra_specs were not cleared)
- Added capability to specify extra_specs during instance type creation

Change-Id: Ia540178e7ec6dd95fd7345cfff04b70243d7bb75

commit_message:
Allow shorter periods for instance audit

Changed the instance usage audit script to support periods counted
in hours. Also added the audit script to the collection of installed
files.
Fixes bug 868527.

Change-Id: I509dc8530d6e333ff50159cecfff162c95be2fba

commit_message:
Build metadata as needed through callbacks.

Fixes bug 851159.

Moves all metadata requests out of the cloud controller into the
MetadataRequestHandler class.

Uses callbacks to generate data as needed.  Requests just for structural
elements do not generate any database requests.  Requests for specific data
items to be loaded only load what is required, not the entire tree.

There is still room for improvement with caching, or having all of this data
pre-generated.

Change-Id: Icaa647705d6d4cbc3b784ac719c35eb54ebae9d2

messages:
[{'account_id': 979, 'date': '2011-10-07 12:21:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ooo, nice.

I agree that shipping a sample cert for the test case is an efficient approach, The cert is only valid until Jul 20 15:05:46 2012 GMT.  Am I right in saying that the cert isn't verified as part of the test, which would cause fail after Jul 20th?

It's not clear to me what SSL protocol versions this enables, does it expose: SSLv2, SSLv3, SSLv23 & TLSv1?  If so, SSLv2 at the very least should be able to disable (may raise PCI compliance issues).

Have you been able to compare this results in parity with another EC2 implementation?

Does it work with euca2ools?

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-10-07 13:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hmm, this code looks vaguely familiar! ;)

So, one of the things that Dan Prince suggested on the SSL support in Glance code review (https://review.openstack.org/#change,190) was to change the name of the configuration option from registry_client_use_ssl=True to registry_client_protocol=https. I liked the idea and think it would be good to do here for consistency.

Cheers!
-jay'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-10-07 19:27:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(11 inline comments)

Awesome, we needed support for this. I have a few comments inline, but overall I'd love to see some more error handling and tests for those cases:

Currently if you modify the test to have a missing cert (like FLAGS.privatekey = "privatekey.missing") then the tests just hangs.

I'm not sure that I agree with Jay on the flag specifying "https" versus a boolean flag, but I do think that "enable_api_ssl" is a little misleading because the WSGI server can be used to serve anything...not just APIs. My 2 cents.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-10-13 01:00:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

2nd all of blamar's comments.   I also added 1 inline comment about HACKING violation."}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2011-11-21 15:54:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am looking at the possible redesign of this implementation. Thanks for the comments.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
Add SSL support to API

Implemented the SSL support in NOVA and EC2 REST api service. The SSL
can be enabled or disabled through nova flag (enable_api_ssl).
Certificate and key are configurable via 'certificate' and
'privatekey' options.
Fixes bug 869884.

Change-Id: I44c0d8d78e4f285c32d91db80f1d714596fc86e3
