subject: This enhances nova-compute to use the flag --multiple_storage_path. This is a comma separated list of directories. When spawning an instance, the directory with the most free space is chosen to store the image files. The neccessary information are stored in a separate file "imagestore.pkl", a simple pickle structure file and cleaned when an instance is deleted.
messages:
[{'account_id': 167, 'date': '2011-11-02 14:57:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-11-03 03:30:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure I understand exactly why the pickle file is needed. It seems like you could select the path when the instance is created and then forget everything. When is the pickle file read from again?"}, {'account_id': 1057, 'date': '2011-11-03 14:36:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It is simple. After deleting an instance, the corresponding files must be removed and the instance directory should be deleted to. This is why I have replaced the corresponding calls with the additional function. I've thought about storing this information in the database but this would require additional communication over the queues and the way with the local store pickel file is sufficient."}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-11-03 15:06:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I guess my point here is that the data being stored in the pickle file is duplicate information which the libvirt domain already has. Why not ask libvirt for the domain information, extract the relevant locations for the domain and then cleanup based on that?'}, {'account_id': 1057, 'date': '2011-11-03 15:15:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
This enhances nova-compute to use the flag --multiple_storage_path. This is a comma separated list of directories.
When spawning an instance, the directory with the most free space is chosen to store the image files.
The neccessary information are stored in a separate file "imagestore.pkl", a simple pickle structure file and cleaned when an instance is deleted.

Change-Id: I96a24976f24e3465f68c0a20c12c51f29cf01fb2

I'd like to get soren's opinion on this becasue he wrote utils.synchronized."}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-11-10 13:36:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I keep wanting to suggest that you do this as a wrapper around synchronized, but I can see it'll end up a bit awkward..'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-11-10 14:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hey Vladimir, I'm not understanding how this helps fix the issue. The bug you reported says "instance creation followed by instance deletion (with relatively short interval)" which would seem to indicate that the compute manager can get two messages back to back like:

_run_instance(1234)
_delete_instance(1234)

and not that _run_instance or _delete_instance is being called in quick succession like:

_run_instance(1234)
_delete_instance(1234)
_delete_instance(1234)

..which is seemingly what this patch protects against (multiple concurrent calls with the same parameters).


Can you give me some more insight into the exact places you're seeing errors or are there no errors being reported? I'm not saying this change shouldn't go in, just trying to learn more about the issues as it's not something that I've seen before. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-11-10 15:53:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Various improvements on the script to make it work reliably with the
current nova code base, including:

- update calls to `nova-manage' to match the current syntax
- check that the user is running as root
- use `git' rather than `bzr'
- ability to re-use the `nova.conf' file
- ability to re-use the database
- install missing packages, including glance
- add usage help output when no parameters given
- remove errors on shutdown
- add a README file to describe it's operation

Change-Id: Id9be1fa823ec146357cea48327c0fca487b83e03
"}]
commit_message:
Update the script so it works with the current tree

Various improvements on the script to make it work reliably with the
current nova code base, including:

- update calls to `nova-manage' to match the current syntax
- check that the user is running as root
- use `git' rather than `bzr'
- ability to re-use the `nova.conf' file
- ability to re-use the database
- install missing packages, including glance
- add usage help output when no parameters given
- remove errors on shutdown
- add a README file to describe it's operation

Change-Id: Id9be1fa823ec146357cea48327c0fca487b83e03

Nachi: 

What code uses the data added by the annotation? Is it used by code that is coming in a future merge proposal?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-11-22 16:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-11-22 16:54:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Corrected import order...'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-11-22 19:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm...

Lorin: The attributes are used by nose when selecting tests to run.  There are options you can give to nose to make it select only tests with a given declared attribute, such as "small".'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2011-11-22 19:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Ah, thanks Kevin. 

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-11-23 07:24:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Something looks wrong here ...

Firstly, RebuildRequiresActiveInstance() seems like an inappropriate exception to raise here - this method gets called by run_instance(), and the error isn't due to the instance being inactive AFAICS

More importantly, though, I don't think this code can ever be reached. The code can be simplified to:

  if ((bdm['snapshot_id'] is not None) and
      (bdm['volume_id'] is None)):
      vol = volume_api.create(...)
      ...
      bdm['volume_id'] = vol['id']

  if ((bdm['snapshot_id'] is not None) and
      (bdm['volume_id'] is None)):
      ...
      raise ....

So, clearly the error condition can only be hit if volume_api.create() returns a volume without 'id' set. And the volume object is created by db.volume_create() which will always set 'id'

The test case stubs out volume_api.create() with:

  def stub_volume_api_create(*args, **kwargs):
      return {'id': None}

but AFAICS, returning a volume with 'id' set is part of the basic contract of the volume_api.create() method"}, {'account_id': 1850, 'date': '2011-11-23 18:43:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Mark

Thank you for your comment 

- For exception selection
I agree with you RebuildRequiresActiveInstance is not good selection of exception.
exception.BrokenBlockDeviceMapping() should be defined, then used here.

- For Code structure
I don't think the code simplified your way 
because second if condition is like this way.

            if not ((bdm['snapshot_id'] is None) or
                    (bdm['volume_id'] is not None)):

And also, I just updated exception class. So basically if there are problem other than exception class selection, it is another bug."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-11-23 19:27:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This:

  if not ((bdm['snapshot_id'] is None) or
          (bdm['volume_id'] is not None)):

is equivalent to this:

  if ((bdm['snapshot_id'] is not None) and
      (bdm['volume_id'] is None)):

See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Morgan%27s_laws

My main point here is that test_setup_block_device_mapping_database_vol_id_is_none() is testing for a condition that can never occur. The code it is exercising should just be deleted

The parts of the patch which fix some of the exceptions used in nova/compute/manager.py are fine though"}, {'account_id': 1850, 'date': '2011-11-23 22:20:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Ah, I got it.

test_setup_block_device_mapping_database_vol_id_is_none() should be deleted because it tests  unreachable path.

And also nova.compute.manager has unreachable path, so it should be deleted. I report this as another bug.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/894172'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-11-24 07:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Nati, fix posted here http://review.openstack.org/1894'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2011-11-29 19:33:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

FYI, this needs to be rebased. There is a little bit more work being done with ids -> uuids that may bring more conflicts to this soon.

Otherwise, good stuff (maybe soon we can move all those compute manager tests over to that new file!)'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-08 15:01:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm curious why the new test file is necessary? We already have a ComputeTestCase in test_compute.py that covers the manager specifically.

And yes, this does need to be rebased."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2011-12-09 21:51:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The actual tests look good, but I'm with Brian: why did we create a new file? +1'ing anyway, because I think we can get these through once we've addressed his concerns."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

subject: Adds trusted-computing-pools support. Implements blueprint trusted-computing-pools
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 849, 'name': 'fred yang', 'username': 'fred-yang'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1419, 'name': 'Mike Pittaro', 'email': 'mikeyp@LaHondaResearch.org', 'username': 'mikeyp-3'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 10:54:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(12 inline comments)

Ok, I've taken a first pass and included a fairly random set of comments

I'm no expert on the scheduler architecture, but what I don't understand is why you can't include the host's trust state in the compute capabilities and use the instance type's extra_specs to match against it. This way you'd be able to use the InstanceTypeFilter rather than adding a new JSON filter"}, {'account_id': 849, 'date': '2011-12-06 23:50:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

Mark,
As my replies embedded in the code comments. Let me explain the trust_lvl usage again.  
To verify a compute node's trustworthiness, we can't trust on node itself to post/report its own trust_lvl tate because the node will always report itself is trusted.  We can't put trust_lvl as part of $compute of service_state{} either because $compute is updated by nodes through RabbitQ.  
By above points, that is the reason we need to create $trust_lvl separated from $compute, and gt trust inform from standalone trusted Attestation server which will then verify the compute nodes' trustworthiness"}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2011-12-07 03:05:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(8 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-09 15:46:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I don't think this is the right approach to adding trusted computing pool support to nova. I would prefer to see you propose a plugin mechanism compatible with your use cases.

I sent an email about this to the mailing list, but I haven't heard anything back yet."}, {'account_id': 849, 'date': '2011-12-09 18:08:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Mark,
I have partial replied on https://review.openstack.org/#change,2122

To Enable TrustedComputingPools, two things must happen.  1st is to have scheduler.filter able to filter "$trust_state" from  servie_states{}.  2nd is to have a standalone attestation server (exposing Restful API for query nodes' trust state) to verify compute nodes.

The patch here is to enable 1st operation.  We are also working on the open source project to achieve 2nd, which is to come as SDK format.  We work with 3rd party ISVs to integrate into their cloud management tools, and also able be downloadable, from open source community, by cloud provider to host their own attestation server'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

[{'created': '2011-11-24 16:25:38.000000000', 'message': "Adds trusted-computing-pools support.
Implements blueprint trusted-computing-pools

Adding scheduler support to filter candidates base on compute nodes' integrity state from attestation server
- added trust_state caps into zone_manger and json_filer common code
- added manager_integrity to pull integrity report periodic if a node is rebooted
- json_filter_integrity for scheduler to filter trust_state
- compute nodes is default to be on either trusted or untrusted pools

Change-Id: I871702ad91fbe83ba5c76dab95b4dd163662797b
"}]
commit_message:
Adds trusted-computing-pools support.
Implements blueprint trusted-computing-pools

Adding scheduler support to filter candidates base on compute nodes' integrity state from attestation server
- added trust_state caps into zone_manger and json_filer common code
- added manager_integrity to pull integrity report periodic if a node is rebooted
- json_filter_integrity for scheduler to filter trust_state
- compute nodes is default to be on either trusted or untrusted pools

subject: XenAPI: destroy VM if the post-boot operations fail.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 271, 'name': 'Ewan Mellor', 'email': 'ewan.mellor@citrix.com', 'username': 'ewanmellor'}, {'_account_id': 335, 'name': 'Paul Voccio', 'email': 'paul@substation9.com', 'username': 'pvo'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 271, 'date': '2011-11-26 20:58:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Note that this changeset does genuinely depend upon xenapi-fake-refactor (https://review.openstack.org/1907).  Without the changes in that branch, this change would expose even more unit test failures.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-11-28 21:07:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Is Bueno!'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2011-11-28 21:15:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm a little concerned about this, but I might have missed something in the patch. Please let me know. If we return False from wait_for_boot, nothing above seems to handle or catch that return result. As such, it would go on to update the build progress, and as far as I can tell, go active. Is that the case?"}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-11-28 21:43:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Good catch Dietz!

In the except clause in addition to calling the destroy, should we not also raise a faliure to be caught on line 215 so the rest of the cleanup gets called. Then the spawn call above that would also need .wait() tagged on the end of it."}, {'account_id': 271, 'date': '2011-11-30 19:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 271, 'date': '2011-11-30 20:29:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The instance will have gone ACTIVE before any of the code in _wait_for_boot runs.  _spawn returns a timer Event, and puts _wait_for_boot on a background thread, so you'll exit out of _spawn, spawn, and _run_instance before the VM has booted.

Destroying the VM as I do in my patch will mean that compute.manager._sync_power_states will notice, and set the power_state to NOSTATE on the next poll.  Nothing will set the vm_state that I can see.  That will leave the VM in vm_state=ACTIVE, power_state=NOSTATE.

Is that acceptable?  I don't know.  These states aren't very well documented, so I can't tell what the intent of them is.

There isn't any code that I can see in nova.virt that updates the vm_state fields.  That seems to be left to nova.compute.manager.  If we wanted to make set vm_state=ERROR from nova.compute, then we'd have to make _run_instance wait for spawn's background thread to complete before returning.  Is that acceptable?  I can't tell that either.

Comments, anyone?"}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-11-30 21:33:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Dietz would know better than I so I'll defer to him. My feeling is that the spawn shouldn't return until the VM is either running or failed.

Since that's not how it works now. I'm +1 for this to just fix not having the instance hanging around, but I think we should look at refactoring and removing the loopingcall."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-01 06:09:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

I think we have cases where _wait_for_boot fails when it shouldn't... so we do have some cases where the instance is actually working and now this will destroy them.  But that's something we need to resolve separately."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-01 06:10:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Shoot... wrong button.  Should have had another nova core approval, but probably too late now. :-/'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-01 06:11:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Ah, I think this is going to fail pep8 anyway. Sorry for the spam. :)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-01 06:18:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/129/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/524/ : This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset. 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/1899/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-13 06:29:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

johannes has a larger fix coming that I think will address your issue along with some others.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-11-26 20:55:38.000000000', 'message': "XenAPI: destroy VM if the post-boot operations fail.

If the post-boot operations fail (i.e. file injection, admin password
setting, network setup, vCPU weight setting) then destroy the VM.

This may seem a bit aggressive, but the VM is likely to be unreachable
and/or unusable by the tenant, so it seems like the best thing to do.  The
alternative would be to show this failure as a task_state, but then you're
going to have to set appropriate billing policy if you don't want the
customer to be charged in this scenario.  I'm open to other suggestions.

Doing this has exposed the fact that our unit tests don't cover any of
this stage.  We were failing in various ways during unit testing, but none
of the tests noticed because there was no external indication of the failure.
Cleaning up the VM meant that I had to fix _test_spawn and _create_instance
to set injected_files and admin_pass before calling xenapi_conn.spawn.  These
two fields are set by compute.manager._run_instance before passing the
spawn request to the virt layer.

I also had to fix _set_vcpu_weight to cope with the absence of a
vcpu_weight value on the instance_type DB object.

Change-Id: I30cfc23c363939107fdce980a59a25395d858e10
"}]
commit_message:
XenAPI: destroy VM if the post-boot operations fail.

If the post-boot operations fail (i.e. file injection, admin password
setting, network setup, vCPU weight setting) then destroy the VM.

This may seem a bit aggressive, but the VM is likely to be unreachable
and/or unusable by the tenant, so it seems like the best thing to do.  The
alternative would be to show this failure as a task_state, but then you're
going to have to set appropriate billing policy if you don't want the
customer to be charged in this scenario.  I'm open to other suggestions.

Doing this has exposed the fact that our unit tests don't cover any of
this stage.  We were failing in various ways during unit testing, but none
of the tests noticed because there was no external indication of the failure.
Cleaning up the VM meant that I had to fix _test_spawn and _create_instance
to set injected_files and admin_pass before calling xenapi_conn.spawn.  These
two fields are set by compute.manager._run_instance before passing the
spawn request to the virt layer.

I also had to fix _set_vcpu_weight to cope with the absence of a
vcpu_weight value on the instance_type DB object.

Change-Id: I30cfc23c363939107fdce980a59a25395d858e10

subject: models: make IP addresses unique
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 34, 'name': 'Todd Willey', 'email': 'todd@ansolabs.com', 'username': 'xtoddx'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 1063, 'name': 'Ed Leafe', 'email': 'ed@leafe.com', 'username': 'ed-leafe'}, {'_account_id': 1528, 'name': 'Stanislaw Pitucha', 'email': 'viraptor@gmail.com', 'username': 'stanislaw-pitucha'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2011-10-26 12:09:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-10-26 12:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-10-26 14:23:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

For Vlan Manager it is possible to have overlaping address space on different vlans. So the constraint should be on (network_id, address)"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-10-26 14:51:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2011-10-26 14:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I think this change would have to go into a new db migration step, otherwise it will never make it into the datebase."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-10-26 15:21:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-03 20:06:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

You need to update your migration to 58. This code looks good after that."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-11-04 10:27:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:48:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The migration doesn't actually run due to a typo:

File "nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/058_unique_on_network_address.py", line 24, in upgrade
    table = sqlachemy.Table('fixed_ips', meta, autoload=True)
NameError: global name 'sqlachemy' is not defined'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:51:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Also, 'logging' isn't defined and 

File "nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/058_unique_on_network_address.py", line 27, in upgrade
    UniqueConstraint(table.network_id, table.address).create()
AttributeError: 'Table' object has no attribute 'network_id''}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:51:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:56:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-11-08 17:17:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm now getting the following error on Oneiric when running migration 58. From nova-manage.log:

AttributeError: 'UniqueConstraint' object has no attribute 'create'

http://paste.openstack.org/show/3177/"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-11-09 15:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2011-11-09 15:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Does floating_ips not need the column migrated to unique also?'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-11-09 16:16:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2011-11-09 16:21:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Just thought about a case where this is unique constraint cannot be enforced:
If you have a floating ip which you delete, the address will stay the same, but deleted will be 1. That would prevent you from adding the same address to the database, even though it should succeed.

Same thing is true for fixed ips. You cannot fix it by making (address, deleted) unique either, since you can do the: create, delete, create, delete, ... process many times. It seems like this protection just needs to be handled by a db transaction during creation instead."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-11-09 16:33:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

What's the rationale behind the deleted field?

Anyway, having twice the same IP in the database seems totally broken anyway. If you want to readd it, you should switch back to deleted to 0, not add a new row."}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2011-11-09 16:42:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

One reason (there are probably others): It's good for auditing. Reversing a delete is not the same as adding the same entry again. If you want to keep track of changes, there might be an important difference between "created in May, deleted in June, created again in December" and "created in May (delete reverted, but you don't know about it)".
It could be implemented in a better way (transaction log), but that's not what's available at the moment.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-11-09 16:45:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I agree that it's not the same and that we may need logging of such actions.

But you are proposing to keep a design issue as a feature, rather than fixing the bug and then adding the feature correctly. That does not sounds reasonable to me."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-13 16:07:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-13 17:07:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Do not submit

Unfortunately this does not work with our lazy delete strategy.  Records aren't actually deleted from the db by nova, they are just marked deleted=1 for cleanup later.  This means that we have to be careful with unique constraints because you can't re add something that has been deleted previously.

If we want to avoid duplicate ips, we should really put some logic in the nova-manage commands to make sure that no ips from the requested range  already exist."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-13 17:14:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Can't re-add by switching back deleted to False, simply?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-13 17:18:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Sure, that would be an alternate method, but it requires specialized logic.  Imagine creating and deleting a /25, then attempting to add a /24 that includes it.  You would have to "undelete" everything in the /24 by searching through deleted records, then add the other ones individually.

Also it is just functionally different from the way that the rest of the code base works, so it will be confusing. There was an addition a while ago of unique constraints on flavors, and it has generally caused a lot of headache, so I'd prefer that we don't repeat the pain.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
models: make IP addresses unique

It happened at least once that I got the same IP address twice in the
database. I think the add tools might not doint some checks properly.
Anyhow, it's better to set the right constraints in the model, and it seems
to me that there should be only one record by IP address.

Change-Id: I7176ac36823f2c586064786b39df786189f6c93d
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>

subject: aliases for standard openstack args
messages:
[{'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:46:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

How does tenants come into play?

In keystone the owner of a resource is the tenant - the user is the actor.

Kind of like accounts (tenant) vs users (user)'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2011-12-14 22:00:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not entirely sure. The v1 and v2 auth support in bin/swift make no reference to tenants, so I didn't add any options to the CLI args for it. Nothing that is there seemed to match.

I'd like some comments from Chmouel on this."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-12-15 16:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We can add the tenant support in there as there is support in the CLI  (for 2.0) :

https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/bin/swift#L212

It would detect the format the tenant:user format and pass the right information to the 2.0 service (eg: keystone).

The logic is: if we specify only a user then user == tenant but if we specify a tenant:user then it would use those values.

If you want, you can merge that pull req and I will add the tenant change after you? (not sure if there is a better workflow with gerrit for that).'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
aliases for standard openstack args

This is to implement a common implementation for all openstack cli tools as

commit_message:
Changed to auth by tenantName instead of by tenantId

Keystone now produces UUID's as tenant ID's, instead of auto-inc integers.
The implication is that it's easier to hardcode authentication by name than by ID.
The tenant ID could still be discovered by calling GET /tenants

Change-Id: I3fd359643752df751d04230510ff983bce9ff290

Generate billing events for the following Volume Actions:
- Create Volume
- Attach Voulme
- Snapshot Volume
- Detattch Volume
- Delete Volume

Event generation should follow the pattern used for VM events

The Billing process will recieve these events and generate a billing
record for each one.

A volume-usage-audit script (peer of the instance-usage-audit scrpit)
will generate periodic billing entries.

Change-Id: I3d9374980838fc2ecefa0a19641b7088bef29327
'}]
commit_message:
add volume billing events support in nova

Generate billing events for the following Volume Actions:
- Create Volume
- Attach Voulme
- Snapshot Volume
- Detattch Volume
- Delete Volume

Event generation should follow the pattern used for VM events

The Billing process will recieve these events and generate a billing
record for each one.

A volume-usage-audit script (peer of the instance-usage-audit scrpit)
will generate periodic billing entries.

Change-Id: I3d9374980838fc2ecefa0a19641b7088bef29327

commit_message:
add content-range headers to partial HTTP responses triggered by "Range:" requests as required by the HTTP protocol

The S3 layer should not filter out content-range response headers as they are part of the
protocol and expected on pa partial response.

Change-Id: I882f46a0640aabe8184f4312af7a2bc6f8d5ab7a

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1861, 'name': 'david-perez5', 'username': 'david-perez5'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-11-15 19:19:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Your doc strings don't quite match what we'd like to see, but otherwise this looks fine to me..."}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-16 10:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your comment.
I will fix the docstrings and push a new version.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-11-16 16:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Change the commit message to say "blueprint simple-allocation-scheduler" and gerrit will automatically link it correctly and set the topic

Does this really need to be done in as a periodic task? Sure nova-compute doesn't need to poll the value of vcpus, memory_mb and local_db? i.e. these values can only change when Nova knows about it, right?

LOG.warn isn't appropriate for every time you need to update the DB - LOG.debug would be better

There's a bit too much code in common with update_available_resource() for my liking - we should be able to refactor

allocate_instance_resources() and deallocate_instance_resources() are identical except for plus/minus - should be able to use a single method with a parameter for this'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-17 15:05:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Thanks for your feedback!

OK, I will fix the commit message to just include the blueprint name, and not the whole address.

The aim of the periodic task is to correct possible wrong values.
The values are added when an instance is created and substracted when it is terminated (in the future we should also modify the values during instance migration), but if there is any problem (for example, the VM crashes), the values will no longer be valid: that's why I check them in the periodic function.

I used the warning level in the periodic function because the scenario where the values change should not happen in an ideal world, and if the values are not corrected (i.e. they are what we would expect), I don't log anything. We want to be 100% sure that the values are correct if they are used by a scheduler that relies on them to make decisions.

The functions allocate/deallocate_instance_resources were created to make the code more readable in the places they are used (at the begining I just had the function compute_node_update_allocated): maybe I could refactor compute_node_update_allocated so it easily handles both operations."}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-17 17:08:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-11-17 17:26:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(7 inline comments)

I'd really prefer that you capitalize in your comments; something like:

    # This is a comment

See also the section on comments in http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/"}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-18 10:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (7 inline comments)

Thanks for your comments.
I fixed your observations, and also a couple of wrong docstrings.'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-18 10:42:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-11-18 16:19:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Looks pretty good to me.  If you can change that try/except to a try/finally, I think this'll be good to go."}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-21 10:37:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-11-21 10:43:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-11-21 16:58:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-11-23 18:34:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-11-30 21:46:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I happen to know that you will need to rebase and renumber your migration due to some other changes that went in today."}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-12-12 19:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1861, 'date': '2011-12-12 19:05:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

changed db change version, fixed conflicts and added the vms_allocated to track the number of VMs allocated in each compute node too.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-12 19:17:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-15 03:12:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Sorry to swoop in late here with this question, but I have to ask: why is it better to track allocated resources like this rather than ask the hypervisor (who *actually* handles resource tracking).'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-15 12:55:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Brian,

It depends what view of "resource utilisation" you want to use.   The existing hypervisor based methods show what is beign consumed at a point in time.   This hpervisor agnostic approach complements that by tracking what has been allocated / committed.   You can write / configure your scheduler to use either set (or maybe even a combination), depending on how much you want to risk over-commitement of the physical resources.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-15 15:37:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I'm on the fence about this... in a sense, this patch adds some critical "reservation-like" functionality to the scheduler. On the other hand, it adds yet another non-authority data source to the central zone database that may get out of sync with the authority (the hypervisor, as Brian points out). I see the sync periodic task in the patch and it looks like a decent check for skew between the database and the hypervisor... that said, the more we add to the central database, the greater the impact of an outage (database corruption, network partition preventing contact with the database, etc)

But, even with my concerns about the increase in non-authority data stored in the database, I don't see a better solution for the problem than this patch, at least without a substantial discussion about the existing use of the database for lots of stuff...

So, like I said, I'm on the fence :) would be awesome to see some performance numbers that show better performance for launches of largish blocks of VMs (which is where I think this patch will be a benefit in terms of performance)

-jay'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-15 16:07:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I dispute the term "non-authorative" data source - there are different data sets here, and they have different authorities.  The hypervisor is authoriative for "consumed" resources.   The scheduler is authoriative for what its initially allocated, and the compute node itself is authorative for what is still allocated (the scheduler isn't involved in the deletes so this can't rest just in the scheduler).   Neither of these different views are mandated to particular scheduler - it can use or ignore either or both depending on the policy its trying to implement. 

BTW you can of course build the same view by scanning all of ths instance table, but that's a pretty expensive opertaion for each schedule request.

We are working on a simple allocation based scheduler that uses this data - so perhaps the use case will become clearer when that's submitted, but as this is a building block we thought it worth submitting seperatly first.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-15 17:04:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Valid concerns and points, Phil. I'll stew a bit more on this today and maybe write up some more comments."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-15 17:23:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

BTW I think we may need to refactor this slightly so that the initial setting of the allocated values is done in the scheduler base class, to avoid the latency of the values only being updated once the message gets to the compute host."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-19 21:57:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I think you should look at this branch, as this is the approach we're taking as a step towards orchestration and scheduler changes.

https://review.openstack.org/#change,2460

Also I think we handle the various provisioning events in a slightly more extensible manner."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 11:52:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Sandy:  I've reviewed and posted some comments on #2460,  Hopefully we can combine the best of both into that stream."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
create and populate allocated resources DB

needed by the scheduler defined in the blueprint:
simple-allocation-scheduler

Created a script to update the compute_node table of the
DB with the allocated values (version 058).
The compute manager adds the VM reserved resources
to the allocated resources of the compute node record
during the creation of the VM, and substracts the values
during the VM termination.
Also, a periodic task which corrects wrong allocated values
has been implemented.

Change-Id: I8a0d820289acf69201d2dcbde0c13561ac2c3b41

subject: Remove FLAGS.minimum_root_size
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 357, 'name': 'Devin Carlen', 'email': 'devin@openstack.org', 'username': 'devcamcar'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}, {'_account_id': 1812, 'name': 'p-draigbrady', 'email': 'P@draigBrady.com', 'username': 'p-draigbrady'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-20 20:31:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2011-12-20 20:43:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So now size will not be passed to libvirt.utils.fetch_image() and so that will not do disk.extend(). Why is that no longer required?

Note this patch conflicts somewhat with:
https://review.openstack.org/#change,1993
so I'll adjust that accordingly"}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-20 23:01:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Please explain why this change is needed and make sure there is a corresponding bug on launchpad for this."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-21 09:06:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@p-draigbrady
I did not checked all call to fetch_image to check the size but I'll try to, but I'm afraid that the patch will be bigger then. :)

@Devin Carlen
The change is needed because the flag is not used by anyone else than libvirt (= bug) and is useless AFAICT."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 09:57:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Even weird special cases need a better justification to remove that just being weird :-)

I belive that this flag is used to define the maximum size of a root disk in KVM.  Changing it has an impact on the size of image snaphots that are created, and we've used in in our deployment for just that reason, so it can't just be removed from the system.

I'd agree that there may be better ways to control the size of snapshiots - but thats a much bigger change."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-21 10:01:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Phil
Wait, what? The maximum size of a root disk ? The flag is named *minimum_root_size*.

The flag is just used in one special case if you flavor name is m1.tiny, an has nothing to do with snapshots, so I am starting to doubt about your argumentation.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-21 10:04:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 10:22:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

@Julian:  It's not only used if the flavor is m1.tiny.   The check says if the flavour is m1.tiny then set it to None. 

In all other cases it gets passed through to libvirt.utils.fetch_image to set the minimum size of the root disk.  When a snapshot is created the imags is expanded to this size (I agree that this is a side effect rather than the main purpose of the flag)

If you don't have this mechanism then how can we define the minimum size of a root disk independtly of the stored image ?

Maybe you don't see this as useful, but I still don't see a justification for taking this option away from others."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-21 10:31:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Julian: It's not only used if the flavor is m1.tiny. The check says if the flavour is m1.tiny then set it to None. In all other cases it gets passed through to libvirt.utils.fetch_image to set the minimum size of the root disk. When a snapshot is created the imags is expanded to this size (I agree that this is a side effect rather than the main purpose of the flag) If you don't have this mechanism then how can we define the minimum size of a root disk independtly of the stored image ? Maybe you don't see this as useful, but I still don't see a justification for taking this option away from others.

@Phil: I see what you mean. But that does not make this flag right anyway. If you want this feature, then it has to be implemented properly in the API and then in ALL virt systems. Right now this just looks an ugly hack."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 11:15:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

Yep - agree its ugly.  Not convinced it should be raised to the API (i.e customer defined) though.

Ideally root disk size should be something that is defined as a combination of flavour and image, and I seem to remember some talk about this at Boston.

I'd be happy to see a more elegant solutuion, but that still doesn't make me want to throw this away in the short term.

If you wanted to make the flag accept a value of 0 to give the same behaviour as if the flag wasn't defined then I'd support that."}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:41:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not submit

Based on conversations here, it looks like this probably isn't the best way to approach this and that a more formal solution around dictating minimum root disk size is needed."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-28 19:08:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

we already have a plan for this:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/disk-configuration-parity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-05 02:17:56.000000000', 'message': 'Remove reference to distributed data store.

The compute admin guide incorrectly states that nova uses a distributed
datastore to maintain system state. I think at one point, nova used Redis,
but it currently uses a traditional database such as MySQL or PostgreSQL.

Fixes bug #912091

Change-Id: I45fd76674c9f09eccdafe50f6257ba270a785d2c
'}]
commit_message:
Remove reference to distributed data store.

The compute admin guide incorrectly states that nova uses a distributed
datastore to maintain system state. I think at one point, nova used Redis,
but it currently uses a traditional database such as MySQL or PostgreSQL.

Fixes bug #912091

Change-Id: I45fd76674c9f09eccdafe50f6257ba270a785d2c

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-11-15 18:47:59.000000000', 'message': "Adds openvz support to nova.

Implements blueprint bp/openvz-driver

This is my first attempt at wrapping up openvz that makes sense and gives
a greater level of control of OpenVz containers from Nova.  The driver is
known to work on debian based distros with flat networking using multiple
network interfaces.  There is some code for supporting redhat based distros
but will need to have some templates made.

In testing I haven't found any race conditions however we will be deploying
an earlier version of this driver in a beta service at some point so the
feedback from its heavier usage may lead to more improvements.

Migrating openvz driver from reddwarf to nova trunk

added block_device_info argument to destroy to meet driver contract

fixed find_by_name to apply name_filter, made destroy and reboot async and have them returning a utils.LoopingCall object

fixed issue where when using veth devices the name server doesn't get set properly

added set_admin_password method to set root password from api call and at time of spawn()

fixed boneheaded mistake

changed instance['admin_password'] to instance['admin_pass'] in spawn() to make sure the root password gets set on spawn

Added run_as_root=True to set_admin_password

Fixed test_get_cpuunits_usage_failure to fail

fixed test_gratuitous_arp_all_addresses

added a mock for _fill_templates in test_ovz_network_interfaces_add_success to bypass that method attempting to touch and modify files on the local system

added mox for _set_nameserver as this runs sudo command line commands that don't exist on the testing system

fixed broken mox for _set_nameserver to use the right ID from INTERFACEINFO

fix broken call to _send_garp in test_send_garp

change mox for arping call in test_send_garp

removed -s from arping system call

commit_message:
Adds openvz support to nova.

Implements blueprint bp/openvz-driver

This is my first attempt at wrapping up openvz that makes sense and gives
a greater level of control of OpenVz containers from Nova.  The driver is
known to work on debian based distros with flat networking using multiple
network interfaces.  There is some code for supporting redhat based distros
but will need to have some templates made.

In testing I haven't found any race conditions however we will be deploying
an earlier version of this driver in a beta service at some point so the
feedback from its heavier usage may lead to more improvements.

Migrating openvz driver from reddwarf to nova trunk

added block_device_info argument to destroy to meet driver contract

fixed find_by_name to apply name_filter, made destroy and reboot async and have them returning a utils.LoopingCall object

fixed issue where when using veth devices the name server doesn't get set properly

added set_admin_password method to set root password from api call and at time of spawn()

fixed boneheaded mistake

changed instance['admin_password'] to instance['admin_pass'] in spawn() to make sure the root password gets set on spawn

Added run_as_root=True to set_admin_password

Fixed test_get_cpuunits_usage_failure to fail

fixed test_gratuitous_arp_all_addresses

added a mock for _fill_templates in test_ovz_network_interfaces_add_success to bypass that method attempting to touch and modify files on the local system

added mox for _set_nameserver as this runs sudo command line commands that don't exist on the testing system

fixed broken mox for _set_nameserver to use the right ID from INTERFACEINFO

fix broken call to _send_garp in test_send_garp

change mox for arping call in test_send_garp

removed -s from arping system call

reverted changed to test_ovz_network_interfaces_add_success and added a mox stub for set_permissions to fix the real issue

add Daniel Salinas <imsplitbit@gmail.com> to the Authors file

pep8 fixes

pep8 fixes

pep8 and pylint fixes

adding test for get_connection

added test_init_host

added import for socket to fix tests that use socket methods

fixed test_init_host

adding test_init_host_not_found

fixed test_init_host_not_found

added error message to all utils.execute mocks to mimick the fact that vz commands, while successful, sometimes output messages to stderr

fixed test_list_instances_fail to exercise the except clause of the method

adding more unittest coverage

setting FLAGS.use_ipv6 to False for testing purposes right now as there is no ipv6 support in the ovz driver

added more unittests and fixed destroy() to return the timer object

adding more unittests

adding more unittests

adding more unittest coverage

fixed pep8 violation in test_ovz.py

fixed bug 890829

added unittests for pass and fail cases of spawn()

changed _cache_image() to raise an exception to facilitate catching the error
later and doing something more intelligent with this error as it can lead to
the container not creating properly

changed the copyright date to 2011, thanks soren

added more detail to the TODO in test_ovz.py to clarify the reordering TODO

added comment explaining the ovz_disk_space_oversub_percent flag for clarity

removed the ovz_use_dhcp flag as it isn't needed.  to support dhcp using
nova's dhcp facilities one only needs to create an appropriate template and
set FLAG.injected_network_template

changed all docstrings that were in the first person to be more abstract in
their perspective.  thanks soren

changed the _set_hostname method signature to use hostname=None instead of
hostname=False as hostname shouldn't ever be a bool. thanks soren

changed "if len(out) == 0" to "if not out" to be easier on the eyes and be
more pythonic.

refactored the repetitive utils.execute calls into a helper method execute()

pep8 fixes

fixed unittests after execute refactor

Change-Id: I297319b045a9983f027cffd6cc9712945d283d5e

commit_message:
Converts syspanel.images to use datatables, new modals, etc.

Also finishes some cleanup on nova.snapshots that got forgotten.

There was a ton of dead code that was removed from syspanel.images
which clearly hadn't been used/tested/accessible since the diablo
release or earlier.

Change-Id: Ic9a9284b23574b10f6c34c90026b054d6608dc7c

Sometime recently, the tenant ID instead of the tenant Name
was used in Compute URLs, and we were appending the tenant Name
to the management URL returned from Keystone improperly.

This patch grabs the tenant ID from the returned management URl
and appends the tenant ID instead of the tenant Name.

commit_message:
Fixes LP #920782 - Malformed request URL

Sometime recently, the tenant ID instead of the tenant Name
was used in Compute URLs, and we were appending the tenant Name
to the management URL returned from Keystone improperly.

This patch grabs the tenant ID from the returned management URl
and appends the tenant ID instead of the tenant Name.

Change-Id: I4d4d23b3722c5c67463592397c5b23c5f3281c30

Update the filter so that context is part of the filter_properties, bro.
Changed the instance_id -> affinity_instance_uuid so it's clear

commit_message:
Implement Secure Token Auth

- Added OS-KSVALIDATE extension that supports
  /tokens calls with the token supplied in the
  headers. Using X-Subject-Token instead of in the
  URL.
- Addresses bug 861854

Change-Id: Ib6798a98683111c8ce7dfd70a99603ddf1f85248

commit_message:
Brings back keystone middleware

 * Adds ec2 auth middleware
 * Adds keystonecontext middleware
 * Notes alternative configurations in paste config
 * Fixes nova portion of bug 917408

subject: horizon: instances: Gracefully error if can't talk to glance
messages:
[{'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-01-23 23:51:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

This code no loner exists, so this patch *can't* be submitted.

But aside from that, the right place to fix this issue is at it's source in horizon.api.nova.Server.image_name. That code should use the new exceptions.handle() method to provide consistent/broader error handling, the imports should be cleaned up, and the image data should be cached so that subsequent accesses to the property don't make additional API calls.

Unit tests to verify this behavior would also go a long way towards making it awesome."}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-24 00:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Thanks for the feedback, I'll withdraw this change and see about doing the proper fix (provided the behavior is still present). Thanks Gabriel!"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-09 16:21:08.000000000', 'message': "horizon: instances: Gracefully error if can't talk to glance

If glance keystone integration is misconfigured, the 'instances' panel
errors in an unfriendly way when processing the template (unlike the
images page).

Test glance communication ahead of time so we can handle the error
gracefully.

Change-Id: I8078ae0a2458b99ba17540403d4a26d9cfb01a4b
"}]
commit_message:
horizon: instances: Gracefully error if can't talk to glance

If glance keystone integration is misconfigured, the 'instances' panel
errors in an unfriendly way when processing the template (unlike the
images page).

Test glance communication ahead of time so we can handle the error
gracefully.

Change-Id: I8078ae0a2458b99ba17540403d4a26d9cfb01a4b

subject: shell: Default --version to 1.1 if not specified
messages:
[{'account_id': 741, 'date': '2012-01-23 23:58:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

python-novaclient is used to talk to both essex and diablo installs of nova, the 1.0 support should be kept.

Additionally, there is a second/duplicate review for the behaviour change .. https://review.openstack.org/3312"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-24 00:00:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Kiall:

He is simply removing an artifact of what once was support for 1.0. We have already dropped support for 1.0 in novaclient.

I do, however, agree this is a duplicate.'}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2012-01-24 00:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Aha - I had thought 1.0 was still supported in novaclient. My mistake!'}, {'account_id': 1783, 'date': '2012-01-24 00:57:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Ah didn't see that other patch, I'll drop this. Thanks guys!"}]

value any more.

Updates the nova-manage to use db.instance_get_all for instance
information instead of relying on Sqlalchemy model relationships
(which not longer exist due to network refactorings).

This commit fixes 'nova-manage fixed list' so that it correctly
displays hostname, and host. I dropped the MAC address column
which would have required an extra VIF's table lookup and
wasn't used as much.

Fixes LP Bug #920159.

Change-Id: I3cec690c5e40631e0f10b2a914f46863601a1734
"}, {'created': '2012-01-23 19:54:59.000000000', 'message': "Fixes nova-manage fixed list.

Updates the nova-manage to use db.instance_get_all for instance
information instead of relying on Sqlalchemy model relationships
(which no longer exist due to network refactorings).

This commit fixes 'nova-manage fixed list' so that it correctly
displays hostname, and host. I dropped the MAC address column
which would have required an extra VIF's table lookup and
wasn't used as much.

Fixes LP Bug #920159.

Change-Id: I3cec690c5e40631e0f10b2a914f46863601a1734

commit_message:
Fixes nova-manage fixed list.

Updates the nova-manage to use db.instance_get_all for instance
information instead of relying on Sqlalchemy model relationships
(which no longer exist due to network refactorings).

This commit fixes 'nova-manage fixed list' so that it correctly
displays hostname, and host. I dropped the MAC address column
which would have required an extra VIF's table lookup and
wasn't used as much.

Fixes LP Bug #920159.

Change-Id: I3cec690c5e40631e0f10b2a914f46863601a1734

commit_message:
Specify stable/diablo glance version.

Specify stable/diablo in both pip-requires and buildout.cfg.
This should allow unit tests to pass now that glance has
moved on to essex.

commit_message:
Remove deprecated extension code.

The recent extensions refactoring (blueprint extension-refactor)
deprecated ActionExtension and RequestExtension, replacing them with
ControllerExtension.  This patch completes the deprecation by
removing those classes and all related support infrastructure,
including ExtensionMiddleware and LazySerializationMiddleware.  (The
classes remain, as deprecated do-nothing stubs, for compatibility
with existing api-paste.ini files.)

Change-Id: I8272ac3cf432813d749db67b2e1ad1a72abbb784

commit_message:
Update pipelines

The change https://review.openstack.org/#change,3190 updates the
pipelines in api-paste.ini to remove deprecated middleware, but
devstack was still using the old pipelines and thus barfed.  This
updates the pipelines in devstack.

Change-Id: I3088d3cd6c9e1bbf5762e74cbc8eaf8d06c44405

commit_message:
Bug #909574: Glance does not sanity-check given image size on upload

Don't allow an image size greater than 1 PiB.  Also, add an exception
block catching and reraising HTTPError inside _upload.  This way, we don't
fall into the Exception block below and log the full backtrace when the
error has been diagnosed already.

Adds unit test to verify 400 returned with supplied overlimit image size

Change-Id: Ie745dffaf2fe43fdb7643c27d087e36d76b7c0e4

[{'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-19 15:08:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-19 20:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

You might want to check this branch out: https://review.openstack.org/#change,1630. I would hate for one of you to have your work discarded.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-19 22:42:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Was doing some thinking while merging in capacity calls into my branch.  Openstack has a need to also track volume stuff.  Not sure volume stuff warrants its own capacity table, but the capacity table in your branch is specifically for compute, so should we name the table 'compute_capacity', instead?"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-19 23:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

We need to deal with the case of user-extensible capacity ... would this fit under that category?'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-20 02:20:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yeah, there's that too, at some point. ;)

So, I'm not sure volume maps to the table in the same way that one might desire.  A volume service on a host can have multiple volumes.  The scheduler may want to make decisions based on the host as a whole, but it also certainly needs to make decisions based on each volume.  So, it feels like a volume solution might be a completely different model.

Also, I'd think you'd want to keep the tables as small as possible since scheduling decisions are going to be pulling a lot of rows.  Mixing volume and compute means unused columns in the table for each service type.

So, it feels like we'd want different tables.  Interested in your thoughts based on above.

Hm.  Just discovered a bug in trunk, also.  We need to check that the host is up and we're ignoring that right now in DistributedScheduler.  Do we want to be able to join Service with Capacity?  Or should we check that separately (via the service_states the scheduler tracks)?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-20 03:30:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oops, I think I'm thinking about volumes incorrectly.  Ie, I think you can ignore my 2nd paragraph above."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-20 07:13:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

inline comment... but I've not fully looked this over yet.  Will hit the rest of this tomorrow."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-20 14:39:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)
