'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 11:00:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi All,  Sorry for comming late into this one, but I was following a similar stream that we'd submitted:

https://review.openstack.org/#change,1630

I agree that somehow we need to rationalise them into one stream, and that there are a number of things in this one that are more elegeant, but I have a few concerns:

1) Since the values are initially updated in the scheduler (at least that's what I'm guessing from the comment in capacity_notier.py) then I don't think this patch is complete without that part of the scheduler base class.  I understand the drive to kep seperate a scheduler that uses this new info - but both parts of the increment / decerment need to be here for a meaningful review.

As this information has to acccurate and up to date for the schduler to reply on it I'm assuming the scheduler doesn't use the notification queue, but makes its update directly to the DB.   I'd like to see how this is made atomic from multiple scheduler instances.

2) Not clear to me where the capacity notifier would run, or how it would be protected against failure (not running at all would lead to cpacity apparenty never being released).   In #1630 we implemeted a check and correction mechanism in the periodic tasks of compute manager, and I think the same is needed here.  This kind of correction mechanism could offset some of the concerns around atmoic updates from mulitple schedulers. 

3) Why no tracking of free vcpus ?   Whilst probably the least useful of information for the scheduler it feels all of the data in the flavor shoudl be tracked for completeness

4) It would be really nice if there was a way to track all any flavour attribuite, even those defined in type_extra_specs.

If we can agree on how to address the above, then we could abandon #1630 in favour of this change."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-21 13:48:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

comments inline:

-----
> Hi All, Sorry for comming late into this one, but I was following a similar stream that we'd submitted: https://review.openstack.org/#change,1630

You should really be involved in the Orchestration discussions so we aren't treading on each others toes, there is a lot of overlap in what you're trying to achieve and the direction we're headed.

-----

> I agree that somehow we need to rationalise them into one stream, and that there are a number of things in this one that are more elegeant, but I have a few concerns: 

> 1) Since the values are initially updated in the scheduler (at least that's what I'm guessing from the comment in capacity_notier.py) then I don't think this patch is complete without that part of the scheduler base class. I understand the drive to kep seperate a scheduler that uses this new info - but both parts of the increment / decerment need to be here for a meaningful review. 

You can see the full branch here:
https://github.com/SandyWalsh/nova/commit/5a55e8301cccc610af41e4f632d28fec7609d543

As I mentioned, we have to do this due to other scheduler branch changes that are coming. Hopefully we can get this all resolved quickly.

------

> As this information has to acccurate and up to date for the schduler to reply on it I'm assuming the scheduler doesn't use the notification queue, but makes its update directly to the DB. I'd like to see how this is made atomic from multiple scheduler instances. 

Note the row level locking in the db updates. 

------

> 2) Not clear to me where the capacity notifier would run, or how it would be protected against failure (not running at all would lead to cpacity apparenty never being released). In #1630 we implemeted a check and correction mechanism in the periodic tasks of compute manager, and I think the same is needed here. This kind of correction mechanism could offset some of the concerns around atmoic updates from mulitple schedulers. 

It's reset every time the compute node starts up (like ComputeNode) and updated with every change. 

-------

> 3) Why no tracking of free vcpus ? Whilst probably the least useful of information for the scheduler it feels all of the data in the flavor shoudl be tracked for completeness 

We don't use it, but it could certainly be added. During the Orchestration discussions we agreed we needed a generic means of extending what goes in the Capacity table. We decided to get this branch landed first and then address that problem after. 

-------
4) It would be really nice if there was a way to track all any flavour attribuite, even those defined in type_extra_specs. If we can agree on how to address the above, then we could abandon #1630 in favour of this change.

The problem with Key/Value tables is they are terrible to query against and give back hard-to-use result sets. We're trying to think of a better way."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 14:24:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

>You should really be involved in the Orchestration discussions so we aren't treading on each others toes, there is a lot of overlap in what you're trying to achieve and the direction we're headed.

I did try initially, but a combination of other priorities and time zones made it difficult.   I also only recently realized that “orchestration” was now covering scheduler changes in general – from the sessions at Boston I’d had the impression that the scope was more about how make requests “retryable” once they were in the system, rather than making different resource allocation data available to the scheduler.    I believe the remit for the team was something like “orchestration, work flow management for requests, state machine for recovery”.  Its fine that scope changes over time, but a tad unfair to ping people for not noticing it ;-)

-----
>	You can see the full branch here: https://github.com/SandyWalsh/nova/commit/5a55e8301cccc610af41e4f632d28fec7609d543
> As I mentioned, we have to do this due to other scheduler branch changes that are coming. Hopefully we can get this all resolved quickly.

I didn’t doubt that there was work to add the code to the scheduler, but to me it still looks as if without also commiting as part of this patch the code to decrement the capacity values in the scheduler this patch set would just be doing one half of the job (i.e. the counters would always increment), and that doesn’t match my expectation around the completeness of changes going back into trunk.   
If this patch is about creating and maintain these new tables in the database, then from the point its committed it needs to make sure that data is always going to be reliable, and consistent whatever scheduler is configured into the system, hence I still think this patch set should include the changes in the base class to make sure that is the case.

------
>> 2) Not clear to me where the capacity notifier would run, or how it would be protected against failure (not running at all would lead to capacity apparently never being released). In #1630 we implemented a check and correction mechanism in the periodic tasks of compute manager, and I think the same is needed here. This kind of correction mechanism could offset some of the concerns around atomic updates from multiple schedulers. 
>It's reset every time the compute node starts up (like ComputeNode) and updated with every change. 

Maybe I’m missing something, but “updated with every change” seems to rely on the capacity_notifier picking up the events.  My point was more what will keep this data consistent / correct it if the capacity_notifier misses an event or doesn’t run for some reason ?"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-21 15:15:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The capacity notifier can't miss an event since it's done in the compute manager (via the ListNotifier chain). Not all notifications have to go on the queue."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-21 15:16:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

My point about the patch is that is has to land in stages due to other, external, conflicts. This patch by itself will not break or affect anything else. But it will be complete when the next couple of patches land.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-21 15:25:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

re: joining orchestration discussions, it was an invitation, not to chastise. 

Perhaps we can move this discussion to a better forum?
Gerrit is ass.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 19:49:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I've been discusing this with Sandy by e-mail, and as I'm about to go on hols I thought I'd post a quick summary:

Now I understand how the capacity_notifier is to be configured to make updates without notiifctaions havign to go through the message queue my thoughts are:

 1) Capacity_notifier should be extended so that it also handles "start" events generated by the scheduler.  In that way the same mechanism will be used and configured to update the capacity table on both the scheduler and compute hosts (currently it seems that the scheduler would make direct calls to the db.api)

2) Stil feels that an audit role in periodic tasks to check  / correct the consistency of the capacity table would be a useful addition'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-23 05:40:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Delayed in a few days in seeing the comments here.  Sorry if Sandy has clarified some of this even further.

Phil: I tend to agree with a periodic 'sync' so that we have 'built in recovery'.  The problem with it is going to be that we're going to need to lock around:
{
setting instance['host'] (and unsetting)
updating the Capacity table.
}

Otherwise we have a race condition between those 2 operations when doing a sync.  This is an issue with the current sync-at-startup as well that we're going to need to think about.  Just thought about this. :-/

The scheduler side is missing because I have a scheduler re-factor coming for further scaling sub-team work that's going to collide and we thought it would be better to split up this patch.  This makes the Capacity table un-usable until it's in the scheduler, but it's a configuration item to use the Capacity notifier or not.  Ie, unless you use the capacity notifier, the table is not used.

Also:  I think I agree that it makes sense for the scheduler to use the same notify framework so the DB updates are in one spot (the capacity notifier plugin)."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-23 15:47:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hmm, interesting problem with the notifier.

In an upcoming branch we have a sanity check that we can't overallocate during db.capacity_update(). It will raise an exception if we attempt to overallocate ... but there's a problem.

I started to move the notification code into scheduler, but it will conflict with the notification driver, where we can't raise an exception in the notification chain (because it'll prevent the rest in the chain from being processed)

Tricky."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-23 17:20:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

I don't think that should even be an exception - what if someone had a scheduler where they want to allow some degree of over-commit (quite posible given that some hypervisors are very good at memory page sharing, etc) ?   

The scheduler should be allowed to make these decisions, and the capacity-table should just reflect the current situation.

So my vote would be to lose that sanity check, as I think its wrongly anticipating only a certain type of scheduling.

Phil"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-23 18:16:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Some sort of sanity check has to occur while the Capacity row is locked, or you end up with a race condition.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-23 18:44:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Are you trying to protect against the case where the table has changed since the scheduler read it and made a placmetn decision ?

Seems to me that in that case the check should be that the value is unchanged or still below some maximum specified scheduler rather that compared to the physical limit.

Assuming the notification is sent before the message is sent to the selected host then I don't see the issue in the exception stopping the notification message, since it seems to fair to say that in this case the event itself won't go ahead.

Phil"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-23 18:57:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Are you trying to protect against the case where the table has changed
> since the scheduler read it and made a placmetn decision ?

Correct.  I suppose that checking if the row has changed is one way to solve your problem.  It's just that we need to need to make sure that "check and set" is an atomic operation (happens while the row is locked).'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-23 19:27:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I get that that there will always be some delay since the scheduler looked at all of the values and the point where it has selected a particular host and now wants to update the capacity table and send the meesage to the host, 

In our large systems we're still keeping a small degree of randomness in the scheduler selections (it selects one of the N most suitable hosts rather than the most suitable), so the risk of this kind of clash even with multiple schedulers is small enough that we can live with it, but I guess that might not suit everyone.

It kind of feels as if we should allow the scheduler to specify some upper bound on the current value for the request to go ahead - and if that's not met then you get an exception and the scheduler won't use that host (since the capacity notifier is called in-line it could re-evaluate the request and pick another host). 

In effect when doing this via the notifier the scheduler has to generate a conditional notification (sort of a contract between the scheduler and the capacity notifier to "send this notifictaion only if this condition is still true")  

Would that work for folks ?

I realise its getting to be a close call between the symetry of only updating the capacity table in the capacity_notifier and the now having conditional behaviour in the notifier.

Maybe we just say that schedulers that really want to implement this check do have to make direct db updates and not use the notifier, but that others can chose to use the notifier without the sanity check ?'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-23 19:44:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

We were chatting about this a few minutes ago and I think this is the approach we're going to take:

1. land this branch
2. following your lead with your branch, make the compute.manager act as the lock for the request ... in that vein the scheduler will ask the compute node to allocate for the request, which will either succeed or fail and send an event back to the scheduler informing it what to do.
3. if the request succeeds, run_instance continues, if not the scheduler picks a new host.

This will be done in a follow up branch, since this branch doesn't really affect this plan as is."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-24 10:37:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> 2. following your lead with your branch, make the compute.manager act as the lock for the request ... in that vein the scheduler will ask the compute node to allocate for the request, which will either succeed or fail and send an event back to the scheduler informing it what to do.

I like the idea of a compute host being able to re-submit a request to the scheduler if it finds that it can't host the instance, providing its decision for this needs to be against criteria specified by the scheduler (so passed along in the run instance message)

However just to be clear this should be a final sanity check; I still belive that the capacity table has to be first updated in the run context of the scheduler - if there is a delay in updating the table whilst the message gets to the compute host then the schdulers will be dealing with stale values and will make more requests that get bounced by the compute hosts. (We had this wrong in out last patch set, which is why I -1'd it) 

Maybe the scheduler could be changed to call the compute api to send a run_instance request instead of just calling rpc.cast - so that the code for maintaining the capacity table is fully enapsualted in compute (albeit a combination of api and manager)

(Happy holidays everyone)"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-24 21:26:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Phil:  The latter idea is what we're thinking about.   Ie, I think things are a bit more clean if we make these changes:

1) Scheduler does not set instance['host'] anymore.  Instead, it just makes a _call_ to compute's 'run_instance' (vs a cast).
2) Modify compute's 'run_instance' so that it finishes builds in a greenthread after completing initial validation checks.   These initial validation checks have an atomic operation of "Will this fit, etc?  If so, modify the capacity table."  If that is successful, it sets the instance['host'] to itself and returns True to the scheduler, else it returns False.  (Build then finishes in the background if True)
3) Scheduler checks response of run_instance and picks next best host if it fails.  Repeat.

The reason for finishing the build in a greenthread is so that the scheduler is not sitting there waiting for 'x' minutes for the build to complete to get a response.

This gives us:

1) Cleaner code because there'll be a single spot (the compute worker) where capacity updates occur.
2) An easier way to solve race conditions with the 'sync' operations (startup and periodic) because instance['host'] and capacity is all updated in the same worker.
3) Scheduler has an easy way to pick a host again without possibly picking the same host repeatedly too much.

But, we're proposing to make these changes as a 'next step' in a following branch, I think.  If we can agree on this, I think we can move forward on getting this branch in with some minor tweaks.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-03 17:12:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-03 18:43:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-04 13:49:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-04 13:52:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Sorry, had to do another quick patch (git left an untracked migration in my dev directory so I accidentally bumped the migration to 067) ... moved it back to 066.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-04 16:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-01-11 17:09:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

Ok, this looks good. I wish we could have not renamed the current events to .end, but I see why you did that.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-16 17:17:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

There's a couple of small nits, but it overall looks good.

This change does need to be rebased on trunk since 066 migration is already taken."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-16 17:27:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

Looks good, one comment in line.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-17 08:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Please include a reference to the scaling-zones blueprint in the commit message

Also, a simple "The table represents the current state of compute nodes and will be used by the scheduler when selecting a host" explanation in the commit message would be no harm'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-18 00:22:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Do not submit

Just putting this on here so no one else bothers looking ATM.  Another change is coming.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-19 21:31:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-19 21:42:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-19 21:43:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Removed the Capacity Table and added the necessary fields to the ComputeNode table. Adjusted accordingly.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-01-20 01:01:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (6 inline comments)

Nice work - added my comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-20 13:41:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (5 inline comments)

changes on the way ... thanks for the review Mike!'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-20 13:47:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-01-20 14:48:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-20 16:15:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-22 03:53:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (3 inline comments)

Needs some fixes due to what's hit trunk recently... see inline.

Also:  I think we'll need to change the capacity_find() call (or whatever its name was that filters by ram/disk)... because it's now apparent that not everyone will want to filter out by physical disk/ram.  Some people want to overcommit... and those checks are going into filters.  So, I think we'll have to brainstorm a little on the right way to do it.  I think perhaps that call should accept some filter parameter like instance_get_all_by_filters().  We'll still need the "check and set" call as well... with a similar filter parameter, too.  Not sure how to tie that into the filters, though!

In any case... I'm not sure I'd hold up this branch based on the above, since it's not adding calls from the host_manager yet, but figured I'd drop some notes in on what we'll need to chat about.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-23 14:55:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-23 15:27:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
ComputeNode Capacity support

The table represents the current state of compute nodes and will be
used by the scheduler when selecting a host.

Re: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/scaling-zones

This is just the db & notification portion of the branch. The scheduler
portion is being deferring until comstuds branch gets merged since it
conflicts heavily.

NOTE: Compute notifications are now two-part.
There is a compute.instance.XXX.start event and a compute.instance.XXX.end
message instead of the previous compute.instance.XXX event (which is
the same as the .end message)

Change-Id: Ia8e68680cb0924c59df84f2eec858febf4926d65

Adds unit test to verify behaviour required:

* Location field may only be **edited** if the image is
  in a queued state, which indicates that the user issued
  a POST /images with NO location field and NO image data
* Otherwise, Location field may not be edited and may not
  be read via the API server either.

commit_message:
Bug#911599 - Location field wiped on update

Adds unit test to verify behaviour required:

* Location field may only be **edited** if the image is
  in a queued state, which indicates that the user issued
  a POST /images with NO location field and NO image data
* Otherwise, Location field may not be edited and may not
  be read via the API server either.

Change-Id: I42aba7bc8e2da6ac81b18b564ba096208406f893

[{'created': '2012-01-21 07:17:02.000000000', 'message': 'Adds isolated hosts filter

Part of a series of commits that are moving all of the filtering
done in simple scheduler into hosts filters so we can default to
the distributed scheduler.

commit_message:
Adds isolated hosts filter

 * Also removes a couple of duplicate tests

Part of a series of commits that are moving all of the filtering
done in simple scheduler into hosts filters so we can default to
the distributed scheduler.

Change-Id: I63b05d0c6476ff0ab9cc17e3e6c39f81bec37d77

commit_message:
Add a specific filter for kill commands

Use a specific KillFilter to restrict kill commands run as root.
This implementation checks the signals and the executables
actually affected, using procfs. Fixes bug 918226.

Change-Id: I6f220d741423c4b8e0e792b647760b3ef521b9b2

commit_message:
move batch_config.py to client library.

do not yet add it to console_scripts, as it is more of an internal
development tool.  If we want to expose it to users, we would
probably incorporate it into the main quantum client, rather than
having a separate utility.

Change-Id: I3541dd430b931f883f8e18194776972a9cafcc70

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-common-merge/6/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-23 15:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-23 15:36:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add support to cfg for disabling interspersed args

Implements blueprint cfg-disable-interspersed-args

Nova currently relies on cfg being implemented with optparse because it
uses optparse's disable_interspersed_args()

The use case for this is if you do:

  $> nova-manage --verbose create --project foo --user bar

you want invoking ConfigOpts() to return:

  ['create', '--project', 'foo', '--user', 'bar']

as the "extra" args rather than aborting when it doesn't recognize the
--project arg.

This is a reasonable use case for cfg to support and it should just have
{disable,enable}_interspersed_args() methods.

If we ever switch from optparse to argparse, we'll do something like this:

  parser.add_argument('--verbose')
  ...
  parser.add_argument(
    'extra_args',
    nargs=argparse.REMAINDER if disable_interspersed_args else '*')
  ...
  ns = parser.parse_args(...)
  extra_args = ns.extra_args

i.e. we will need an 'extra_args' multi-value positional argument in any
case and we'll just pass nargs=REMAINDER if we want trailing options to
be included in the extra args.

Change-Id: I3ecb7dc18230327cf5aaaa7d832224e64aafa40c
'}]
commit_message:
Add support to cfg for disabling interspersed args

Implements blueprint cfg-disable-interspersed-args

Nova currently relies on cfg being implemented with optparse because it
uses optparse's disable_interspersed_args()

The use case for this is if you do:

  $> nova-manage --verbose create --project foo --user bar

you want invoking ConfigOpts() to return:

  ['create', '--project', 'foo', '--user', 'bar']

as the "extra" args rather than aborting when it doesn't recognize the
--project arg.

This is a reasonable use case for cfg to support and it should just have
{disable,enable}_interspersed_args() methods.

If we ever switch from optparse to argparse, we'll do something like this:

  parser.add_argument('--verbose')
  ...
  parser.add_argument(
    'extra_args',
    nargs=argparse.REMAINDER if disable_interspersed_args else '*')
  ...
  ns = parser.parse_args(...)
  extra_args = ns.extra_args

i.e. we will need an 'extra_args' multi-value positional argument in any
case and we'll just pass nargs=REMAINDER if we want trailing options to
be included in the extra args.

Change-Id: I3ecb7dc18230327cf5aaaa7d832224e64aafa40c

subject: Add a specific filter for kill commands
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-18 16:43:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

============================================================Hi Thierry,

Your timing is good with this patchset! I was just getting ready to dig into what was causing failures when using nova-rootwrap.

Looks like there is a unit test failure on this one:

==========


FAIL: test_kill_filter (nova.tests.test_nova_rootwrap.RootwrapTestCase)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/tmp/tmp.GtZ3qFdFZC/nova_source/nova/tests/test_nova_rootwrap.py", line 87, in test_kill_filter
    self.assertTrue(f.match(usercmd))
AssertionError: False is not true'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-01-18 17:15:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-18 22:01:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks pretty good to me

I'd suggest that "Incorrect number of arguments" should throw an exception which would be logged, rather than silently returning false ... not a huge deal, though'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-01-19 08:04:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

FWIW match functions in CommandFilters return a boolean, they are not expected to throw exceptions or log anything. They are used by nova-rootwrap (not nova) and should only return False on attack scenarios (abused nova user trying to execute forbidden commands as root).'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-19 08:25:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Programming errors will cause an exception to be thrown. This is just another programming error, but you're hiding it by quietly returning False."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-01-19 08:45:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This code is run by nova-rootwrap, which is a Python process (run as root) completely separate from Nova. Logging wouldn't appear anywhere.

The match function returns False when nova-rootwrap is used to try to run an unauthorized command. An incorrect number of arguments is just as unacceptable as an unauthorized signal."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-19 09:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Ah, sorry - I misread

I thought this was "incorrect number of KillFilter contructor args" - i.e. len(self.args) != 2 rather than len(userargs) != 2'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:38:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Once you clean up the imports, you've got my +2"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-01-20 10:53:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-20 11:17:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Not blocking on it, but I would have preferred to see the imports cleanup as a separate patch and have this patch depend on the cleanup patch. The way it is now, the important parts of the change are lost in the cleanup noise

"Also do foo" in a commit message is a good hint that "do foo" could be a separate commit :-)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-01-20 12:58:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

bcwaldon made me do it :)'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-20 17:24:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Sorry, Mark. I'm not always in backport mode ;) Thankfully this won't need to be backported, so I got lucky this time. 

Thanks for the cleanup, Thierry! You seem to have a test failing:

======================================================================
FAIL: test_kill_filter (nova.tests.test_nova_rootwrap.RootwrapTestCase)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/bcwaldon/projects/nova/nova/tests/test_nova_rootwrap.py", line 86, in test_kill_filter
    self.assertTrue(f.match(usercmd))
AssertionError: False is not true

----------------------------------------------------------------------'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-01-20 17:31:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

looks good to me, see my comment on the length of the sleep.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-01-23 09:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Strange that you get test failure..; Missing /bin/sleep ? I have a bugfix that needs to go in, so I will repropose the patch series.'}]

commit_message:
Add a specific filter for kill commands

Use a specific KillFilter to restrict kill commands run as root.
This implementation checks the signals and the executables
actually affected. Fixes bug 918226.

Also cleans up imports in the whole module to respect HACKING.

Change-Id: If17bfa0c3b8efb4421bce487db493844756af681

commit_message:
Fixes bug #919390 - Block Migration fails when keystone is un use.

I've Updated the calls to nova.virt.libvirt.utils.fetch_image() to match the rest of the class.

Additionally, nova.virt.images.fetch() currently makes no use of the user/project id supplied.

Change-Id: I2db4b8c1b6542909fcc2b452fc961e22fe2557bf

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-21 08:11:05.000000000', 'message': "Make start_instance cast directly to compute host

Fixes bug 918615

start_instance doesn't need to go through scheduler because it still has
instance['host'] set and resources are still accounted for in the
scheduler, which means there's still room to restart it on its assigned
host (even though it is deleted from the virt layer)

Change-Id: I3cdd73b7ad2297b57f7e36be84819ff233ac8f08
"}]
commit_message:
Make start_instance cast directly to compute host

Fixes bug 918615

start_instance doesn't need to go through scheduler because it still has
instance['host'] set and resources are still accounted for in the
scheduler, which means there's still room to restart it on its assigned
host (even though it is deleted from the virt layer)

Change-Id: I3cdd73b7ad2297b57f7e36be84819ff233ac8f08

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-21 08:11:04.000000000', 'message': "Refactor compute api messaging calls to compute manager

API's calls to compute manager all use instance_uuid now.  That allows
us to refactor _cast_compute_message and make everything use it.

This removes an extra DB call in a lot of cases where we already had the
instance object, but then passed an instance_uuid into _cast_compute_message
with no host, where it would look the object up again.

Change-Id: Ia0739efcab0ca362c5bb89cd45c920bf762098f3
"}]
commit_message:
Refactor compute api messaging calls to compute manager

API's calls to compute manager all use instance_uuid now.  That allows
us to refactor _cast_compute_message and make everything use it.

This removes an extra DB call in a lot of cases where we already had the
instance object, but then passed an instance_uuid into _cast_compute_message
with no host, where it would look the object up again.

Change-Id: Ia0739efcab0ca362c5bb89cd45c920bf762098f3

commit_message:
Refactor test_scheduler into unit tests

Also adds a service_is_up test for utils/service_is_up, which used to be
in the scheduler.

Minor bug spotted when doing tests, also, with live migration.  Was
checking 'launched_on' host when should be checking current host.

Change-Id: I964abb767d619afbd90da549b267d8a9d7c31fc1

commit_message:
Add SchedulerHints compute extension

This allows arbitrary key/values to be passed in on a compute create
request or rebuild/resize action. That data will be made available to the
compute api as a filter_properties dictionary.

Change-Id: Ie2ec57dcbc0d1d178e06606cb41027f9e46719a2

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-21 00:03:56.000000000', 'message': 'Update Actions to require class-level name property.

Actions which specified a name during instantiation (or after) caused a subtle bug with instance caching for tables, causing actions to overwrite each other in the cache. A longer-term solution would be to do instance caching based on class rather than name, but that requires an invasive change since "name" is used to construct actions.

Change-Id: I9ad29c8abe59fbb595be6bfaa185de238dcb5314
'}, {'created': '2012-01-21 00:06:08.000000000', 'message': 'Update Actions to require class-level name.

Actions which specified a name during instantiation (or after)
caused a subtle bug with instance caching for tables, causing
actions to overwrite each other in the cache. A longer-term
solution would be to do instance caching based on class rather
than name, but that requires an invasive change since "name"
is used to construct actions.

Change-Id: I9ad29c8abe59fbb595be6bfaa185de238dcb5314
'}]
commit_message:
Update Actions to require class-level name.

Actions which specified a name during instantiation (or after)
caused a subtle bug with instance caching for tables, causing
actions to overwrite each other in the cache. A longer-term
solution would be to do instance caching based on class rather
than name, but that requires an invasive change since "name"
is used to construct actions.

Change-Id: I9ad29c8abe59fbb595be6bfaa185de238dcb5314

commit_message:
Adds Availability Zone Filter

 * Sets distributed scheduler as default for compute
 * Adds context to parameters passed to filter

commit_message:
Support for version and extension discovery

- Supports unauthenticated call to Keystone to discover
  supported API versions
- Added command-line support (usage: keystone discover)
- Added client support (keystoneclient.genenric client).
  Client returns dicts, whereas shell command prints
  formated output.
- Added tests for genenric client
- Replicates 'nove discover' in python-novaclient
- Starts to address blueprint keystone-client
- keystone discover output looks like this:
    $ keystone discover
    Keystone found at http://localhost:35357
        - supports version v1.0 (DEPRECATED) here http://localhost:35357/v1.0
        - supports version v1.1 (CURRENT) here http://localhost:35357/v1.1
        - supports version v2.0 (BETA) here http://localhost:35357/v2.0
            - and HP-IDM: HP Token Validation Extension
            - and OS-KSADM: Openstack Keystone Admin
            - and OS-KSCATALOG: Openstack Keystone Catalog

Change-Id: Id16d34dac094c780d36afb3e31c98c318b6071ac

commit_message:
Adds Images API tests

* Adds new images API tests in tempest/tests/images
* Adds tempest.openstack.ServiceManager class to deal with non-Compute API
  clients
* Adds an [image] section to the configuration file and manager
  that deals with Image API stuff
* Updates the tools/conf_from_devstack script to write an image
  section to the generated tempest.conf

This is all in preparation for removing the functional integration
tests from Glance and putting them in Tempest...

Change-Id: I6caf50e5cab97794204472151acc88fcdd0fc224

commit_message:
Tooltip implementation cleanup.

Re-enables tooltips for modal forms (previously not using delegated events). Fixes bug 918950.
Aligned the x position of the tooltips. Fixes 915762.
Reworks triggers for checkboxes to better handle focus/hover. Fixes bug 915765.

Change-Id: Ic728fd426418c5d81f87256b0674f21050c0e79c

commit_message:
Auto-remove auto-generated .rst files for deleted .py files.

This eliminates annoying warnings when building the docs for files
that were automatically documented and subsequently deleted, causing
import errors in Sphinx.

Change-Id: Iba90c157995b21456dc5bddb44d9e77023112a7b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-20 19:32:06.000000000', 'message': 'Return 400 if registry returns 400.

Fixes bug 919244.  The registry would return 400 for invalid input,
which resulted in an exception.Invalid being thrown in the registry
client.  There was no exception handler for this exception, so it
got bubbled up and turned into a 500.  This should fix the problem
by adding the missing exception handlers.

Change-Id: I75ecfec1c0b0b4b3df1a8c9ace83e75d19527c93
'}]
commit_message:
Return 400 if registry returns 400.

Fixes bug 919244.  The registry would return 400 for invalid input,
which resulted in an exception.Invalid being thrown in the registry
client.  There was no exception handler for this exception, so it
got bubbled up and turned into a 500.  This should fix the problem
by adding the missing exception handlers.

Change-Id: I75ecfec1c0b0b4b3df1a8c9ace83e75d19527c93

Looks great!

Just one thought for the future ...

I wonder would it make sense to follow the separation-of-concerns pattern and move the enforcement logic to a new class PolicyFilter(wsgi.Middleware) in order to avoid polluting the images Controller?

Policy enforement could then be added to the minimal default paste pipeline, e.g.

etc/glance-api-paste.ini:
# Default minimal pipeline
[pipeline:glance-api]
pipeline = versionnegotiation context policy apiv1app

or alternatively disbaled by omitting it from the current pipeline.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-19 16:09:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Honestly I don't want these checks to live in the REST API. They should really live in an internal library. Maybe that means that I need to split up the store checks vs the registry checks, but this is what I've done to get the coverage we need. If it made more sense to me to keep it in the API layer, however, your suggestion would be something to consider. commit_message:
Add policy checking for basic image operations

Partially implements bp interim-glance-authz-service.
This checks basic image operations: get_images, get_image,
add_image, modify_image, delete_image. It looks for a
policy json file next to our config files.

Change-Id: I07f29c11934c68d38a6bdadd39f9dc841b61648a

commit_message:
Handle EC2 Credentials on /tokens

- EC2 credentials are just another type of credential
  that can be passed in to /tokens. This patch now
  handles those credentials correctly.
- POST /tokens {'auth': {'OS-EC2-ec2Credentials...}
  now works correctly.
- Multiple credential handling is improved. There is
  a detect_credentials call in utils now to detect
  the different types.

Addresses:
- bug 843058
- bug 904523
Prepares for:
- bp s3token
- bp keystone-client

Change-Id: I43931fdc7b8a9b76eac351e11394cfa507911578

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-19 22:45:44.000000000', 'message': 'Swallow exception on unsupported image deletion.

Fixes LP #912897

When the remote store does not support deletion of images (e.g. HTTP)
the StoreDeleteNotSupported exception is now swallowed and logged as
opposed to it being propagated back to the glance CLI.

Also after a failed delete, we avoid falling through to the delayed
delete logic.

Change-Id: I6cc529f029750fc66a4d32e2076f29198b3d2093
'}]
commit_message:
Swallow exception on unsupported image deletion.

Fixes LP #912897

When the remote store does not support deletion of images (e.g. HTTP)
the StoreDeleteNotSupported exception is now swallowed and logged as
opposed to it being propagated back to the glance CLI.

Also after a failed delete, we avoid falling through to the delayed
delete logic.

Change-Id: I6cc529f029750fc66a4d32e2076f29198b3d2093

commit_message:
nova/network: pass network_uuid to linuxnet_interface_driver and vif driver

This is preparation for Quantum ovs ryu driver which is proposed by
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/quantum/+spec/ovs-driver-extension
The ryu is available at https://github.com/osrg/ryu

When ovs port is created, the related network information
(including network uuid) is told to ryu.

Change-Id: I88ca1ab9dda4c40d3f5cae4935fcc6f78cf68f28

subject: Allow Quantum Manager to run in "Flat" mode.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 236, 'name': 'Monsyne Dragon', 'email': 'mdragon@rackspace.com', 'username': 'mdragon'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 447, 'name': 'dan wendlandt', 'email': 'dan@nicira.com', 'username': 'danwent'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-19 23:47:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-01-19 23:55:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Yah, needed.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-20 00:00:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The goal of this patch makes sense (i.e., I want to run Quantum Manager without configuring the host that the Quantum Manager is running on to potentially act as a node forwarding traffic).

I'm not a fan of using the dhcp flag to indicate whether this should happen.  To me, the use of DHCP and the use of IPtables for L3 is orthogonal.  You could always choose one but not the other.  

I see two possible solutions here: 
1) add a separate flag indicating whether L3 will be used. 
2) hold off on doing the L3 forwarding initialization until the administrator has signaled that they want a gateway by adding a network that includes a gateway.  

I would probably prefer #2, but I want to get Brad's opinion, as he's about to push some change here that generalize a lot of the L3 functionality, so he's probably thought more about this than I have."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-20 00:15:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yea, I found it odd that the changes to add DHCP support automatically assumed that it needed to be the L3 gateway and started calling into self.driver.

My only issue with option #2 is in our case, networks will have a gateway set that will not be the network-host ala the classic FlatManager style.

We're currently blocked on this, as we don't have iptables/sudo setup on our network hosts. My other thought was to have a "pass" network_driver that just did nothing, but this was less code ;).'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-20 02:57:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

This is definitely a legitimate bug, so if you're OK with brad coming in and changing the code again in a few days, go ahead and push this code if its actively blocking you (I've removed my -1).

Brad's changes should provide you with the same properties: if you don't use L3 + NAT, no need for sudo/IPtables."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-20 18:10:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-01-20 18:11:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-17 19:26:39.000000000', 'message': 'Drop FK constraint if it exists in migration 064

Fixes LP bug 916992

A workaround was originally applied to fix a FK constraint problem in migration
064.  The original bug only affected MySQL+InnoDB databases and was masked by
using MySQL+MyISAM.  Commit d503d6b1079f9eafe0430754214fc5b6d4e32c09 attempted
to improve the workaround, though it caused issues on databases not using
InnoDB, so it was reverted enitrely and we are back with the original bug.

This change will attempt to drop the FK constraint only if it exists.  This
should now support MySQL installations that are configured both
default_storage_engine=MyISAM (oneiric) and default_storage_engine=InnoDB
(precise)

Change-Id: Ie2cfa32d8f52b163f513679649da52a73fc501df
Signed-off-by: Adam Gandleman <adam.gandleman@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Drop FK constraint if it exists in migration 064

Fixes LP bug 916992

A workaround was originally applied to fix a FK constraint problem in migration
064.  The original bug only affected MySQL+InnoDB databases and was masked by
using MySQL+MyISAM.  Commit d503d6b1079f9eafe0430754214fc5b6d4e32c09 attempted
to improve the workaround, though it caused issues on databases not using
InnoDB, so it was reverted enitrely and we are back with the original bug.

This change will attempt to drop the FK constraint only if it exists.  This
should now support MySQL installations that are configured both
default_storage_engine=MyISAM (oneiric) and default_storage_engine=InnoDB
(precise)

Change-Id: Ie2cfa32d8f52b163f513679649da52a73fc501df
Signed-off-by: Adam Gandleman <adam.gandleman@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
scheduler host_manager needs service for filters

distributed scheduler isn't checking service_is_up or
services['disabled'] due to filters not having access to service.

Fixed both.  Since ec2 API also uses service_down_time, I moved
service_is_up() into utils and made ec2 use it.

Change-Id: I0321844a47031b2de4d8738e032a4634edd1e945

commit_message:
Implemented bp keystone-manage2

$ ./bin/keystone-manage --help
usage: keystone-manage [-h] command

OpenStack Identity (Keystone) Management

positional arguments:
  command     create_credential, create_endpoint, create_endpoint_template,
              create_role, create_service, create_tenant, create_token,
              create_user, delete_credential, delete_endpoint,
              delete_endpoint_template, delete_role, delete_service,
              delete_tenant, delete_token, delete_user, downgrade_database,
              goto_database, grant_role, list_credentials,
              list_endpoint_templates, list_endpoints, list_roles,
              list_services, list_tenants, list_tokens, list_users,
              map_endpoint, revoke_role, sync_database, unmap_endpoint,
              update_credential, update_endpoint_template, update_role,
              update_service, update_tenant, update_token, update_user,
              upgrade_database, version, version_control_database

optional arguments:
  -h, --help  show this help message and exit

Change-Id: I67ec29be8ce6407a1e1f5ce8f1b0e00e86c07d8d

commit_message:
Fixes 918535: time not properly parsed in auth_token middleware

- replaced get_datetime() with expanded _convert_datetime()
  function that uses datutil parser to handle any date
  string.
- added tests
- fixes bug 918535
- also addresses bug 911197

Change-Id: I7f4e3c01b1b7466fd5f30889c7b28deae9fc9367

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 711, 'name': 'Matthew Hooker', 'email': 'mwhooker@gmail.com', 'username': 'u-matt-h'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 711, 'date': '2011-11-23 01:33:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It would be very handy if someone could deploy with this patch and perhaps run awscompat against it before it gets +2d. I'll see if anyone on my team can do it.

https://github.com/cloudscaling/aws-compat"}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-11-23 18:22:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

You can probably install devstack with essex and using your branch as the nova branch and run the euca nova/tests...'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-11-23 19:17:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Not a review as such - more a request for clarification:

- I like the idea of adding a parameter validation layer, but why only for EC2 rather than EC2 and OSAPI - I though we were trying to keep OSAPI at least as good asd EC2 ?

- Maybe me being dense, but I couldn't see where the new validation rules were being added to the API calls ?"}, {'account_id': 711, 'date': '2011-11-23 22:58:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@phil

There's a Validator middleware in https://review.openstack.org/#patch,sidebyside,1860,1,nova/api/ec2/web.py which got buried in my attempt to move code out of __init__.py. Look around line 345

As for OSAPI, you're right, we probably should be validating that as well. The validator in this patch should be general enough to be used for OSAPI, though since this patch is for the ec2 api, perhaps a new bug should be opened to add validation to the OSAPI."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-11-29 21:23:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Looks good aside from the inline comment.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-11-30 09:07:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Nice work Matt

I think the move from nova/api/__init__.py to nova/api/web.py in this patch is fairly gratuitous. It makes it very hard to see the validator specific changes. Please submit it is a subsequent change, after this patch has been merged.

You need to include the validator filter in the ec2 pipelines in api-paste.ini.

"Do not import objects, only modules" says our HACKING file. You're importing validate() and DEFAULT_VALIDATOR from the validator module.

ec2.action_args is unused and should just be removed. Please just use req.environ['ec2.request'].args instead. See https://review.openstack.org/1962

Should be a newline between stdlib imports and nova imports in validator.py. See HACKING

Setting an attribute on a method? Ickity ick! :) I'd prefer to see it as an attribute on a Validator object

I think I'd go for something like this:

  class Validator:
    ...
    def validate(self, value, type, **kwargs):
      ...
    def validate_str(self, value, max_length=255):
      ...

  EC2_ARG_VALIDATIONS = {
    'instance_id': ['ec2_id'],
    ...
    'group_name': ['str', max_length=255],

But obviously, there's lots of options

Multiple validators per arg isn't something you're actually using, so I'd drop that altogether. Similarly, we're not using the option of different validators yet, so I'd remove the second arg to validate()'}, {'account_id': 711, 'date': '2011-12-22 01:37:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Mark, thanks very much for your constructive feedback.

I've rolled almost all of your suggestions into a new patch. As soon  as I can figure out how to submit it, I will.

Tomorrow will be my last day at my company, which means I won't be able to follow up on this.

I'll make sure the person who's taking over for me will follow up on this."}, {'account_id': 711, 'date': '2011-12-22 01:59:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-22 13:38:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Thanks for handling most of my comments Matt

Just a few small issues left to handle and I'll +1"}, {'account_id': 711, 'date': '2011-12-22 18:26:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 711, 'date': '2011-12-22 18:35:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-10 16:55:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Cool stuff'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-01-12 13:30:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-01-12 14:42:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I don't know, to be honest. The code looks great, and I think validating things is a great idea, but doing it as middleware seems really weird to me. Can you explain why you chose to do it this way?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-12 18:23:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Matt Hooker went to a different company, so I'm not sure he will be around to answer your question soren.

Soren: do you feel that it is a blocking issue? Or can we merge this and potentially change it later to be something other than a middleware?"}, {'account_id': 711, 'date': '2012-01-12 21:30:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@soren

I don't honestly remember why I put this in middleware.  I think the idea was that all input needs to be validated, and that it can be done in a way that's independent from any given controller."}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-01-13 11:57:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Soren: do you feel that it is a blocking issue? Or can we merge this and potentially change it later to be something other than a middleware?

If there's no good reason to make it middleware, I dread that this will end up on the growing list of things that get accepted under the assumption they'll be fixed later, but then never do."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-13 17:41:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Not going to get into the middleware vs. not-middleware debate, but added a comment that some of nova/api/validation.py should be in /nova/api/ec2/__init__.py.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 21:52:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

I'm holding out for the EC2-specific stuff to live in the nova/api/ec2 directory somewhere.

Also, I agree that doing this as a middleware is kinda weird, but that is also partly due to the fact that I've just spent several weeks refactoring code to finally get rid of the ExtensionMiddleware and LazySerializationMiddleware in the OSAPI…and the latter of those two middlewares was necessary only because extensions are done as middleware."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-19 23:39:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-19 23:48:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-20 04:47:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Bam!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-20 05:06:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/651/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/985/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/598/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2361/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-20 05:06:35.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-20 05:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/nova-tarball/1709/ : SUCCESS'}]

commit_message:
aws/ec2 api validation

Adds middleware to validate user-input to the aws/ec2 api.
This patch is a port to gerrit of this launchpad merge request:
    https://code.launchpad.net/~u-matt-h/nova/aws-api-validation/+merge/71962

blueprint aws-api-validation
bug 813685

Code started by Matthew Hooker, fixes by Joe Gordon

Change-Id: I9346ecd5e5051cb0126c13f7c771173bc23959b9

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-13 22:26:42.000000000', 'message': "Bug #916199: keystone-manage service list fails with AttributeError on Service.description

Make sqlalchemy.api.service take a keystone.models.Service into create, and
return the same from get_all.  This replaces their use of
sqlalchemy.models.Service in these positions.  This is consistent with
User, Tenant, Token, and fixes the bug referenced above.

Added unit tests for keystone.manage.api.{list_services,add_service,
add_token}.  The latter isn't actually related to this bug (that call turned
out to be working fine) but I've written it so you may as well have it!

Fix tearDown in test_backends.  These tests were leaving the DB layer in an
invalid state, so the subsequent test_commands_v1 tests couldn't initialize.

Change-Id: I63e24189832cb96454c085797bff4c5c09e10b70
"}, {'created': '2012-01-19 19:41:50.000000000', 'message': "Bug #916199: keystone-manage service list fails with AttributeError on Service.description

Make sqlalchemy.api.service take a keystone.models.Service into create, and
return the same from get_all.  This replaces their use of
sqlalchemy.models.Service in these positions.  This is consistent with
User, Tenant, Token, and fixes the bug referenced above.

Added unit tests for keystone.manage.api.{list_services,add_service,
add_token}.  The latter isn't actually related to this bug (that call turned
out to be working fine) but I've written it so you may as well have it!

Fix tearDown in test_backends.  These tests were leaving the DB layer in an
invalid state, so the subsequent test_commands_v1 tests couldn't initialize.

Change-Id: I63e24189832cb96454c085797bff4c5c09e10b70
"}]
commit_message:
Bug #916199: keystone-manage service list fails with AttributeError on Service.description

Make sqlalchemy.api.service take a keystone.models.Service into create, and
return the same from get_all.  This replaces their use of
sqlalchemy.models.Service in these positions.  This is consistent with
User, Tenant, Token, and fixes the bug referenced above.

Added unit tests for keystone.manage.api.{list_services,add_service,
add_token}.  The latter isn't actually related to this bug (that call turned
out to be working fine) but I've written it so you may as well have it!

Fix tearDown in test_backends.  These tests were leaving the DB layer in an
invalid state, so the subsequent test_commands_v1 tests couldn't initialize.

Change-Id: I63e24189832cb96454c085797bff4c5c09e10b70

commit_message:
Add support for proxy servers

Set http_proxy and https_proxy as usual outside of devstack, or
in localrc.  All clients running under sudo need env vars passed
explicitly (apt-get, pip, curl).  Some tests using wget need proxy
turned off since they point to our services (i.e. glance, keystone).

Change-Id: Ie87aa2d3502ed5a1312f148db12bb61e5eaf1054

commit_message:
Increase exercise robustness

* increase some timeouts
* tolerate existing security groups and rules
* add optional DEFAULT_IMAGE_NAME to select the image to boot
* fix image lists via glance

Change-Id: I31ae743e602f69a2c9f872273273f542fc4afda3

messages:

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-01-19 07:14:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-01-19 07:18:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-01-19 07:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-01-19 07:50:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

not a fan of this style of cli at all, did the dynamicly built cli we discussed not work for you?

the decorator style is pretty weird, in my opinion, and there seems to be a lot of repetition, and using --args for all variables is pretty strict and limiting"}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-01-19 08:08:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I tried getting the dynamic client provided in keystonelight's keystone-manage to work within keystoneclient but was unsuccessful.

I agree that the keystonelight's style of building a cli is cleaner and requires less code but I also think that writing the cli in the same style as python-novaclient is acceptable and transparent for developers who work on both clients."}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-01-19 22:20:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-19 18:50:48.000000000', 'message': 'Exception raise error

Fixes bug #916827

As per: http://docs.python.org/library/stdtypes.html
?highlight=__exit__#contextmanager.__exit__

Ionut Artarisi wrote:

The exception passed in should never be reraised explicitly - instead,
this method should return a false value to indicate that the method completed
successfully and does not want to suppress the raised exception.
This allows context management code (such as contextlib.nested) to easily
detect whether or not an __exit__() method has actually failed.

Change-Id: I79bbac32b5c99742b5cb283c6e55e6204bf92adc
'}]
commit_message:
Exception raise error

Fixes bug #916827

As per: http://docs.python.org/library/stdtypes.html
?highlight=__exit__#contextmanager.__exit__

Ionut Artarisi wrote:

The exception passed in should never be reraised explicitly - instead,
this method should return a false value to indicate that the method completed
successfully and does not want to suppress the raised exception.
This allows context management code (such as contextlib.nested) to easily
detect whether or not an __exit__() method has actually failed.

Change-Id: I79bbac32b5c99742b5cb283c6e55e6204bf92adc

commit_message:
Updates to middleware to deprecate X_USER

- There is an outstanding issue where we return the user id
  for the legacy X-User header, but the documentation says
  it should be the 'name the user logged in with'. I did not
  fix this in this commit until we discuss with other teams.

Change-Id: Ibf2acf5bb594b889b5c220ea00d777ac528175b0

commit_message:
Log uuid when instances fail to spawn.

Update xenapi/vmops.py so it logs the UUID instead of the instance ID
when instances fail to spawn. Fixes LP bug #918497.

Change-Id: Id7f41ccb79d22df5d10a5d6d9822ff65dd459056

commit_message:
Bug #915544: keystone-manage version 1 commands broken when using flags

Fix detection of keystone-manage version 1 commands.  The
heuristic for detecting these was broken in the presence
of options of the command line.

Change-Id: Iae7b5fe892ce5030a384867f1783dd81f7a4bd74

subject: Multi-process Glance API server support.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 455, 'name': 'Stuart McLaren', 'email': 'stuart.mclaren@hpe.com', 'username': 'stuart-mclaren'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 927, 'name': 'Gabe Westmaas', 'email': 'gabe.westmaas@rackspace.com', 'username': 'westmaas'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 455, 'date': '2011-12-20 18:11:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Note: This is closely based on similar functionality in Swift's wsgi.py."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-20 19:52:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good to me.  Don't forget to email the list to warn about the configuration file change once this is approved."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-26 16:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

It might be a good idea to test 0 workers as well as 1, since they do use two different code paths."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-27 16:57:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hey Stuart, any chance of adding that test for 0 workers like Brian suggests? I agree it would be good to test that alternate code path."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-02 13:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (9 inline comments)

Hi Stuart, have a few more code readability and i18n comments inline..'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-05 17:35:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Rain confirmed that this patch fixes a long-standing performance problem of simultaneously running index and add:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/907969

Let's get this in ASAP."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-05 17:38:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

I'm actually thinking of pulling this locally, adding the missing test and fixing up the remaining comments. I'd like to move on this quickly now that it is confirmed that it increases scalability substantially."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-07 02:58:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Go for it. I think we might want to standardize the abandonment period for things like this. Does 2 weeks w/ no response sounds fair?'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 20:57:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 20:58:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I went ahead and took point on this one. In addition to addressing all of Jay's comments, I also did this:

- Default to 0 workers across the board.
- Added functional test module that runs with 2 workers"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:08:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Thanks Brian! Couple little nits to address, but this is great."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:12:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:12:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

rock on.'}, {'account_id': 927, 'date': '2012-01-11 02:56:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I saw something similar to this smokestack failure the other day.  I think the rebuild, reboot, and subsequent tests can be ignored - right now when a server has a task_state of snapshotting, rebuild and reboot fail.  The errors after the reboot are because it is expecting the rebuild to have been successful.

I'm not sure why the snapshot didn't work, have you seen anything that might cause that?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-11 02:58:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Gabe! No, this patch really shouldn't affect anything related to snapshotting... is there a way to re-run smokestack against this branch to see if this was an intermittent failure?"}, {'account_id': 927, 'date': '2012-01-11 04:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks like it was a fluke, smokestack passed twice in a row!'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-11 05:22:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hm.  Slightly funky thing in here.  In bin/*, there's a server.start() and server.wait().  When workers > 0, start() will actually block.  If the parent gets a SIGTERM or HUP, it'll end up returning.  server.wait() should get called at that point.  And it does a self.pool.waitall(), but there is no self.pool() in the parent.

In the workers == 0 case, start() will return and wait() gets called like it did before, with a valid self.pool

At least this is what I can tell from this patch.  Am I missing something?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 23:06:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(2 inline comments)

Couple of doc nits here.  I also see a potential race condition around the signal handler setup, but that's (hopefully) unlikely to happen.  (Who's going to HUP/TERM their server immediately as it starts up?  If they do, they deserve whatever they get :)"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-18 23:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-18 23:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-18 23:40:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

All issues should be addressed'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-18 23:53:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:23:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Excellent.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:33:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Fails

Build Failed

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-pep8/469/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:50:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:50:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Sorry about that, rebased and good to go.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:51:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Multi-process Glance API server support.

Implements blueprint multi-process-server. Allows several Glance API
worker processes to be started, which can increase performance on machines
with more than one CPU.

Change-Id: I1cbb48945fd23afd71de3a30b80836b590c023a1

Adds boundary tests for image metadata in Compute API

Changed the indentation to 4 space width.
Added nonexistant tests for image metadata operations

commit_message:
Removed references to FLAGS.floating_ip_dns_domains.

Now the availabable floating_ip_dns zones can be modified
dynamically, and determined from the DNS driver and nova database.

Change-Id: I0e02858e95085c868e8891f8f21d204472c46d33

commit_message:
Removed some vestigial default args from DNS drivers.

In an early design, the domain was optional for several
DNS driver methods.  That would add some needless complexity
to the drivers, and I never really implemented it anyway.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: Ia7b4c9ff7eaa9b6d8c1091a92bb7439941ac0a9f

commit_message:
Clean up crypto.py

 * Remove chained certs since we don't use them
 * Make get_vpn use the existing generate call instead of shell script
 * (Bonus: we can revoke vpn certs now)

Change-Id: I8e118c5bd3dee6ba7c6a2a1390874b69008c436b

[{'created': '2012-01-18 23:52:16.000000000', 'message': "Rename 'zone' to 'domain.'

between dns zones and openstack availability zones.  'Domain'

Change-Id: I1d420be2e6f2054ee4392ce762775ece20a823b3

commit_message:
Rename 'zone' to 'domain.'

This code was getting confusing because of the ambiguity
between dns zones and openstack availability zones.  'Domain'
seems a bit clearer than 'zone' in this context.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: I1d420be2e6f2054ee4392ce762775ece20a823b3

commit_message:
Make paste.ini file location configurable.

Add an optional paste_deploy.config_file variable to identify
a non-default location for the paste.ini file (the default for
/path/to/component.conf is /path/to/component-paste.ini).

Change-Id: Ibd7aefe95706fb50e4e353c14eb6dab0f948331f

commit_message:
Set size metadata correctly for remote images.

Previously the size metadata was always zero'd for remote images,
which was misleading and led to issues like:

  Bug 900959

We now query the remote store (HTTP, S3 or Swift) with the
equivalent of a HTTP HEAD in order to determine the correct
image size without downloading.

Where the size is available, the metadata is set appropriately.
Otherwise it falls back to zero as before.

Change-Id: I3093eba1b2fa023348558c45febee39e68e1a08f

[{'created': '2012-01-13 17:38:08.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid the need for users to manually edit PasteDeploy config in order to switch pipelines.

Define multiple pipelines in glace-api.conf to reflect the
various supported deployment flavors (minimal, with caching,
with cache management, with keystone-based auth etc.).

Add an optional paste_deploy.flavor config variable to allow the
user select the appropriate pipeline without having to edit the
paste config (i.e. uncommenting lines as before). For example
in glance-api.conf, a setting of:

  [paste_deploy]
  flavor = keystone+caching

identifies the following pipeline in glace-api-paste.ini:

  [pipeline:glance-api-keystone+caching]
  pipeline = versionnegotiation authtoken auth-context cache apiv1app

the advantage being that the user need not be concerned with
the precise sequence of filters required to realize the QoS
they desire.

Modify the functional tests that patch configuration (i.e. the
keystone and caching tests) to use the new deployment_flavor
mechanism.

Extend the TestConfigOpts to support option groups.

Change-Id: Ide843ada11bce115b7dc650440397853c6409b03

commit_message:
Avoid the need for users to manually edit PasteDeploy config in order to switch pipelines.

Define multiple pipelines in glace-api.conf to reflect the
various supported deployment flavors (minimal, with caching,
with cache management, with keystone-based auth etc.).

Add an optional paste_deploy.flavor config variable to allow the
user select the appropriate pipeline without having to edit the
paste config (i.e. uncommenting lines as before). For example
in glance-api.conf, a setting of:

  [paste_deploy]
  flavor = keystone+caching

identifies the following pipeline in glace-api-paste.ini:

  [pipeline:glance-api-keystone+caching]
  pipeline = versionnegotiation authtoken auth-context cache apiv1app

the advantage being that the user need not be concerned with
the precise sequence of filters required to realize the QoS
they desire.

Modify the functional tests that patch configuration (i.e. the
keystone and caching tests) to use the new deployment_flavor
mechanism.

Extend the TestConfigOpts to support option groups.

Change-Id: Ide843ada11bce115b7dc650440397853c6409b03

This flag allows deployers to choose which address proxies like nova-xvpvncserver should use to to connect to instance proxies.  For xenserver, this will generally be the management ip of dom0.  For libvirt, this will be the management ip of the host.

 * Improves deployment flexibility by allowing deployers to choose which address proxies like nova-xvpvncserver should use to to connect to instance proxies.  For xenserver, this will generally be the management ip of dom0.  For libvirt, this will be the management ip of the host.

commit_message:
Allow config of vncserver_proxyclient_address.

 * Improves deployment flexibility by allowing deployers to choose which address proxies like nova-xvpvncserver should use to to connect to instance proxies.  For xenserver, this will generally be the management ip of dom0.  For libvirt, this will be the management ip of the host.
 * Fixes bug 918451
 * Renames vncserver_host to vncserver_listen for slightly better usage clarity
 * Updates docs

Change-Id: I85c9850c57ffac3dfecaec4510eb808a6a2af79c

commit_message:
Corresponds to the Glance patch that splits paste

The patchset https://review.openstack.org/#change,3036 splits
paste.deploy application pipeline stuff from regular configuration
file options. This is the change to devstack that will be needed
to go along with that change in Glance.

Change-Id: I606aa81c8ebdf50cdc554611ab3781c554991205
