Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1998, 'name': 'andrewbogott', 'username': 'andrewbogott', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 21:37:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm of two minds on this patch.  On the one hand, having this functionality available for nova is great, even if it's only used by WikiMedia right now.  On the other hand, some of this is apparently only used by WikiMedia right now.

I think one of the things that would make me happier is if the defaults for the new flags could be changed to something more generic—ldap.example.com, for instance?"}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-01-16 21:58:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Kevin --

I totally agree... I got bogged down in unit tests and forgot that I had WM-specific stuff in the flags.  I will make those generic and resubmit.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-01-16 22:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-01-16 22:11:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-01-16 22:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I know vish has been reviewing this code as well.  We are interested in using this eventually.

We might have tweaks to the api once we start looking at it in more depth post E3'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-01-16 22:36:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Be forewarned that PowerDNS/ldap is a dead end, as the PDNS people have already announced that they're discontinuing ldap support.

We'll be using LDAP for a while yet at WikiMedia because we're already down that path, but new development should pursue a different backend."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 22:50:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

I see a PEP8 error, but otherwise, this looks fine.  Thanks!

(If you haven't already, might want to change that password on your existing back end…unless it was always just an example ;)"}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-01-16 23:15:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 23:35:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Added an LDAP/PowerDNS driver

This driver is largely for internal WikiMedia use.  It will probably
need a fair bit of tinkering for any other deployment.

Related to blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: I8636296192aecffedf363bd10a4ae761f7f6e6c3

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 970, 'name': 'Dean Troyer', 'email': 'dtroyer@gmail.com', 'username': 'dtroyer'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-12 23:30:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Great catch, but grepping the source I see these additional password/key flags:

FLAGS.ldap_password
FLAGS.xenapi_connection_password
FLAGS.vmwareapi_host_password
FLAGS.san_password
FLAGS.san_privatekey
FLAGS.build_plan_encryption_key
FLAGS.s3_access_key
FLAGS.vsa_ec2_access_key"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-12 23:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-13 00:02:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Dean,

I updated the patch to hide the contents of any flag that contains the word password.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-13 07:46:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch looks fairly reasonable, but could you file a bug report covering this and reference it in the commit msg? Thanks'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-13 15:52:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Joe,

Using "_password" and "_key" would eliminate a couple of false positives (FLAGS.password_length and FLAGS.monkey_patch_modules) and only remove a couple of flags incorrectly (FLAGS.credential_key_file and FLAGS.vnc_keymap).  Of course that is just for today's trunk, maintaining this is going to be interesting.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-13 17:13:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

One way we could make this easier to maintain is to add "the value of this option is security sensitive" to the option schemas

So, since Nova will be moving from gflag definitions to cfg schemas you might have e.g.

  conf.register_opt(StrOpt('admin_password', secret=True))

and the logging stuff will be smart enough to elide these values

See https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-common/+spec/cfg-password-options'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-13 20:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-13 21:22:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-13 21:27:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Dean,
Thanks for the feedback I made the relevant changed.

Mark,
I created a ticket for the problem.  I take it I should continue with the patch until the longterm openstack-common solution is ready/'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-13 21:49:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Looks like this will miss 'san_privatekey'"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-13 22:59:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Chris, I checked and it looks like san_privatekey is actually an ssh key filename so I think that one is OK.  Depending on the naming of the flags to match here makes me uncomfortable.  It wouldn't be too much work to go through and clean up the false matches/misses here but I have no idea how much breakage outside of Nova that might cause...

I think the long-term suggestion of attributes in the revamped config system is workable, can we live with this until then?"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-17 21:39:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Dean,

While I do think we can live with this until the revamped config system is workable, I am concerned that if the revamped config gets put on hold this will never get patched.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-18 03:59:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

To be clear, by 'live with this' I was referring to the current proposal in my response to Chris."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-18 19:22:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-18 19:55:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-18 20:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-18 21:01:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

Thnx, looks good now.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-18 21:37:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Do not write passwords to verbose logs. bug 916167

Look for _key and _password in flag names

Change-Id: Ic0c43ad70db0b9f819219e8ca4966908e48b50c9

commit_message:
Glance changes to stack.sh for https://review.openstack.org/3092

* Handle before/after upcoming Glance configuration file changes
* Add configuration vars for Keystone URIs to configure Glance
  and other services

Change-Id: I465065592ade11fb86c40cd04d29c4ae3f1706d7

commit_message:
Fix disassociating of auto assigned floating ips.

Also makes adds passing True to the disassociate/deallocate functions
use a kwarg so the meaning is more apparent.

Fixes bug #918358.

Change-Id: Ie88d19456ffe0fa5f7c7bba79b572672db96c766

commit_message:
Add dns domain manipulation to nova.

Adding this functionality required the existing DNS api
to be rearranged considerably.

Nova needs to track some information about domains that is
outside the scope of the DNS driver, specifically the availability
zone of a private domain and the project of a public domain.
In order to track those attributes, this patch adds a new table
to the Nova database, dns_domains.

This patch perpetuates some naming ambiguities (e.g. zone vs. domain).
A future renaming patch will sort all this out.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: I80865207d34ab7c6e2afc5638863a299b3913f8e

commit_message:
Rework exceptions in Tempest

* Add base exception class similar to other OS projects
* Catch certain HTTP errors and raise exceptions in base
  client classes
* Fixes LP Bug#899701 by adding tearDownClass() method
  to the test_list_images.ListImagesTest class to destroy
  images and instances the test case creates

Change-Id: I0f616813539b31da27e5106a59c2ca3765b1919f

"}, {'created': '2011-12-29 10:01:35.000000000', 'message': "Separate scheduler host management

This is a bit of a scheduler refactoring to support future scaling work
as a part of blueprint scaling-zones.

With or without that blueprint work, this cleans a number of things up
and paves the way for combining a lot of the schedulers by using this
new 'HostManager' for filtering and weighing (future work :)

On to the goodies:

Introduces new HostManager, splitting code out from ZoneManager.
Zone communication and management is handlded in the ZoneManager.
Host filtering and weighing is handled in the HostManager.
ZoneManager is removed from the SchedulerManager and direct calls to it
  from the SchedulerManager now occur via the scheduler driver.  This
  simplifies a number of things.
ZoneManager and HostManager classes to use are now flags.  This allows
  one to extend the current classes and use them.
HostManager uses a HostState class to keep info about hosts.  This class
  needs to be extendable.  Since it's very much tied to the HostManager,
  the HostState class to use is not a flag.  It is, instead, a class
  variable in HostManager.
Filtering functions now accept a single host to filter.  This improves
  performance by not having to build a new array of hosts within every
  filter function.
Filtering functions now accept a more generic 'filter_properties'
  dictionary which we can fill with information available for filtering.
Filtering functions are now topic-specific, so we can support more than
  just compute host filtering.
Filtering tests are true unit tests now.
test_zones was moved from top level to under scheduler as zone_manager
  tests and refactored to be true unit tests.
Host tests are true unit tests now.
Other minor cleanups

Change-Id: I0ef2acef6639b4500c400c18cf2c673cb80f0150
"}, {'created': '2011-12-30 01:47:17.000000000', 'message': "Separate scheduler host management

This is a bit of a scheduler refactoring to support future scaling work

Introduces new HostManager, splitting code out from ZoneManager.
Zone communication and management is handlded in the ZoneManager.
Host filtering and weighing is handled in the HostManager.
ZoneManager is removed from the SchedulerManager and direct calls to it
  from the SchedulerManager now occur via the scheduler driver.  This
  simplifies a number of things.
ZoneManager and HostManager classes to use are now flags.  This allows
  one to extend the current classes and use them.
HostManager uses a HostState class to keep info about hosts.  This class
  needs to be extendable.  Since it's very much tied to the HostManager,
  the HostState class to use is not a flag.  It is, instead, a class
  variable in HostManager.
Filtering functions now accept a single host to filter.  This improves
  performance by not having to build a new array of hosts within every
  filter function.
Filtering functions now accept a more generic 'filter_properties'
  dictionary which we can fill with information available for filtering.
  Adding additional data to this 'filter_properties' can be done by
  subclassing.
Weighing functions now accept this 'filter_properties', also, although
  it's poorly named ATM.  Will be cleaned up in a future branch when I
  move some weighing functions into the host manager.
Filtering functions are now topic-specific, so we can support more than
  just compute host filtering.
Filtering tests are true unit tests now.
test_zones was moved from top level to under scheduler as zone_manager
  tests and refactored to be true unit tests.
Host tests are true unit tests now.
Other minor cleanups

commit_message:
Separate scheduler host management

This is a bit of a scheduler refactoring to support future scaling work
as a part of blueprint scaling-zones.

Also fixes bug 891971 (remove unused set_network_host in scheduler)

With or without that blueprint work, this cleans a number of things up
and paves the way for combining a lot of the schedulers by using this
new 'HostManager' for filtering and weighing (future work :)

On to the goodies:

Introduces new HostManager, splitting code out from ZoneManager.
Zone communication and management is handlded in the ZoneManager.
Host filtering and weighing is handled in the HostManager.
ZoneManager is removed from the SchedulerManager and direct calls to it
  from the SchedulerManager now occur via the scheduler driver.  This
  simplifies a number of things.
ZoneManager and HostManager classes to use are now flags.  This allows
  one to extend the current classes and use them.
HostManager uses a HostState class to keep info about hosts.  This class
  needs to be extendable.  Since it's very much tied to the HostManager,
  the HostState class to use is not a flag.  It is, instead, a class
  variable in HostManager.
Filtering functions now accept a single host to filter.  This improves
  performance by not having to build a new array of hosts within every
  filter function.
Filtering functions now accept a more generic 'filter_properties'
  dictionary which we can fill with information available for filtering.
  Adding additional data to this 'filter_properties' can be done by
  subclassing.
Weighing functions now accept this 'filter_properties', also, although
  it's poorly named ATM.  Will be cleaned up in a future branch when I
  move some weighing functions into the host manager.
Filtering tests are true unit tests now.
test_zones was moved from top level to under scheduler as zone_manager
  tests and refactored to be true unit tests.
Host tests are true unit tests now.
Other minor cleanups

Change-Id: I0ef2acef6639b4500c400c18cf2c673cb80f0150

revisions:

commit_message:
Fixed bug 912701

Add an check to the list_instances method so that the domains whose ID
is 0 are not listed, since this is reserved in libvirt for hypervisors.

Refers to https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg06699.html

Change-Id: I55f6f370cbaf8bd2254e08afad8b36d833726817

subject: Check M2Crypto before making venv in Oneiric
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1994, 'name': 'Zhongyue Luo', 'email': 'zhongyue.luo@gmail.com', 'username': 'zyluo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-15 16:27:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

nice work.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-16 17:08:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Looks good, have one question though.

I'm wondering if we can preserve the 'automate-everything' aspect of install_venv by doing something like:

1. Retaining the automatic `sudo apt-get install python-mcrypto`

2. Once apt-get returns (w/ zero exit status), we import M2Crypto and discover its path

3. Use that path to symlink into the venv

The advantage w/ this approach (assuming it works :-), is that we're not relying on environment preconditions when creating our venv.... one less thing for the user to have to worry about.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 17:15:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good to me, modulo Rick's question…"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-16 19:20:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think having a script run sudo and install software system wide is a bit of a surprise. It's certainly outside of the scope of setting up a virtualenv."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-16 19:56:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Johannes: Don't disagree there.  Though we're already doing that in the Fedora install_venv driver. 

I'd lead slightly towards preserving the 'install-for-user' behavior in this patch, and then creating a separate bug/patch to remove 'sudo' entirely from the script."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-17 22:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I guess this patch is obsolete now?'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-18 14:42:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Obsolete'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-15 12:18:45.000000000', 'message': 'Check M2Crypto before making venv in Oneiric

Fixes Bug #916749

After venv is created soft link python-m2crypto to venv.

Change-Id: Ie47d3f2187dcf88048edfb4ed30aabbcae1b8848
'}]
commit_message:
Check M2Crypto before making venv in Oneiric

Fixes Bug #916749

Changed python-m2crypto check on Oneiric before venv is created.

After venv is created soft link python-m2crypto to venv.

Change-Id: Ie47d3f2187dcf88048edfb4ed30aabbcae1b8848

subject: Set instance_ref property when creating snapshots.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-17 21:02:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

This was explicitly removed. Can you please update the view builder code to use instance_uuid rather than re-adding instance_ref? If you would rather keep instance_ref and drop instance_uuid, that would work, too. We just don't need both."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-17 21:08:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

bcwaldon:

As near as I can tell 'instance_ref' is the correct way to do this.

See for the backup admin action:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/admin_actions.py#L235

Also have a look at what the image view builder actually expects:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/images.py#L53

Am I missing something here?"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-17 21:21:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

For reference:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/6e7e3870a4ca047185ba5e3320d63afaa08357b8

Looks like we need to go the other way and remove 'instance_ref' in favor of just the instance_uuid.

The backup action needs to be updated to use instance_uuid as well."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-17 21:25:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Actually, the property code can just be removed from backup. instance_uuid is added in the compute api automagically'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-17 21:58:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-17 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

WIP.

Looks like I've got a test failure (test_create_backup)."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-17 23:03:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-17 23:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

bcwaldon: I think this is a go now.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-17 23:05:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

One minor thing, Dan. Thanks for cleaning up after me :)"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-18 02:15:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-18 04:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yes, sir. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-18 07:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-18 07:54:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful

commit_message:
Converts instances and volumes to new tables, modals, etc.

This commit reworks the instances and volumes panels, extends that to
the syspanel instances panel, cleans up usage-related code and
moves it to overview and/or tenants panels as appropriate,
and finally implements a new layout/modal interface style
for combined modal/table views like security groups and
volume attachments.

Re-ordered the attach volume form. Fixed bug 913863.
Reworked syspanel usage views. Fixed bug 904861.
Table displays have much more useful data. Fixed bug 905065 and fixed bug 907512.
New modals fixed bug 898867.

Lots of additional code cleanup and fixes.

Change-Id: I407d3ec70a080883c137a963fa0ee22124b53dc2

messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-11 01:52:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hm.  I notice the old code you replaced also has the same problem, but:

Technically in proxies, when you get an EOF from a read(), you should only call socket.shutdown(SHUT_WR) on the destination until you've received an EOF from both sides.  It's possible that the destination is sending data back to you at the same time that you still want to relay back.  And EOF doesn't mean the connection is closed.. it just means there's no more data to read.  When you've finally decided you're done (you've got the EOF from both sides), you can then socket.close().

See 'Connection Termination' section here: http://pdos.csail.mit.edu/6.824-2004/labs/tcpproxy.html"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-11 02:04:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

One other question inline.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-11 19:57:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

added a response to your comment chris - curious about Ewan's take"}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-11 19:59:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The smokestack failures appear to be packaging errors due to the removal of nova-vncproxy.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-11 20:08:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(15 inline comments)

Thanks for the awesome work, Anthony. I've got some style comments inline. Also, it looks like your extension might be able to replace the undocumented consoles extension we already have (api/openstack/v2/consoles.py). Can you confirm this and possibly remove that old file if so?"}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-14 07:27:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-14 07:31:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Brian - I addressed your previous feedback with the following exceptions:
 * I didn't add a test for get_session_id, as no other similar functions in the XenAPISession class have tests and are generally stubbed out.
 * I am still trying to determine what to do with the existing console api code.  I should have an update shortly.

Chris - I reworked the proxy code based on your feedback.  I will contact citrix folks directly and inquire about the use of get_session_id in the context where you commented."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 22:02:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Code looks good, but you're using a recently deprecated interface for the extension.  For an example of converting ActionExtension over to ControllerExtension, see https://review.openstack.org/#change,3020"}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-17 21:28:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-17 21:37:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Implements blueprint vnc-console-cleanup

 * Creates a unified way to access vnc consoles for xenserver and libvirt
 * Now supports both java and websocket clients
 * Removes nova-vncproxy - a replacement version of this (nova-novncproxy) can be found as described in vncconsole.rst
 * Adds nova-xvpvncproxy, which supports a java vnc client
 * Adds api extension to access java and novnc access_urls
 * Fixes proxy server to close/shutdown sockets more cleanly
 * Address style feedback
 * Use new-style extension format
 * Fix setup.py
 * utils.gen_uuid must be wrapped like str(utils.gen_uuid()) or it can't be serialized

Change-Id: I5e42e2f160e8e3476269bd64b0e8aa77e66c918c

commit_message:
Implemented user & tenant CRUD (bp keystone-manage2)

- ./bin/keystone-manage create_user, list_users, update_user, delete_user
- ./bin/keystone-manage create_tenant, list_tenants, update_tenant, delete_tenant
- Create & update commands also old cover enabling/disable functionality

Change-Id: Ifa840bfeb14a52a82f522de070c5f50d016b9cc7

[{'created': '2012-01-13 17:05:11.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint host-aggregates

This is the first of a series of commits that add the host-aggregates capability, as described on the blueprint page.

This commit, more precisely, introduces changes to the Nova model: model classes related to aggregates have been added, as well as DB API methods to interact with the model; a sqlalchemy migration script plus a bunch of tests are also part of this changeset.

Commits that will follow are going to add:

- Extensions to OSAPI Admin, and related python_novaclient mappings
- Implementation of the XenAPI virt layer
- Integration of OSAPI and virt layer, via the compute_api
- smoketests

These commits will be pushed for review not necessarily in this exact order.

commit_message:
blueprint host-aggregates

This is the first of a series of commits that add the host-aggregates capability,
as described on the blueprint page.

This commit, more precisely, introduces changes to the Nova model: model classes
related to aggregates have been added, as well as DB API methods to interact with
the model; a sqlalchemy migration script plus a bunch of tests are also part of
this changeset.

Commits that will follow are going to add:

- Extensions to OSAPI Admin, and related python_novaclient mappings
- Implementation of the XenAPI virt layer
- Integration of OSAPI and virt layer, via the compute_api
- smoketests
- openstack-manuals documentation

These commits will be pushed for review not necessarily in this exact order.

Change-Id: Iceb27609dc53bf4305c02d7cbc436fba4c4a7256

[{'created': '2012-01-17 17:33:36.000000000', 'message': "Fix an error that prevents message from getting substituted.

The problem: self.__dict__ contains message.  This overrides the
default of None for the NovaException constructor.  Since a
message is provided, it's used directly instead of trying to
substitute the keyword arguments.  The solution is to limit the
keyword arguments we pass to the NovaException constructor, so
they don't contain message.  Fixes bug 917768.

Change-Id: I5986fa7b552c84ba7f902e78b32498ab294beb7b
"}, {'created': '2012-01-17 19:14:01.000000000', 'message': "Fix an error that prevents message from getting substituted.

The problem: self.__dict__ contains message.  This overrides the
default of None for the NovaException constructor.  Since a
message is provided, it's used directly instead of trying to
substitute the keyword arguments.  The solution is to limit the

commit_message:
Fix an error that prevents message from getting substituted.

The problem: self.__dict__ contains message.  This overrides the
default of None for the NovaException constructor.  Since a
message is provided, it's used directly instead of trying to
substitute the keyword arguments.  The solution is to limit the
keyword arguments we pass to the NovaException constructor, so
they don't contain message.  Fixes bug 917768.

Change-Id: I5986fa7b552c84ba7f902e78b32498ab294beb7b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-17 15:14:50.000000000', 'message': 'Add missing scripts to setup.py (lp#917676)

If distutils-extra is installed, all scripts are automatically included
in the tarball. We should explicitly include them in setup.py to avoid
confusion.

As an example, the 2011.3 tarballs appear to have been generated with
distutils-extra but the 2011.3.1/2012.1 tarballs are now being
generated in a venv. So, these newer tarballs are missing scripts which
were included in 2011.3.

(cherry picked from commit d72109e7114724de668de24800829b07e0d3fe7e)

Change-Id: I2a85418b84b93e041f6c7d31833b09acdcb29daa
'}]
commit_message:
Add missing scripts to setup.py (lp#917676)

If distutils-extra is installed, all scripts are automatically included
in the tarball. We should explicitly include them in setup.py to avoid
confusion.

As an example, the 2011.3 tarballs appear to have been generated with
distutils-extra but the 2011.3.1/2012.1 tarballs are now being
generated in a venv. So, these newer tarballs are missing scripts which
were included in 2011.3.

(cherry picked from commit d72109e7114724de668de24800829b07e0d3fe7e)

Change-Id: I2a85418b84b93e041f6c7d31833b09acdcb29daa

commit_message:
Add missing scripts to setup.py (lp#917676)

If distutils-extra is installed, all scripts are automatically included
in the tarball. We should explicitly include them in setup.py to avoid
confusion.

As an example, the 2011.3 tarballs appear to have been generated with
distutils-extra but the 2011.3.1/2012.1 tarballs are now being
generated in a venv. So, these newer tarballs are missing scripts which
were included in 2011.3.

Change-Id: I2a85418b84b93e041f6c7d31833b09acdcb29daa

subject: Make volumes work again with oneiric
messages:
[{'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-14 05:09:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Vish, I'm having a problem with tgt not starting properly the first time.  It looks like the upstart config file for tgt is :

+ sudo restart tgt
restart: Unknown instance:

subject: Add policy checking to nova.network.api.API
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-13 00:18:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Default rules are empty for now since we dont have any good roles to validate against and we don't have volume objects so we cant check ownership"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-13 00:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

s/volume/network/'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-13 00:58:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-13 14:39:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

A few comments inline.

I'd like to at least get back to having a netadmin role that we check for actions that create or delete network resources, like we did back in the good old days.  I know I can do this by tuning the json, but I'd like to have a default that does *something*.

Are there places where calling enforce with a target of the return value of an rpc.call makes sense?  Is it possible to add enforce checks in the manager and bubble the exception (if it raises one) back through the queue?

We need some way to enforce ownership of IPs that are attempted to be associated, unassociated, etc.  Ideally we would check for ownership AND the netadmin role, like we did in Bexar."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-13 15:28:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Todd: The default of noauth means that we can't depend on extra roles existing.  I think it makes sense for the default to stay at admin-or-owner.  

There might be some value in defining a couple more default rules that resolve to admin-or-owner:
rule:compute-default -> rule:admin-or-owner
rule:network-default -> rule:admin-or-owner
rule:volume-default -rule:admin-or-owner

I was also discussing with brian about where the checking should go, and I think it might be more valuable in the network case to put it in the manager classes.  We are planning on loading all of the objects at the api layer, checking, and then passing them through the queue, but I'm not sure that makes sense for network as it will break quantum manager."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-16 21:34:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-16 21:34:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Ok, I pushed all the checks down to the NetworkManager. Review away!'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 21:43:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

You have some trailing whitespace on nova/tests/policy.json; other than that, this looks good.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-17 00:21:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-17 00:21:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-17 00:24:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

So this really needs to be loading the network objects and passing them in to the enforce call.  Unfortunately that is going to be a more extensive set of changes, so I'm ok with it going in like this for now."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-17 16:43:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-17 17:13:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful

commit_message:
Updates linux_net to ignore some shell errors

 * Allows exit 254 from ip add and ip del
 * Allows exit 7 from route add and route del
 * These exit codes means the ip/route already existed or was
   already removed
 * Fixes bug 915556

Change-Id: Ib71da2351372f3c7e3558cf5b3e9f55e10681875

[{'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-01 22:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-11-01 22:48:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This actually looks good. But without having anything to identify the service type or name in the schema for a capability, I would like to see some use cases clearly documented to get comfortable that this is a sufficient schema for capabilities. However, I think we can start with this and iterates on it.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-01 22:50:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

@Yogi: Just putting this out there for you, in case you want to review/revise. I think RBAC work should probably occur in it's own branch though, and merge all at once near the end of next week."}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2011-11-02 00:39:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

nit: you misspelled "resource" in the WADL comments.

this base set of description doesn't allow for a capability to ever be removed and/or deprecated.

I think this would make a lot more sense with the linkages all listed and available for mapping users+tenant -> roles -> capabilities -> service endpoint.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-02 00:45:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Ziad: Since there's no other context here, I guess it's worth pointing out that Capabilities map to Roles (Capability <-- RoleCapabilities --> Roles) and Roles map to Services (Role --> Service). So, Services have many Roles, and Roles have many Capabilities. Not that this solves every use case :)

We also don't have a business case for listing *all* Capabilities (GET /capabilities) -- until we do, I don't see why we're supporting it."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-02 01:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-02 01:22:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

@Joe: I call your nit and raise you a review: https://review.openstack.org/1248

Also, can you expand your discussion points? (and feel free to take it to the mailing list - this deserves a much wider audience!)

Also, for reference: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/rbac-keystone"}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-02 15:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not submit

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-16 23:10:50.000000000', 'message': 'Bug #894683: nova.service does not handle attribute specific exceptions and client hangs

As Sateesh points out nova.service.Service.__getattr__ throws an AttributeError exception when the upcall method is not available.

However nova.rpc should catch all exceptions. This does not happen in this specific case because the following statement was outside the try-catch-all:

node_func = getattr(self.proxy, str(method))

(cherry picked from commit 421e5cb2b4a3f1b5a8db58543b9cd96df62e9599)

Change-Id: I437c88783bca037e4054078d2687ef41c8fc2b83
'}]
commit_message:
Bug #894683: nova.service does not handle attribute specific exceptions and client hangs

As Sateesh points out nova.service.Service.__getattr__ throws an AttributeError exception when the upcall method is not available.

However nova.rpc should catch all exceptions. This does not happen in this specific case because the following statement was outside the try-catch-all:

node_func = getattr(self.proxy, str(method))

(cherry picked from commit 421e5cb2b4a3f1b5a8db58543b9cd96df62e9599)

Change-Id: I437c88783bca037e4054078d2687ef41c8fc2b83

YAMLed cli output.
We now let templatization of the command line output with bottlepy's templating

Change-Id: I035d9ec8834da4a912475b29419a1d5c91202316

commit_message:
Moved client code from main melange repo.

Implements blueprint melange-client-repo
Changed cli tests to not depend on server-side models.
YAMLed cli output.
We now let templatization of the command line output with bottlepy's templating

Change-Id: I035d9ec8834da4a912475b29419a1d5c91202316

[{'created': '2012-01-16 22:58:07.000000000', 'message': "Fixes incorrect URI scheme for s3 backend

Fixes bug #912094.

URI scheme for s3 backend should be 's3+https', not 'swift+https'.

Use s3.amazonaws.com instead of s3service.com to follow RFC2606.

Indent reason for BadStoreUri exception in s3.py.

Comments added for the following option in etc/glance-api.conf
    's3_store_host'

(cherry picked from commit d466cec3576b12c61491c75c43ec2d839072890e)

Change-Id: Id456b287d82fe61711f0d738e61ccb599f0b5684
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes incorrect URI scheme for s3 backend

Fixes bug #912094.

URI scheme for s3 backend should be 's3+https', not 'swift+https'.

Use s3.amazonaws.com instead of s3service.com to follow RFC2606.

Indent reason for BadStoreUri exception in s3.py.

Comments added for the following option in etc/glance-api.conf
    's3_store_host'

(cherry picked from commit d466cec3576b12c61491c75c43ec2d839072890e)

Change-Id: Id456b287d82fe61711f0d738e61ccb599f0b5684

commit_message:
Fix some cfg test case naming conflicts

As pointed out by Vish, there are duplicates of:

  OverridesTestCase::test_default_override
  OverridesTestCase::test_override
  SadPathTestCase::test_conf_file_not_found

Also, rename the ConfigFileOptsTestCase so it is obvious they
don't clash with the tests by the same name in CliOptsTestCase.

Change-Id: I5cda3c4796b98eaf0e99589579d0b3bceaf9cd8b

commit_message:
Remove 'location' from GlanceImageService

Glance no longer returns location through its public API, so we
should not attempt to display it. Addresses bug 911599.

(cherry picked from commit 3e015b869789c7aeeb90e160ede3b3a7b7921f30)

Change-Id: I3400006eb6ab94095c0c2d2b5dc90cb9b7775a84

subject: Prefixing the request id with 'req-' to decrease confusion when looking at logs.
messages:
[{'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-12 17:29:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think this change will help reduce confusion when looking at logs. Before this change, the request id in the logs was just a uuid. By prefixing the uuid with 'req-', it is immediately apparent that the uuid represents a request id. I got the idea from swift. Note that their equivalent of request ids (trans id) is prefixed with tx:
https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/middleware/catch_errors.py"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-12 18:08:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

seems reasonable.  While you are in there, can you switch it to use utils.get_uuid() instead?'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-12 22:35:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-12 22:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

subject: Add ipv4 and ipv6 validation
messages:
[{'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-01-16 15:36:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This logic should be in the IPAM and not servers.py"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-01-16 15:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

accessIPv4 and accessIPv6 are just metadata so they at least need to be validated when doing a simple update.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 17:19:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I agree with Alex on this one.'}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-01-16 17:42:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

How do we know the IP is valid for the network this instance will be plugged into? I'm arguing that this check is a false sense of security because it caches a small part of the errors that will occur with this data."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-16 17:45:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is a user-defined field. We don't have to know about the IP internally for a user to place it in the accessIP fields. It could be an external loadbalancer or something like that..."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-16 17:54:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It isn't clear to me that the accessIP fields have to be a single IP. Since it's a user-defined field, we should expect our users to try to send a list or json blob. Maybe we need to update the docs to be more specific?"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-01-16 18:31:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree, this does need to be spelled out somewhere'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-17 08:04:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-17 08:15:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-16 23:11:04.000000000', 'message': "nova-manage floating ip fixes

* Add pool, interface to 'floating list' output
  These columns were added to the floating_ips table in
  https://review.openstack.org/2892 and are not visible elsewhere
* Fix 'floating delete' to skip network/broadcast addresses
  Makes the delete command match the create command behaviour
  introduced in https://review.openstack.org/2663
* Address changes listed in bug 817281
  Change host column in output to project ID, change hostname
  column to uuid

(cherry picked from commit 9e21a2228c191896223daae2379fcf1352cc736c)

Change-Id: Ibbfbe9ed5543927a6b2a1e676f5617901a32f897
"}]
commit_message:
nova-manage floating ip fixes

* Add pool, interface to 'floating list' output
  These columns were added to the floating_ips table in
  https://review.openstack.org/2892 and are not visible elsewhere
* Fix 'floating delete' to skip network/broadcast addresses
  Makes the delete command match the create command behaviour
  introduced in https://review.openstack.org/2663
* Address changes listed in bug 817281
  Change host column in output to project ID, change hostname
  column to uuid

(cherry picked from commit 9e21a2228c191896223daae2379fcf1352cc736c)

Change-Id: Ibbfbe9ed5543927a6b2a1e676f5617901a32f897

commit_message:
Base version.py on glance.

This makes setting and calculating the versioning of quantum more
like other OpenStack projects, simplifying the work of the CI
and Release Management teams.

Addresses bug 916018 which prevents the quantum-tarball job from
running correctly.

Change-Id: I5b006ccc3d31c5d213c703853dfa38f04d983918

subject: Fix for lp907123
messages:
[{'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-17 04:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I agree with Dan we should probably update the client library as well; however if we don't do it, that won't break the client, see the following code snippet:

if res.status in EXCEPTIONS:
    raise EXCEPTIONS[res.status](**exception_args)
# Add error code and message to exception arguments
ex = Exception("Server returned error: %s" % status_code)
               ex.args = ([dict(status_code=status_code,
                                 message=error_message)],)

Also, it seems we should just add the 441 exception to the EXCEPTIONS list.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-17 04:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Brad, I think the plan is to temporarily abandon this review until we get the new HTTP error code changes in, is that correct?'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-17 04:23:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

I think you missed a spot in quantum/client/__init__.py where the HTTP error codes are called out.  I don't see 421 in there.  

Also, if you're introducing a new error code, we have to modify the docbook spec as well, which raises the question of whether we should be returning an error code that wasn't included in the v1.0 API spec.  Perhaps this an argument for using more standard error codes?  

I'm not sure what the best way forward is with this one.  Perhaps use a more standard error code?  Or an existing error code?"}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2012-01-17 04:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good Job!'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-01-17 04:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Yup'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-17 04:23:07.000000000', 'message': "Fix for lp907123

This adds a new exception (InvalidAttachment) which can be thrown if the
attachment-id passed into attach_resource is invalid.  Currently we don't do
any validation checking so the plugin will have to determine whether or not it
is a valid attachment id.

Change-Id: Ibb799813c609db23000a35c545514c80bcf829e9
"}]
commit_message:
Fix for lp907123

This adds a new exception (InvalidAttachment) which can be thrown if the
attachment-id passed into attach_resource is invalid.  Currently we don't do
any validation checking so the plugin will have to determine whether or not it
is a valid attachment id.

Change-Id: Ibb799813c609db23000a35c545514c80bcf829e9

commit_message:
add a flag to fix mouse cursor problem.

fixed bug #885966

add a flag FLAGS.use_usb_tablet to libvirt.xml.template to slove
the problem in cases when the virtual and real mouse cursors are
not syncronized using vnc to access windows xp instances.

Change-Id: Ife47f0d803df9c00c8bdbbeb57fee9abcd3c8fe8

commit_message:
fixed bug lp:885966

add a flag FLAGS.use_usb_tablet to libvirt.xml.template to slove
the problem in cases when the virtual and real mouse cursors are
not syncronized using vncviewer or through websocket to access
windows virtual machine.

Change-Id: I5d3a712776479f7acb792e8b8f33260f6302ccc5

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-16 23:46:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix several issues with devstack and Quantum + OVS plugin

- flag telling nova quantum manager to use DHCP is incorrect
- OVS quantum plugin no longer has default sql_connection string.
- only run quantum OVS agent is openvswitch is enabled
- add ovs-vsctl to sudoers file.

Change-Id: I1e9b3fe987b3e29d0d4f670b2d964777d9cc3e1b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix several issues with devstack and Quantum + OVS plugin

- flag telling nova quantum manager to use DHCP is incorrect
- OVS quantum plugin no longer has default sql_connection string.
- only run quantum OVS agent is openvswitch is enabled
- add ovs-vsctl to sudoers file.

Change-Id: I1e9b3fe987b3e29d0d4f670b2d964777d9cc3e1b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-03 16:20:12.000000000', 'message': "Clean FloatingIPDNS resource

create() and get() are not needed here :
 - it's not the role of the resource to call 'create'.
 - 'get' is here to refresh the resource. There's no mean to retrieve
 for sure the resource (get by IP address *or* by name only).

Change-Id: I97f4c26264b4abd0c1c8cdd91acc23ab6d6d008e
"}]
commit_message:
Clean FloatingIPDNS resource

create() and get() are not needed here :
 - it's not the role of the resource to call 'create'.
 - 'get' is here to refresh the resource. There's no mean to retrieve
 for sure the resource (get by IP address *or* by name only).

Change-Id: I97f4c26264b4abd0c1c8cdd91acc23ab6d6d008e

commit_message:
Update some extensions (1)

Updates the following extensions to conform to new interfaces:

    * admin_actions (AdminActions)
    * console_output (Console_output)
    * deferred_delete (DeferredDelete)
    * floating_ips (Floating_ips)
    * multinic (NMN)
    * rescue (Rescue)
    * security_groups (SecurityGroups)

Related to blueprint extension-refactor.

Change-Id: Ica7b44db22835971703cc72d831410d7e7660f1d

commit_message:
Fixes LP Bug#913608 - tests should be isolated

This reworks the stubs.FAKE_FILESYSTEM_ROOTDIR used in unit
tests by making each test case create and destroy its own little
sandbox in /tmp/test.*/images. Adds a base IsolatedUnitTest that
tests needing to have an isolated filesystem_store_datadir and
configuration can inherit from.

Change-Id: I396f5127c6a687da8dcef3368e7ed0912efc9b3a

that raise.

commit_message:
Modify the fake ldap driver to fix compatibility.

The fake implementation was raising an exception during a failed
search_s where the normal python ldap module does not.  So, removed
that raise.

Also added a modrdn_s implementation because I need it for a network test.

(Indirectly) for blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: Ia86a776afe19ffce72b285bb4c96ce3ed0ae7c4a

subject: Refactoring logging _log function.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 998, 'name': 'Naveed Massjouni', 'email': 'naveedm9@gmail.com', 'username': 'ironcamel'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-12 20:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-12 20:32:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Heaven knows I'm a big proponent of decorators, but I don't think we need to use one within the logging class here.  If we're going to override the methods, let's override the methods—create a method that does the transformations that the decorator does, then call it explicitly from within each of the level-specific functions (not to mention from within an override of the log() method).

Also, don't forget the aliases of level-specific methods, such as warn() or fatal(); I know for a fact that most warnings in nova are issued using the warn() method rather than warning().

(All in all, overriding _log() still seems like the best idea, given all the details!)"}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-12 21:17:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-12 21:31:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kevin, I have no problem with replacing the decorator with a method. That was actually the way I did my first implementation. I thought the decorator made more sense, but I don't have a strong opinion on this.

So far it seems that you and Vish prefer the original implementation where we are overriding the private Logger._log() method. This violates the basic concept of encapsulation and seems horrible to me, but I will defer to the wishes of the core devs and leave it as it is. Let me know if you guys change your minds. Then I would be glad to address the outstanding issues."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-01-13 19:47:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I disagree with Vish and Vek. We absolutely should not be overriding private methods. 

But especially in this case since _log is not documented anywhere and causes the code in log.py to be confusing. There is no guarantee that logging._log will not be changed to behave differently in the future.


Also, does anyone know what the point of having 'audit' is? Based on where it's used we should just be using warn and info depending."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-13 19:59:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To be fair, I only said (or at least intended to say!) that overriding _log() is the simplest way, given the amount of work that needs to be done otherwise.  We could just as easily replace our _log() with a new internal method that calls log() (not _log()) directly but handles all the context processing, then repoint error(), warning(), etc. to call it…'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-01-13 20:08:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well I think it's safer to let debug call it's parent debug, etc. Since we don't know what else the parent debug may be doing."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-13 22:35:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

I'm with Naveed and Alex.  I don't like overriding _log() when it is really not meant to be a public interface.  I realize python allows you to do this, but it feels bad to me as well.  I would just fix up the warn/fatal cases, etc."}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-13 22:54:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-13 23:07:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

One minor in-line comment, but it's not at all a blocker."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-13 23:12:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I guess I'm fine with this.  I still have no problem overriding _ methods in classes because I interpret them in my head as being protected, not private. But I don't have a problem with this version."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-13 23:31:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/478/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/896/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/509/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2272/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-14 01:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Failure is here:

_log() got an unexpected keyword argument 'context'#012(nova.api.openstack.wsgi): TRACE: Traceback (most recent call last):#012(nova.api.openstack.wsgi): TRACE:   File "/opt/stack/nova/nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py", line 1016, in __call__#012(nova.api.openstack.wsgi): TRACE:     action_result = self.dispatch(meth, request, action_args)#012(nova.api.openstack.wsgi): TRACE:   File "/opt/stack/nova/nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py", line 1089, in 

Looks like you need a del kwargs['context'] in the update_context method if it exists.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-14 01:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Refactoring logging _log function.

We should not be overriding private functions of core python modules.
Fixes bug: 915597

commit_message:
Add support for port security to QuantumManager

If enabled, QuantumManager will now pass in the allowed_address_pairs that
some quantum plugins understand in order to enforce port security on a
given port.  Any plugins that don't understand the extra fields will just
ignore them.

Change-Id: I640658036789b319ecefbb5e7dcdcf6b4f4ab34e

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-16 15:19:17.000000000', 'message': 'Set correct Content-Length on cached remote images

Override the image metadata size attribute with the actual
cached image file size when setting the Content-Length header
on the response to a GET of a cache remote image.

This avoids an non-initial GET on a remote image failing when
caching is enabled, as described in this bug:

  https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/900959

Change-Id: I7656bc971d982cce78ce1ed4cf7ea509f8bbdfa8
'}, {'created': '2012-01-16 16:14:38.000000000', 'message': 'Set correct Content-Length on cached remote images

Override the image metadata size attribute with the actual
cached image file size when setting the Content-Length header

commit_message:
Set correct Content-Length on cached remote images

Override the image metadata size attribute with the actual
cached image file size when setting the Content-Length header
on the response to a GET of a cache remote image.

This avoids an non-initial GET on a remote image failing when
caching is enabled, as described in this bug:

  Bug 900959

Change-Id: I7656bc971d982cce78ce1ed4cf7ea509f8bbdfa8

[{'created': '2012-01-16 18:08:06.000000000', 'message': 'Moved authorized_tenants retrieval to middleware.

Fixes bug 917263. By moving the tenant API call from the context
processor to the middleware the API call is no longer made
multiple times per request/response cycle.

Additionally, there are various PEP8 fixes included, with the
addition of one "ignore" flag to the PEP8 runner (related to
github issue #34 for pep8.py).

Change-Id: I5c755dfe381b1c38dbeeb99eb2b7ed9172d16f86
'}]
commit_message:
Moved authorized_tenants retrieval to middleware.

Fixes bug 917263. By moving the tenant API call from the context
processor to the middleware the API call is no longer made
multiple times per request/response cycle.

Additionally, there are various PEP8 fixes included, with the
addition of one "ignore" flag to the PEP8 runner (related to
github issue #34 for pep8.py).

Change-Id: I5c755dfe381b1c38dbeeb99eb2b7ed9172d16f86

commit_message:
Increase robustness of image filtering by server

* fix bug 912837
* fix bug 912927
* filter images based on instance_uuid rather than instance_ref
* stop adding instance_ref to snapshot properties

Change-Id: I5eed1611b1e885553d0c91380e414e9476dc251c

commit_message:
pip-requires: Document dep list

Add some comments indicating where deps are actually used (I was initially
confused looking at this list until a realized a lot of these are pulled
in to satisfy glance).

Additionally remove django-registration, since current code doesn't seem
to use it.

Change-Id: I9d9bbd76b73aee63ca8dd72f061f0aeae12a58dd

So it would appear this is a bug in devstack. When it creates the network it does not specify the project_id, so it is set to none, however when accessing nova it has a project_id in the context, so the check to only allow access to the network if the project_id in the db equals the project_id in the context fails and doesn't return any networks."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-14 04:56:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-14 04:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

So apparantly flatdhcp is supposed to work without a project even if a project is specified, so this patch makes sure that flatdhcp passes an admin context to network_get.

Also found one more backref that was hiding from my searches.

This *should* pass the devstack test, it atleast did on my cloudserver.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-14 05:01:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Implement BP untie-nova-network-models

Fixes LP853979
Remove the FK references for network data.
Remove unused db functions that used the FK's
Update db functions to not joinload
Update notification to optionally take network_info if compute has it
Update EC2 Api to use the network cache, falling back to rpc.call
Remove test_instance_get_project_vpn_joins which tests calls not used

Change-Id: I1a01ccc5ebcf7efeafe014af62be893325bb0825

[{'created': '2012-01-05 23:49:39.000000000', 'message': 'Make Interface.find_or_configure more generic

find_or_configure would raise if the interface was
created with a device_id, but a subsequent
find_or_configure only had vif_id. This also makes
the InterfaceIpAllocationsController not pass None
as the device_id when the device_id is not 
specified.

Change-Id: Ib2079e8904dc794456cad9b2618aa252b58f2970'}]
commit_message:
Make Interface.find_or_configure more generic

find_or_configure would raise if the interface was
created with a device_id, but a subsequent
find_or_configure only had vif_id. This also makes
the InterfaceIpAllocationsController not pass None
as the device_id when the device_id is not 
specified.

Change-Id: Ib2079e8904dc794456cad9b2618aa252b58f2970

Remove compute.api.API.add_network_to_project

if you need similar functionality.

commit_message:
Remove extra swift delete_object call

This only tries to delete the manifest once when deleting an image
stored (chunked) in swift. Fixes bug 903768.

(cherry picked from commit c06242382e4de3afb67f198f86cdab76c49b00fa)

Change-Id: I65b8f3389e9965a111c4e774f4d1b6f7bbe71a9b

commit_message:
Create an instance DNS record based on instance UUID.

Previously we created one based on instance name only.  Since
name is not guaranteed to be unique, best to have one based
on uuid as well.  Both point to the same address, of course.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: Ibb17f2a49f00b4522205d6b4508f432f6f5b0c5d

commit_message:
Refactor request and action extensions.

The goal of this refactoring is to eventually eliminate
ExtensionMiddleware and LazySerializationMiddleware completely, by
executing extensions directly within the processing done by
Resource.__call__().  This patch implements the infrastructure
required to perform this extension processing.

Implements blueprint extension-refactor.

Change-Id: I23398fc906a9a105de354a8133337ecfc69a3ad3

One last comment, I swear! It looks like the cloudpipe and deferred delete extension test modules were left behind in the old v2 path when you did a rebase. You'll need to make sure they are moved."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-13 13:10:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Approved

Hi Anthony, what's the plan for documenting volume functionality changes?"}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-13 17:07:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-13 17:14:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Brian - I renamed the v2 tests that I missed, and updated the integrated tests for the new endpoint.  I had to remove the attach/detach tests, as that requires both compute and volume endpoints to be used for the same test and the integrated tests are not presently architected to do that.

For now, I think we should leave the old volumes extension in place since there is presently no client for the new api.  We're going to have to spend some time figuring out how to adapt python-novaclient to deal with the new api endpoint.

Anne - as for your documentation question - I expect that we will need to do some massaging of this api between now and essex release.  But by that time we should definitely get this documented.  What is the current recommend way to document this?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-13 18:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Implements blueprint separate-nova-volumeapi

 * Moves openstack/v2 directory to compute and fixes tests accordingly
 * Moves some code from api/openstack/compute to shared location, for use by volume api
 * Implements basic volume functionality for types, volumes, and snapshots
 * Changes service name from osapi to osapi_compute (and adds osapi_volume)
 * Renames nova-api-os to nova-api-os-compute, adds nove-api-os-volume
 * Separate extension mechanism for compute and volume
 ** Removes flag osapi_extension and replaces with osapi_compute_extension and osapi_volume_extension
 * Updates the paste config
 * Fixes setup.py to include nova-os-api-compute and nova-os-api-volume
 * Fix bug in volume version code that occurred as result of trunk merge
 * Update integrated/test_volumes.py to use new endpoint

Change-Id: I4c2e57c3cafd4e1a9e2ff3ce201c8cf28326afcd

commit_message:
Implement more complete kombu reconnecting

Fixes bug 888621

We were missing some wrapping around when consumers are declared and
a case where we had an exception we weren't trapping.  In the latter
case, it's not easy to trap it because you'd have to bypass the kombu
interface and import amqplib and try to trap one of its exceptions.
What I've implemented here looks for 'timeout' in any exception, even
though I really don't like it. :)

Fixes HACKING violations while I'm at it.

Change-Id: I0132fbc4377e221b0a366d0340652147ddb33c87

subject: Update load_images recipe to load image via redirection and not pipe.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-29 18:43:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Why do you hate on pipe?  It saves disk I/O!  Just curious what the problem is with the old way.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-12-29 18:48:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yeah, I'm not fully sure I understand why I did it either... as per Jay's suggestion here (https://review.openstack.org/#change,2569)

"""
FYI, this really is not the way that images should be uploaded to Glance. The image file should be redirected to glance add, not piped in. The difference between piping and redirection is that in the latter case, an fseek(SEEK_END) will work, while it will not on the former, leading to problems with unknown content lengths.
"""

We haven't seen issues with unknown content lengths (that I know of) so any ideas? Maybe we should leave it like it is?'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-29 19:00:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah, interesting.  Well, what he says is true.  However, figuring out content length by seeking to the end seems not quite right to me.  I'd figure you'd read in the full data and set content length based on number of bytes read."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-30 21:13:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm, thx Brian.

Chris, for some background on why we need to calculate the size of the image file *before* we start communicating with Glance, see here:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/794718

Cheerio :)
-jay'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-01-13 17:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-13 17:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/openstack-chef/51/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-13 17:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-12 04:35:39.000000000', 'message': 'Return correct href if bind_host is 0.0.0.0.

The existing code returns incorrect href= in the root document (aka
"version" document) if the default configuration is used. If a remote
system accesses Glance API, the netspec of href= contains 0.0.0.0,
which cannot be used for further remote accesses. This happens because
attempts to use local configuration or the bind address to reconstruct
URLs are futile.

The correct way resolve this problem is to use the Host: header
of the HTTP request. As a bonus, it works with IPv6, should we ever
support it.

Change-Id: I661351b679c695bd6ab310104a3246dd3069f9c6
'}, {'created': '2012-01-12 21:17:25.000000000', 'message': 'Return correct href if bind_host is 0.0.0.0.

"version" document) if the default configuration is used. If a remote
system accesses Glance API, the netspec of href= contains 0.0.0.0,
which cannot be used for further remote accesses. This happens because
attempts to use local configuration or the bind address to reconstruct
URLs are futile.

The correct way resolve this problem is to use the Host: header
of the HTTP request. As a bonus, it works with IPv6, should we ever
support it.

Change-Id: I661351b679c695bd6ab310104a3246dd3069f9c6
Bug: 911599
'}, {'created': '2012-01-12 21:18:17.000000000', 'message': 'Return correct href if bind_host is 0.0.0.0.

The existing code returns incorrect href= in the root document (aka
"version" document) if the default configuration is used. If a remote
system accesses Glance API, the netspec of href= contains 0.0.0.0,
which cannot be used for further remote accesses. This happens because
attempts to use local configuration or the bind address to reconstruct
URLs are futile.

The correct way resolve this problem is to use the Host: header
of the HTTP request. As a bonus, it works with IPv6, should we ever
support it.

Change-Id: I661351b679c695bd6ab310104a3246dd3069f9c6
Bug: 915621
'}]
commit_message:
Return correct href if bind_host is 0.0.0.0.

The existing code returns incorrect href= in the root document (aka
"version" document) if the default configuration is used. If a remote
system accesses Glance API, the netspec of href= contains 0.0.0.0,
which cannot be used for further remote accesses. This happens because
attempts to use local configuration or the bind address to reconstruct
URLs are futile.

The correct way resolve this problem is to use the Host: header
of the HTTP request. As a bonus, it works with IPv6, should we ever
support it.

Change-Id: I661351b679c695bd6ab310104a3246dd3069f9c6
Bug: 915621

commit_message:
Centralized error handling.

Implements blueprint exception-handling.

This takes care of a first-pass implementation at reusable,
consistent, centralized error handling.

It is known to be incomplete as far as the "recognized" exception
types. It needs to be expanded over time as it is further
put into real use and tested. This is only a starting point.

Change-Id: If19e7c1414456f1be69ad867995f46368749a9e9

subject: Added HP-IDM extension.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 5, 'name': 'Ziad Sawalha', 'email': 'ziad.sawalha@rackspace.com', 'username': 'ziad-sawalha'}, {'_account_id': 143, 'name': 'Jorge L. Williams', 'email': 'jorge.williams@rackspace.com', 'username': 'jorgew'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-01-04 15:25:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-01-10 16:44:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 17:29:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Why are we shipping our specs with vendor-specific extensions? If it's in the openstack repos it should be owned by the community (be prefixed with OS-)"}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:26:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I spoke with the Keystone team about this.  They decided that it made sense to store common vendor extensions in a single repo.  They've been doing this for RAX extensions for a while."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-01-11 22:17:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

On that topic, I very much disagree that it "makes sense," but we don't have much choice at the moment because keystone "extensions" aren't pluggable at all - they're just implemented alongside keystone core.

On topic: New files contain a mix of tabs & spaces; see inline question about PDF.'}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-01-12 15:38:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-01-12 15:51:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I think I got all the whitespace issues fixed on this one.

Dolph,  I have the same concern that you do about linking directly to github.  In fact, I brought this up as an issue when we met on Monday.

We have several options to resolving the problem, including maintaining branches on github or sourcing the artifacts in the extension registry.  The long term solution is that we are making changes to doc tool chain so that it can auto-magically resolve those links from the extension registry without a lot of work on our part.  That feature isn't available yet though.

Unfortunately, the issue does not only affect this document, but all of the keystone extension specs and the core spec itself.   Fixing will involve changes all over the docs project and that will take some effort.

I believe that we decided on monday to under take that issue, and reconsider how are structuring these specs -- possibly after essex.  I owe you guys a blueprint on this.

In the meantime, we'll have to live with the github references.  I don't believe there's much chance of it breaking in the short term.

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2012-01-12 19:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-01-12 20:48:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-12 20:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/identity-api/8/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-12 20:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

subject: Adding policy.json for nova policy enforcement
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-12 20:43:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'd like to see us just add the default file to the packages that we install via Chef. That way any changes to the json policy file (in source code) won't have to be duplicated in Chef."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-12 20:45:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:57:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:
