Some of them I just added some comments without adding policy checks, and one I removed (as it didn't seem to be used by anything on the project). I'm open to returning that function I deleted if anybody objects."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-01-10 22:58:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

the network api function you added is bad, and also I can't see that you are using it anywhere."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-10 23:11:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Mostly great stuff. Agree with Trey, though, on his comment, and have a suggestion on the naming of the wrap_enforce decorator"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-10 23:32:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 23:42:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 23:42:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-10 23:52:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-10 23:53:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-01-11 00:15:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

-2 rescinded, but this isn't a full review. Thanks for fixing."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-11 01:12:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-11 02:17:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Questions inline I'd like answered first.  I do like this more generic approach."}, {'account_id': 927, 'date': '2012-01-11 03:14:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

These failed cause of this error:
Could not find config at /var/run/policy.json

Just wanted to make sure we definitely need this file, and that there isn't a way to get sane defaults - kind of guessing its just a new file that we need.

Does it belong in /etc/nova/ instead if it is required?  Seems a little generically named as is.  But it doesn't bother me."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-11 05:09:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

belongs in /etc/nova but looks in path for it as well via utils.find_config'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-11 17:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-11 17:28:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

Thanks for the help, guys. As for where policy.json lives: I've added it to openstack-chef for SmokeStack (correctly, I hope), but I'm not sure if the packages should ship with their own copies or just use what's in the source dir. Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-11 17:38:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Looks like 'compute:' is not prefixed for the target anymore now when you use the decorator in compute/api."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-11 17:54:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ok, Walrus pointed out what I missed.  I think I'm good now."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-11 18:59:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-11 22:01:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

When we use the policy.wrap_enforce, I'm not thrilled that the flow bounces from nova.policy to a seemingly arbitrary command elsewhere in the compute api, and then off to a json file. Its not that hard to understand once I read the whole change, but its still counter-intuitive and will be harder to understand in place without the help of the diff context.

Also, as far as I can tell, the only thing we're adding is "admin_or_owner" policies, and is it applied to all of the public methods on the compute api? This seems like a convoluted way to add

if not context['is_admin'] and not context['project_id'] == instance['project_id']:
   # bail!

Are we saying that the permissions should be deployer configured? At this level (just owner and admin) I don't buy that.

I realize you are trying to make the first steps towards a more robust authz system in openstack and I am sympathetic towards that goal. But here I feel the functionality increase is too small and simple to justify this large and robust a code increase.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-11 22:34:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Mark:

I originally had a more linear path through the decorator directly to nova.policy.enforce. However, in the places that I couldn't use the decorator I had to duplicate the formation of the prefixed action and the call to nova.policy. I felt it was cleaner to allow each individual api (including network and volume) define how it wanted to call nova.policy.enforce in a single place rather than littered throughout its methods. How would you prefer I do this as to make it more understandable? 

As for the level of functionality this adds: this is a step towards a goal. This individual patch is not trying to achieve that goal all at once. Yes, right now we only ship with admin_or_owner as the default policy, but those are just defaults that make sense for the time being. I see it as extremely powerful to allow deployers to customize how to control access to specific compute methods (for example you can restrict snapshots to admins or disallow everybody from resizing, etc). I don't understand what you see as being bad about that, and additionally why you think this is too large patch (>200 lines of code comprised of a decorator, calls to said decorator, and a config file)."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-11 23:19:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Mark:

The whole purpose of these changes is to allow rbac for nova.  This is something we had in the ec2 api from the beginning because it solves use cases for government enterprises that need to restrict certain actions like allocating floating ips.

The default rules are very simple, but the call to enforce is necessary so that role-based checking is possible.  The policy.json file can and should be changed for many enterprise deployments.  Features to horizon will be added to configure policy through dashboard, and keystone features will likely be added to administer policies through an API.  This is just the first step of throwing them into a .json file so that we have something until those features come around the bend.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-11 23:44:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I felt it was cleaner to allow each individual api
> (including network and volume) define how it wanted to call 
> nova.policy.enforce in a single place rather than littered 
> throughout its methods. How would you prefer I do this as to
> make it more understandable?

I agree this is cleaner. Its keeping the shared decorator that I don't like. The connection between the function decorated by policy.wrap_enforce and the class method enforce_policy seems too obfuscated to be justified by the small code-deduplication benefits.

It would be better to simply make compute_api::enforce_policy a decorator and use it.

> I see it as extremely powerful to allow deployers to customize how to 
> control access to specific compute methods (for example you can 
> restrict snapshots to admins or disallow everybody from resizing, 
> etc). I don't understand what you see as being bad about that, and 
> additionally why you think this is too large patch 

My feeling is that to justify the cost of a new deployer-facing interface (i.e. the config file), we should be more ambitious. Because of the documentation and deployer costs of making changes like this, I feel like we should plan to get from where we are to full RBAC in something like two or three jumps. With this approach to the interim-authz bp, the jump just seems too small--more like we would need 5-10 jumps.

I feel like any first step ought to break up the simplistic dichotomy between "regular user" and "super-admin". Maybe that is too much to land before the feature freeze, but then I just wonder if we should even be doing this.

Sorry--not trying to be a Debbie Downer. If we can make the case that deployers really need the feature of controlling what functions regular users (as an global amorphous class) have access to, then I'll relent.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-12 00:53:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-12 00:53:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I went ahead and pulled the decorator into nova.compute.api hoping to clear up any confusion. 

Would you feel better if instead of mapping compute api methods directly to rule names that we first organized a set of rules and applied them only where they make sense?

Did Vish's comment not address the motivation aspect of your concerns?"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-12 14:37:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This new version of the code seems more straightforward. Thanks!

So, I was a bit confused about how roles were determined. It is now clear to me that this config format and system would not have to change if keystone-like added more granularity to roles. I also now understand that it is on the auth system to break up those roles. That makes this policy system more powerful, so I'm on board."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-12 17:22:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-12 17:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/442/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/868/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/480/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2243/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-12 18:45:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-12 18:47:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Ok hopefully it passes devstack this time.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-12 18:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Changed 2 things:
1) the compute:get_all rule in etc/nova/policy.json is now []
2)  the get_all check_policy check now has a target with project_id and user_id'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-12 19:00:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

Build Successful

commit_message:
Add policy checks to Compute.API

 * Second step of blueprint interim-nova-authz-service
 * Adds policy.json to define policy
 * Add nova.policy.wrap_enforce decorator
 * wrap majority of compute api functions with wrap_enforce

Change-Id: If6702873db3249921f931a42e889ee7d0338e4b8

commit_message:
Created skeleton for the context middleware.

This commit creates a pass-through middleware for creating the context object that will
encapsulate internal auth information within keystone. It does nothing of substance; its
only purpose is to provide a way to update the conf files in devstack so that we can
introduce this middleware layer without requiring it to work.

Change-Id: I19da160d80402a4d75af4365a805ee44aeffc51c
bp: keystone-internal-authorization

Looks like there might be some pep8 violations in this proposal."}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2011-12-27 06:44:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2011-12-27 06:47:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-12-27 20:52:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

EC2 functionality/design/compliance driving changes in the OpenStack API is something I have a little issue with.

The OpenStack API v2.0 doesn't specify the ability to have SHUTOFF instances, so that would need to be added to the specification in a future version if/when approved. I honestly can't remember if we're driving the spec from the code or the code from the spec :)

From the current specification: "Servers contain a status attribute that can be used
as an indication of the current server state. Servers with an ACTIVE status are available for
use. Other possible values for the status attribute include: BUILD, REBUILD, SUSPENDED,
RESIZE, VERIFY_RESIZE, PASSWORD, REBOOT, HARD_REBOOT, DELETED, UNKNOWN,
and ERROR."

Either way I was pretty surprised to find the "Compute Manager" calling "driver.destroy" when handling "stop_instance" messages. This is the culprit IMO of the issue's your having, right?

Perhaps another solution would be to remove that logic from the compute manager and ensure when "stop_instance" is called...the instance is stopped and not deleted! The EC2 API and the OS API should be responsible for calling the correct compute API/manager methods, so if the EC2 specification has special logic for when/how an instance is deleted/not deleted that logic can live in the EC2 API alone and not increase the logic in the compute API/manager.

Does this make sense at all? If not feel free to message me on IRC (blamar on #openstack-dev on Freenode) and I can attempt to be more sane. :) Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-29 00:17:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I wasn't suggesting that we added a new api-visible state, but that we had an internal state difference.  It could still show up as shutdown to the api.  It just makes the state checking logic a lot cleaner for transitions.

We have to map actual states to display states in the apis anyway, so it seems better to have a richer internal state representation to simplify the transition logic even if it doesn't show in the api."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-29 00:19:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

That said, if this change seems more complicated, I'm ok with the other method of tracking via an extra boolean.   Brian, lets chat about this online tomorrow and post the results here."}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-01-10 19:43:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

After looking over this again after a long break (sorry!), all of your edits make sense to me. Can you update the migration number so we can test this and get it in? [{'created': '2011-12-16 11:15:23.000000000', 'message': "Unbreak start instance and fixes bug 905270

This patch fixes the bug 905270
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/905270

According to EC2 documentation, EBS-instances that initiated shutdown
 result in stopped state.  And then it can be started again.  (On the
 other hand non-EBS instance result in terminted when instance
 initiated shutdown)

However, the current nova case, the shutdowned instance always results
 in terminated status.  As related issues are
 - describe-instance-attribute instance_initiated_shutdown_behavior doesn't
   work correctly
 - instance attribute disable_api_termination isn't supported
 - stop instance was broken by the change set of the following.
   It needs unbreak.

  > commit eb03d47fecd3bfc24243da29ee01679b334a08fe
  >  Author: Vishvananda Ishaya <vishvananda@gmail.com>
  >  Date: Fri Sep 23 09:22:32 2011 -0700
  >
  >    Remove AoE, Clean up volume code
  >
  >     * Removes Ata Over Ethernet
  >     * Adds drivers to libvirt for volumes
  >     * Adds initialize_connection and terminate_connection to volume api
  >     * Passes connection info back through volume api
  >
  >  Change-Id: I1b1626f40bebe8466ab410fb174683293c7c474f

This patch
- unbreak start instance
- implement instance_initiated_shutdown_behavior and make it EC2 compatible
- implement disable_api_termination

commit_message:
Unbreak start instance and fixes bug 905270

This patch fixes the bug 905270
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/905270

According to EC2 documentation, EBS-instances that initiated shutdown
 result in stopped state.  And then it can be started again.  (On the
 other hand non-EBS instance result in terminted when instance
 initiated shutdown)

However, the current nova case, the shutdowned instance always results
 in terminated status.  As related issues are
 - describe-instance-attribute instance_initiated_shutdown_behavior doesn't
   work correctly
 - instance attribute disable_api_termination isn't supported
 - stop instance was broken by the change set of the following.
   It needs unbreak.

  > commit eb03d47fecd3bfc24243da29ee01679b334a08fe
  >  Author: Vishvananda Ishaya <vishvananda@gmail.com>
  >  Date: Fri Sep 23 09:22:32 2011 -0700
  >
  >    Remove AoE, Clean up volume code
  >
  >     * Removes Ata Over Ethernet
  >     * Adds drivers to libvirt for volumes
  >     * Adds initialize_connection and terminate_connection to volume api
  >     * Passes connection info back through volume api
  >
  >  Change-Id: I1b1626f40bebe8466ab410fb174683293c7c474f

This patch
- unbreak start instance
- implement instance_initiated_shutdown_behavior and make it EC2 compatible
- implement disable_api_termination

---
Changes 5 -> 6:
- fixes to catch up 26b7b9457a5899ecca93fd67d3879efcad4e4968

Changes 4 -> 5:
- HACKING compilance

Changes 3 -> 4:
- rebased to 4c5586a28fd7a085369c49f6039876ffdc86b526
  sqlalchemy migrate version

Changes 2 -> 3:
- rename long name to shorter one
  s/instance_initiated_shutdown_behavior/shutdown_terminate/g
  s/disable_api_termination/disable_terminate/g
  as suggested Kevin L. Mitchell
- improved nova.api.ec2.cloud._state_description
- pep8
- broken out patches are available for easy review at
  git://github.com/yamahata/nova.git lp905270-2

Changes 1 -> 2:
- fixed an unit test failure pointed out by Mark.
  (I think ebtabls failure strongly suggests installation problem)
- introduce vm_states.SHUTOFF and put instance state which is in
  power_state.{NOSTATE, SHUTOFF} into vm_states.SHUTOFF.
- simplified logic a bit by vm_states.SHUTOFF as suggested by Vish.
- instance_initiated_shutdown_behavior:String(255)
   =>
  instance_initiated_shutdown_terminate:Boolean()
  as suggested by Vish.
- Added Johannes Erdfelt to reviews as they written the vm_states state
  machine checker.
  I'd have liked to add David Subiros either, but he doesn't seem to be a
  registered user of the gerrit.

Change-Id: Ibeb94f65137feadad2c343913b39195e3f96a35e

subject: Add 'os-networks' extension
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1172, 'name': 'Nikolay Sokolov', 'email': 'nsokolov@griddynamics.com', 'username': 'chemikadze'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-10-06 13:47:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

I do like this, but there are a couple of things you need to address. One you can find in an inline comment. You also need to support xml, so adding some tests to verify it works would be awesome."}, {'account_id': 1172, 'date': '2011-11-03 08:32:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1172, 'date': '2011-11-03 09:04:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I have updated tests after changes in URLs in trunk (/v1.1/projid/os-networks instead of /v1.1/os-networks) and moved require_admin to extenstions.py.

Unfortunately, I mistakenly commited my update as new change and not sure what to do in that situation.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-03 13:27:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Nikolay: 

First, you should abandon the new review. Next, you need to do a 'git rebase -i' and 'squash' the new commit into the first. After you do that, you can 'git review' again. See http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritWorkflow if you need a more in-depth explanation."}, {'account_id': 1172, 'date': '2011-11-03 15:57:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1172, 'date': '2011-11-03 15:59:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1172, 'date': '2011-11-03 16:01:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Uploaded changes, fixed functools issue.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-03 17:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

You need to add your email address to Authors.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-03 17:33:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

You also have the following pep8 error:

nova/tests/api/openstack/contrib/test_networks.py:224:80: E501 line too long (80 characters)
        req = webob.Request.blank('/v1.1/1234/os-networks/12345')  # not present
                                                                               ^
    Limit all lines to a maximum of 79 characters.

    There are still many devices around that are limited to 80 character
    lines; plus, limiting windows to 80 characters makes it possible to have
    several windows side-by-side.  The default wrapping on such devices looks
    ugly.  Therefore, please limit all lines to a maximum of 79 characters.
    For flowing long blocks of text (docstrings or comments), limiting the
    length to 72 characters is recommended."}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-11-10 15:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Have any of the API dudes signed off on this?'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-10 15:13:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Soren: it's just an extension so we don't really need to sign off on anything."}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-11-10 15:49:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Well, we're accepting it into Nova proper (albeit as an extension). It seems in everyone's best interest to have the API be widely agreed upon to make the transition to core be more seamless once we decide to go that route."}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-11-18 08:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm confused by this.

You say you're porting and extension from openstackx. To the best of my knowledge, openstackx is a client library. How can you port an extension from a client library? Is there another "openstackx" that I do not know about? Can you please provide a link?

Also, please remove the "migrated from bazaar" bit from your commit message. It's insignificant, and will only be confusing in the Nova changelog.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-18 17:27:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Soren: 
OpenstackX actually has some extensions that the dashboard depends on: https://github.com/cloudbuilders/openstackx/blob/master/extensions/admin.py. We are in the process of moving the last ones into Nova.'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-11-18 17:31:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Well, if that's indeed where it comes from, you shoulnd't claim copyright over it. Clearly someone else wrote it (or is the copyright designation in openstackx wrong?)."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-18 17:40:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

This seems to be a different implementation of similar functionality, covering what is already available in openstackx. It's not anywhere close to a direct port."}, {'account_id': 1172, 'date': '2011-11-18 19:41:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

1. I wrote original openstackx extension https://github.com/cloudbuilders/openstackx/pull/13
2. There is long blah-blah-blah thread about what i am doing wrong and this extention has no way to land in nova https://code.launchpad.net/~chemikadze/nova/contrib-extention-networks/+merge/72204
3. This extension is the result of core team recomendations, what do you want else?

I am bored with buerracy around this tiny little class taking 50000% of time I spend writing it.'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-11-18 20:36:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Hey, if you wrote both the old and the new implementation, no worries.

All I can see is what the commit message says: "ported [...] from openstackx" and when I look at the corresponding code in openstackx, someone else holds the copyright. It just looked weird, but clearly everything is fine.

If you could just clarify this somewhere (preferably in the commit message), hopefully some of the people who told you to port this will get around to reviewing the code.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 09:27:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Agree with Soren, we need a more descriptive commit message.

Also, the patch needs rebasing onto latest master - needs moving to the new nova/api/openstack/v2/contrib dir

And I don't think the @require_admin decorator is needed. No other APIs have this and the @require_admin_contect on all the DB level APIs should be sufficient"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-19 20:58:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Ok, I'm just going to pick this up and run with it if we don't hear back from Nikolay within a few days."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-26 16:49:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-26 16:50:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I went ahead and rewrote this patch. It now uses network api calls to get the necessary information rather than speaking to the db directly. Please re-review!'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-29 08:54:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Does get_network() and disassociate_network() work for quantum manager?  I see that quantum manager will override the get_all_networks() call you added, so that one is fine.

This looks good... I just don't know the answer to the above question due to lack of quantum manager knowledge."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-03 15:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

So I looked into what you said, comstud, and I realized I have absolutely no idea how the quantam manager works. Maybe somebody with a better understanding can comment on this?'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-12 01:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Ok, seems like nobody wants to look at this... comstud, what say you?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-12 17:41:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I think this is fine as is.  disassociate may not work with quantum, but we can throw a bug in there and have brad hall look at it.  If i read the code correctly, it is actually ipam that is maintaining the associations, and it may require deleting and recreating a quantum network to do it properly.  Seems like it can be fixed later though.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-12 17:49:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Bug #904830: use type==object-store instead of name==swift from service catalog

The name field in the service catalog is an operator-specified, marketing name.
The type field contains the canonical name for the service (i.e., swift is
object-store).

Change-Id: I8556b3e6fddd8784f259170195352478d9c6ae32

commit_message:
catch InstanceInvalidState in more places

Further fixes to bug 911879

500s or 400s are returned in the OS API when actions are denied due
to being in an invalid state.  409 should be returned, instead.  A
previous review (2846) fixed the delete case and this fixes more.

When writing tests, I found a number of exceptions that are not raised
anymore, and they were being incorrectly used in tests still.  I fixed
those up.

Change-Id: I0d5b1ed52e0cc9766be8e2a7de84c8601f4bdf26

commit_message:
Fix some cfg test case naming conflicts

As pointed out by Vish, there are duplicates of:

  OverridesTestCase::test_default_override
  OverridesTestCase::test_override
  SadPathTestCase::test_conf_file_not_found

Also, rename the ConfigFileOptsTestCase so it is obvious they
don't clash with the tests by the same name in CliOptsTestCase.

Change-Id: I1d650d05d32501623cfed8f0b6399858d101ae02

commit_message:
Add notifications for sending an image

An image.send notification is to be sent to the notifier every time an image is
transmitted from glance. This can be used to track things such as bandwidth
usage.

Addresses bug 914440

Change-Id: If8b6504c4250fa6444d17d611de43d9704ca9aae

subject: blueprint progressbar-upload-image
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-09 15:28:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(9 inline comments)

Hi Reynolds!

This is really interesting and innovative code, thank you!

There's a few little style nits inline to address, but the only big thing I want to see changed is making the progress bar calls optional in the Client class.

One way you could do this is by subclassing glance.client.Client into a specialization class called glance.client.ProgressClient and overriding the add_image() method to add the progress bar calls. That way you could import glance.client.ProgressClient in bin/glance and you would not affect other programs that need a non-interactive client or one that does not operate within a TTY.

Make sense?
-jay"}, {'account_id': 1427, 'date': '2012-01-12 10:14:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

misuse of git'}]

messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:35:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Seeing some unit test failures on this one:

TypeError: list indices must be integers, not str

http://paste.openstack.org/show/3634/'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-14 11:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-14 14:24:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The latest Xen run is showing some of the following errors:

KeyError: 'get_connection'"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-14 15:25:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Dan!
I noticed that. In my opinion this happens because Smokestack is configured with the default value for firewall driver, which is nova.virt.libvirt.firewall.NWFilterFirewall.

On XenAPI backends we would like to use the firewall driver provided with this changeset, which is nova.virt.xenapi.firewall.DomOIptablesFirewall.

In order to function properly, the 'host' XenAPI plugin should be updated as well. 

Can you point me to the people or group in charge for SmokeStack?"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-14 15:41:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Salvatore,

That would be me. Let me try that and get back to you.

Dan'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-14 17:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Dan!
Please ping me should you need some more info.
I think I misspelled the name of the driver in my previous comment. The correct class is:
nova.virt.xenapi.firewall.Dom0IptablesFirewallDriver'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-16 16:06:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Salvatore,

Looking at this today I was able to make some progress. Looks like you have a conflict in nova/virt/libvirt/firewall.py though. Can you have a look?'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-22 15:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-22 15:32:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Sorry about the delay.
I have resolved the conflicts and updated a new patch.

Dan, please let me know if you need any kind of assistance with getting SmokeStack tests to work with the xenapi firewall driver.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-28 20:29:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(13 inline comments)

Hey Salvatore, I've got some comments inline mostly regarding style. Thanks for doing this!"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-29 02:57:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Hi Salvatore,

First of all I've pegged in the needed Chef updates so that subsequent runs should always use the Dom0 firewall driver when the connection is 'xenapi':

https://github.com/dprince/openstack-chef/commit/8dad085bbe87a14c91cfd7993771257218175eff

Thanks for pointing this out.

I run Xen tests on every single merge prop (and have a high confidence in the tests) so I'd expect to see this pass once it it runs. Thanks for your patience!

---

Looks like there is another merge conflict in vmops.py:

CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in nova/virt/xenapi/vmops.py

---

Other than that I found one major issue with this implementation:

As currently implemented taking a server snapshot (creating an image) will delete all the IPtables rules for that instance on dom0. The root cause seems to be that vmops.py snapshot function makes a call to _delete the template vm reference. Perhaps you can add an extra flag/option to _delete in vmops to avoid deleting the firewall rules when deleting a template vm? Let me know if you have any questions on this."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2011-12-29 16:39:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Dan, Brian:

Thanks for your reviews.
Thanks for spotting the issue concerning iptables rules being deleted when a snapshot is created. Unfortunately I did not consider VM snapshots as a use case when testing my code. Shame on me for that :) 

I think I should be able to solve this issue as suggested by Dan.

I will provide an updated patch set as soon as possible.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-10 14:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (15 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-10 17:16:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-10 17:19:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Path set 4 pushed. 
This changeset addresses the reviewers' comments. In particular, the issue concerning snapshot has been solved by avoiding removing instance filters in vmops._destroy when both the 'is_a_snapshot' and 'is_a_template' attributes in the VM record are True."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks Salvatore! This one is a go from me.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-12 01:27:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Nice work, salvatore.  I was playing with this today, and got the Dom0 driver working.  The DomU driver errors out for me though: http://pastie.org/pastes/3169732/text - do I need to configure anything special to make it work?'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-12 03:13:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Actually, my previous issue was just a flag typo.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-12 04:00:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I spent a bit of time with both drivers, and they both work as expected.  I was testing using dashboard, which is starting to feel pretty decent with xen.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-12 04:31:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Blueprint xenapi-security-groups

Provides two drivers for implementing security groups in xenapi:
1) domU driver that enforces security groups on the Openstack virtual appliance (use advised with FlatDHCP in HA mode)
2) dom0 driver that enforces security groups where VIFs are attached

Both drivers translate security groups into iptables rules.
Existing libvirt code has been refactored to reduce the amount of duplicated code to a minimum

Now Addressing reviewers's comments on style. Fixing issue spotted with snapshots
Change-Id: Ifa16a8f2508a709be03241bac0f942fe1a51d1e8

commit_message:
Fix metadata mapping in s3._s3_parse_manifest.

Fixes bug #827617

Fixes incorrect output of the following euca2ools commands:
    'euca-describe-images'
    'euca-describe-instances'
Which occours when user published 'ami' image with 'ari&aki' or 'aki'
image(s).

Fixes minor typo:
    'manifext' -> 'manifest'

Change-Id: If32357e3ea6685476df9dbb6e74af710153457b9

[{'created': '2012-01-12 00:39:39.000000000', 'message': "PEP8 quantum cleanup

Fixes bug #911663

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()
instead of comparing types directly.

Change-Id: Id5c797d3339d0d7015bac386088133540f0c0c9e
"}, {'created': '2012-01-12 00:39:39.000000000', 'message': "PEP8 quantum cleanup

Fixes bug #911663

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()
instead of comparing types directly.

Change-Id: Id5c797d3339d0d7015bac386088133540f0c0c9e
"}]
commit_message:
PEP8 quantum cleanup

Fixes bug #911663

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()
instead of comparing types directly.

Change-Id: Id5c797d3339d0d7015bac386088133540f0c0c9e

commit_message:
Converts nova.containers to use new tables, modals, etc.

Adds support for generic paging to tables, as well as various
improvements to the tables and actions APIs. Adds more data
to the container and object table displays to make them
more useful.

Change-Id: I6c7434657de4398a9da30911b281275d7c978d8b

the stable branch, e.g. 2011.3.1.

(cherry picked from commit bd035a5a6d2d36102986da491c996f1c17fcda40)

Add optional revision field to version number

the stable branch, e.g. 2011.3.1.

See http://wiki.openstack.org/StableBranchRelease

(cherry picked from commit 1590dadcb495f97a3a2d86c13b5d0f847e6d5964)

commit_message:
Fix libguestfs operation with specified partitions

* nova/virt/disk/guestfs.py (mnt_dev): Convert the partition
parameter to int, so we now support a "1" string passed from
nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py.  Also diagnose any
unconvertible strings.

Change-Id: I744bd1fc3ea065891b5ce112dbe27f73086f302e

commit_message:
Don't overwrite local context on elevated

 * Adds an 'overwrite' parameter to context.__init__
 * Overwrite is set to false for elevated and get_admin_context
 * Fixes bug 899302

Change-Id: Ic9464e5813d6db38c48239c7ea8f15aa1bff5562

commit_message:
Remove 'location' from GlanceImageService

Glance no longer returns location through its public API, so we
should not attempt to display it. Addresses bug 911599.

Change-Id: I3400006eb6ab94095c0c2d2b5dc90cb9b7775a84

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-09 20:05:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Is Bueno!'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-09 21:16:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Overall the code looks good.

Is this in reference to a bug or a blueprint, or just a general, forward-looking addition?

I ask, because the deprecated function isn't actually used in the patch, so I'm curious what concrete need prompted this?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-09 21:24:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As I was writing the serialization decorators patch, I kept thinking, "Gee, it would be useful to be able to mark a class as deprecated, so it'd be easy to find later and so I'd have log messages to remind me."  The classes I wanted to mark deprecated are now gone, but there are some other classes that *could* be marked deprecated, and I'm about to start work on the next patch in the series and I figure I'll find some more classes and/or functions that could stand to be marked deprecated.

So, yes, this is a forward-looking addition.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-10 03:17:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hey Kevin,

SO... given this decorator isn't actually in use would a couple unit tests be in order?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-10 16:31:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Indeed, but I'm debating whether unit tests or functional tests make sense here…"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-10 17:22:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-10 17:58:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Is Bueno!'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:41:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:45:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Not sure I like the stubbing of the class.  Would be more fun to try to create a metaclass and set the deprecated class's __metaclass__ attribute.  But then, I guess you probably wouldn't be able to deprecate a class that already uses __metaclass__..  hehe.   Just throwing a random thought out for discussion.  This is probably fine the way it is."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-10 21:55:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Rick: See in-line responses…

Chris: I tried a variety of techniques.  I tried dynamically creating a subclass, overriding __new__() and class and instance methods, but that messed up super().  Another approach I thought of would be to generate a new class from scratch, but then I'd have to unwrap classmethod() and staticmethod() objects, which is non-trivial in Python 2.6 (Python 2.7 does provide a __func__ attribute, IIRC).  In the end, the approach in this patch worked the best.

And yeah, I wanted to avoid using __metaclass__ for this: I specifically wanted a decorator that allowed you to specify a message, and with a __metaclass__ approach, not only do you run afoul of classes already using __metaclass__, but you have to specify another random variable to hold the message."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-10 22:07:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-10 22:11:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-10 22:18:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-10 22:35:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-01-11 16:29:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

we also need to be able to deprecate arguments.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-11 16:43:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Trey: Indeed, that would be very useful; however, it's a much harder problem to solve :)"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-11 18:37:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

re: arguments, not only would it be harder to solve, it would probably be prohibitively expensive in the mean time.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-11 18:54:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Approved

Approve-ed!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-11 19:04:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

'}]
commit_message:
Add @utils.deprecated().

This will allow us to mark deprecated classes and functions/methods as
such.  A warning is issued each time a deprecated function/method is
called, or when a deprecated class is instantiated, or when any class
or static method on a deprecated class is called.

Change-Id: I4b5858492bc14768ac2e12c542bc343962761e34

commit_message:
LP Bug#914770 - NameError in test_images

Thanks to bcwaldon for making me look silly :)

Now checks the location header returned from createImage
call in the case when the image is erroneously created
and should then be deleted...

Change-Id: Iec303355ccb7d19fd4667462b82fc8e95bdafde7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-11 17:08:29.000000000', 'message': "Add new cfg module

As described here:

  http://wiki.openstack.org/CommonConfigModule

The module implements an API for defining configuration options and
reading values for those options that a user may have set in a config
file or on the command line.

The module is successfully in use in both Nova and Glance. Some work
remains in Nova to switch from using it under a gflags compatible
shim layer, but Glance is using it fully.

There doesn't appear to be any blockers to other projects moving over
to it fairly easily. Swift would perhaps be the next project to tackle.

Just to go through potential future compatibility concerns:

  - Nova (the scroundrel) hackily uses the private ConfigOpts::_oparser
    in order to disable interspersed args. This was just for nova-manage
    and can probably be resolved some other way. In any case, Nova
    shouldn't switch to openstack-common's cfg API until it removes this
    hack.

  - the CommonConfigOpts subclass set of logging related options is
    perhaps assuming too much about what configuration options should
    be common across all the projects. However, it seems a fairly sane
    set and the worst that can happen is that projects avoid using it.

  - the parameters to the Opt constructor fairly closely mirror
    optparse, but they're fairly generic and shouldn't prevent us from
    switching to e.g. argparse

  - stuff like %prog expansion in the ConfigOpt's usage ctor param is a
    similar concern, but it's a very minor concern.

  - find_config_files() search path is perhaps too much policy for
    openstack-common; however, it is probably as generic as it could
    be and projects which need a different policy can just not use
    the function

On the whole, I think we're in good shape wrt future compatibility.

Change-Id: I279a9db7806d80aff3b9b085b4a9e4fb193662f9
"}]
commit_message:
Add new cfg module

As described here:

  http://wiki.openstack.org/CommonConfigModule

The module implements an API for defining configuration options and
reading values for those options that a user may have set in a config
file or on the command line.

The module is successfully in use in both Nova and Glance. Some work
remains in Nova to switch from using it under a gflags compatible
shim layer, but Glance is using it fully.

There doesn't appear to be any blockers to other projects moving over
to it fairly easily. Swift would perhaps be the next project to tackle.

Just to go through potential future compatibility concerns:

  - Nova (the scroundrel) hackily uses the private ConfigOpts::_oparser
    in order to disable interspersed args. This was just for nova-manage
    and can probably be resolved some other way. In any case, Nova
    shouldn't switch to openstack-common's cfg API until it removes this
    hack.

  - the CommonConfigOpts subclass set of logging related options is
    perhaps assuming too much about what configuration options should
    be common across all the projects. However, it seems a fairly sane
    set and the worst that can happen is that projects avoid using it.

  - the parameters to the Opt constructor fairly closely mirror
    optparse, but they're fairly generic and shouldn't prevent us from
    switching to e.g. argparse

  - stuff like %prog expansion in the ConfigOpt's usage ctor param is a
    similar concern, but it's a very minor concern.

  - find_config_files() search path is perhaps too much policy for
    openstack-common; however, it is probably as generic as it could
    be and projects which need a different policy can just not use
    the function

On the whole, I think we're in good shape wrt future compatibility.

Change-Id: I279a9db7806d80aff3b9b085b4a9e4fb193662f9

commit_message:
nova-manage floating ip fixes

* Add pool, interface to 'floating list' output
  These columns were added to the floating_ips table in
  https://review.openstack.org/2892 and are not visible elsewhere
* Fix 'floating delete' to skip network/broadcast addresses
  Makes the delete command match the create command behaviour
  introduced in https://review.openstack.org/2663
* Address changes listed in bug 817281
  Change host column in output to project ID, change hostname
  column to uuid

Change-Id: Ibbfbe9ed5543927a6b2a1e676f5617901a32f897

LP Bug#912800 - Delete image remain in cache

Adds a functional test case that verifies that when an
image is deleted and the cache middleware is place, that
the image is properly removed from the image cache.

that provides the nova endpoint.  This change allows the RestClient

commit_message:
RestClient to target specific services in Keystone catalog

Previously, the rest client had no notion of specific services
other than nova, since that is all the current tests cover.  It
also assumed the first row in the keystone.services was the service
that provides the nova endpoint.  This change allows the RestClient
to target specific services in the keystone catalog by name.  Current
nova services are updated to find the nova endpoint.  Future services
that hit glance or swift directly can make use of this as well.

Cleanup pep8 in exceptions.py

Fixes bug 911528

Change-Id: I4d885d96a1d360021b4c8f6aa562f863c6df3608

commit_message:
Do not overwrite project_id from request params

Prevent project_id overwriting from OSAPI request parameters.
The patch is actually very simple (nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py) but
needs significant test adjustments (nova/tests/*) to pass.

Fixes bug 904072. Patch from Vish Ishaya and Mark McLoughlin.

(cherry picked from commit c9c09bd60e7a0e0258d218a31d7878755bea1395)

Change-Id: I66ea0f178ce6271ec1020e9f1a73bd4e8c83ddab

commit_message:
Add __init__.py from plugin to be copied on setup scripts

Using debian building scripts to package Quantum and I was getting this error:
('Inner Exception: %s', ImportError('No module named plugins.sample.SamplePlugin',))

Because none of the setup_*.py was copying the __init__.py from the plugins

Thanks

Change-Id: I29699f1f293e2ca271234a2b708aaa1d3637c9dd

commit_message:
Rename .quantum-venv to .venv.

This simplifies a number of Jenkins jobs which currently, other
than directory names, could be the same for all OpenStack
projects. By renaming the virtualenv directory, the redundant
Jenkins virtualenv build and copy jobs can be eliminated.

Change-Id: I93c7f6577b4c3a76b021f002bda59fcb8fac3f95

If it's not specified, use sys.stdin to read image data. No need to

(cherry picked from commit 1571cd8f83cb80f2c89bd226883d7f802119bfb2)

Change-Id: I057312becad59b3dd7a71f94d25ebd032e1a7b52

commit_message:
Removed bin/glance's TTY detection.

Fixes bug 907906

The logic is sound: if location=XXX is specified, use that.
If it's not specified, use sys.stdin to read image data. No need to
error when location=XXX is specified and stdin just happens to be a TTY.

(cherry picked from commit 1571cd8f83cb80f2c89bd226883d7f802119bfb2)

Change-Id: I057312becad59b3dd7a71f94d25ebd032e1a7b52
